Preface to Volume III on Batteries
Benjamin Franklin used a battery to describe an array of charged glass plates in 1748 and within 90 years, the advent of electric doorbells, telegraphs, and telephones required a backup energy source. John Daniell (1836) developed primary battery in the form of a cell which could deliver 1.1 V and specific energy less than 0.1 MJ/kg to power these devices and the demand for greater output never ceased. Almost 115 years later, Lew Urry developed (1949) the Alkaline Manganese Battery with 1.25 V and a specific energy around 0.4 MJ/kg. Almost 20 years later (in 1971) Alexandr Kloss and Boris Tsenter implemented nickel and hydrogen to form the precursor of the Nickel Metal Hydride battery, also able to deliver 1.2 V but at a higher specific energy (~140 MJ/kg). Lastly, the work by Akira Yoshino of Asahi Chemical led to the lithium-ion battery at 1.5 V and a specific energy density of 0.8 MJ/kg. This was rapidly followed by the lithium polymer battery which had a flexible casing and enabled the form factor to be altered. Portable electronics could be used for longer periods, including cell phones, laptops, and multimedia devices, such as tablets, ipads, nanoPCs, and wearable electronics, increasing lithium-ion battery sales past the billion units sold mark.
The advantage of the lithium-ion rechargeable batteries as secondary batteries (LIB) relative to nickel-cadmium or nickel-hydride batteries is the endurance of the battery coupled with high specific energy density and no memory effects. These storage devices make up the top three choices, after which manganese dioxide-zinc and lead acid are the next most common storage device. Unlike the other metals, lithium has distinct advantages. It has a low atomic mass, low ionization enthalpy, and high electrode potential, resulting in high energy density relative to zinc-based batteries.
Lithium-ion batteries are a system where the lithium metal forms the anode with a nonaqueous electrolyte such as propylene carbonate-lithium perchlorate and carbonbased cathode. The lithium at the anode forms whisker-like formations which resemble dendrites, causing the battery to short-circuit, in addition to safety issues related to a strong oxidizer such as perchlorate. Other concerns relate to replacement of lithium aluminum and/or polyacene conducting polymer used for memory backup or powering small devices with solar recharge, which may be less efficient and more costly. The “current” lithium-ion batteries do not have lithium metal but intercalation of lithium ions into the active electrode surfaces, using the Asahi design, which uses
v
the carbon-based anode and lithium cobalt oxide as the cathode. During charging, lithium would be inserted into the carbon anode, and during discharging, lithium would be extracted. The battery design due to conducting polymers could be cylindrical and was 18 mm by 65 mm in length and known as 18650 type with a capacity of 800 mAh/g. During the decades, after World War II, the demands for portable energy have progressively increased, requiring design of a new generation of energy storage devices. Recently, increased battery usage and lifespan have been achieved by the substitution of carbon-based anodes with more flexible graphitebased carbon and changes to electrolyte and modification of lithium cobalt oxides and cell design (polymers, binders, and internal circuitry) relative to lithium only anodes. The early batteries contained mesophase carbon microbead (MCMB with a capacity of 280 mAh/g). By incorporating functional electrolytes that passivate the electrode, higher graphitization of the anode carbon material can be achieved without solvent decomposition, leading to greater catalyticity at the active electrode surface. This graphitization could be accomplished using mesophase carbon fiber, or more active form of MCMBs yielding capacity of 372 mAh.g 1. The addition of cyclohexylbenzene would lead to the generation of hydrogen gas at higher voltages and would interrupt the current output, safely shutting down the battery. In the early 2000s, the 18650 type cell had a capacity of 2.4 Ah or an energy density of 200 Wh/ kg, which currently have increased to 3.6 Ah and 250 Wh/kg. The passivation of the active surfaces through the introduction of electrolyte additives has enabled the higher energy densities to be reached. To achieve even higher capacities, electrode conditioning is required. Here the cell undergoes several charge-discharge cycles at a low rate (1/4 C) to decompose the additives and form the protective film. The cell is held in their charged state for a week (e.g., 0.005 V vs. Li/Li+ for 10 h, Li+ possess ultrahigh capacity [3,860 mAh g 1] and the very low standard negative electrochemical potential [ 3.040 V]) to ensure completion of the protective film. In the absence of conditioning, lithium ions can intercalate into graphite (in propylene carbonate-based electrolytes) forming a large number of active sites. These sites are formed because of nonhomogeneous voltage distribution across the anode surface due to underpotential (0 V vs. Li/Li+) during the Li+ intercalation. Areas of graphite which become exfoliated do not get
vi Preface to Volume III on Batteries
Li+ penetration, instead Li metal deposition occurs. This would decrease cell potential to 0.8 V and decrease the cell life cycle. The next stage of development for the 18650 type cells is the use of graphene, planar lithium-nickel-cobalt-aluminum, and nickel-manganese-cobalt cathode-type materials, in addition to new electrolyte additives to promote Li+ intercalation, suppress Li metal deposition, and promote greater homogeneity across the electrode surface. With these advances, a capacity of 3.0 Ah may be possible by focusing on nano-carbonaceous materials, improved Li+ intercalation, and use of polyanions other than oxides to increase cell voltages. These different chemistries and formulations are summarized in Table 1.
This book contains an overview of energy policy. Energy policy is critical to long-term planning and stability. While consumer demands related to home and travel account for 4% of the gross domestic product, they account for 28% and 41% of energy usage and CO2 emissions, respectively. Electrical storage such as LIBs has a CO2 “tax” associated with them. Only hydroelectric is CO2-neutral, although fuel cells could fall into this category, LIB, in the long run, could assist in lowering the CO2 emission profile when compared with electrical generation using coal (baseline comparison), which has been subjected to peak-load pricing and lead to increasing the efficiency of national energy resources, clean-coal development, as well as
Note the charge and discharge temperature(s) are different; typically the battery can discharge at lower temperatures but should not be charged if frozen. Cycle life is based on the depth of discharge (DoD), where shallow DoD at moderate to cool temperatures will prolong cycle life.
Preface to Volume III on Batteries vii
development of sustainable resources. Lithium-ion batteries have a role to play both as portable power and as storage, where electric vehicles could be used to power homes in emergencies such as earthquakes and hurricanes when the “centralized grid” fails. The role of national energy policy vis-à-vis LIB and energy storage including recycling of lithium-ion batteries are reviewed.
Other chapters are more traditional in offering an in-depth review of electrode materials, electrolytes, and additives for LIB, as well as indicators of the future directions for continued maturation of the LIB. Here, the authors will explicitly discuss advances in electrode design as the anatomy of the battery is the same as in Daniell’s time of anode, cathode, electrolyte, and casing/binding. The authors discuss materials composites for forming newer more reactive electrode surfaces without side reactions or dendrite formation, with higher specific capacity, energy densities, and cycling stability. The fabrication using more streamlined procedures where appropriate is discussed, including newer materials, such as antimony trioxide, chalcogens, and titanium/molybdenum disulfide as high potential anodes. Cathode materials based on nickel cobalt manganese oxide have been employed to minimize cation dissolution of the cathode materials. Other approaches include the use of layered oxides, structured materials to encapsulation designed to reduce the degree of material dissociation, particularly after prolonged use. In addition, alternative strategies related to modification of carbon nanotubes, graphite, and graphene with dopants, passivation of electrodes by coating, or alloying to enhance Li-ion diffusivity are explored. The purposes of such strategies and approaches are to minimize lithium metal deposition and to improve electrode conductivity, ionic mobility, and battery capacity during charging and discharging cycles and use.
All-solid-state lithium-ion batteries’ solid electrolytes, such as NASICON-type, perovskite-type, anti-perovskite type, garnet-type, sulfide-type, Li3N-type, and other chemistries, require optimal ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability at room and higher operational temperatures. These performance characteristics are discussed with respect to changes in ion mobility at different temperature regimes. The current challenges related to electrolyte selection, refinement of the interfaces, and interfacial resistance are reviewed beyond LISICON- and LiPON-type of solid electrolytes.
Room temperature molten salts (ionic liquids) have drawn attention for electrochemical energy storage. These systems offer excellent thermal and electrochemical stability, exhibit low volatility, and are enabled as electrolytes in batteries such as LIBs, sodium-ion, lithium-air (O2), and Li-sulfur batteries for clean energy storage. The issue of low volatility and low flammability is discussed as well as used in allsolid-state batteries to improve the conductivity of the solid electrolyte, in addition to modification of electrode materials to take advantage of the new physical and chemical properties.
The thermochemistry and modeling aspects are also discussed. Lithium-ion batteries’ stability is typically evaluated by cycling under a galvanostatic regime ( 1/4 C – C/2-rate) between 2.75 Vand 4.2 V for up to 250–1,500 cycles. After each completed 25n (n = 1–4) cycles, the discharge capacity, capacity loss, and average discharge potential are evaluated. Then cells undergo a supplemental charge and
viii Preface to Volume III on Batteries
discharge cycle at higher C/6 rate followed by thermodynamics measurements to determine the open-circuit potential (OCP), entropy, and enthalpy values. Calculations show that state functions of entropy and enthalpy exhibit higher sensitivity to morphological changes in the electrode surface or crystal structure, such as graphite carbon-based anodes and lithium cobalt oxide cathode through repeated cycling (aging) relative to changes in Gibbs free energy estimated from the state of charge or depth of discharge, and OCP values.
Coupled with ex situ X-ray diffractometry, electron microscopy, and Raman spectroscopy analyses on the electrode materials, the relationship between state functions, electrochemical output, crystal structure composition, and density of states can be assessed at both the anode and cathode during aging and inferences made using computational means of processes to stabilize the cathode and/or anode by increased graphitization during the aging process.
The role of non-lithium electrodes is also discussed as it is apparent that increased electric vehicle usage will deplete lithium and cobalt unless aggressive recycling, reuse, and transition to non-lithium are introduced at an early stage, as the demand for portable energy is likely to increase in the near term.
The general aim has been to learn how to assess the technical impact of new active materials and to increase charge density as well as operational reliability, cost, ease of use, and safety. Lastly, no book would be complete without the stellar contribution of the authors, their research group, and institutions. We also would like to extend our deep appreciation to our institution, colleagues, and students as well as the editorial staff at Springer who have strived to deliver the best possible scholarly product. As always, errors and omission are the responsibility of the editors, for which we as preface authors ask forgiveness.
We also wish to thank the Robert Welch Foundation (AC-0006) Award for assistance with part of the research.

About the Editors
Qiang Zhen received his doctoral degree in the field of Metallurgical Physical Chemistry at the University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2000. Currently, he is a distinguished Professor of Research Center of NanoScience and Nano-Technology, Shanghai University. He is the Director of Advanced Functional Materials Laboratory, Engineering Research Center of Material Composition and Advanced Dispersion Technology, Ministry of Education, China. He also serves as the Dean of the Science and Technology Development Academy of Shanghai University, is one of the executive members of the China Instrument Functional Materials Society Council, and is member of China Silicate Society. In 2002, he visited the Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hong Kong University, and then the French National Center for Scientific Research, University of Science and Technology in Lille, France, from 2005 to 2012. His research interests focus on solid electrolyte for fuel-cells and sensors, and design, fabrication, and characterization of micro-/nano-composites. He has directed more than 30 scientific research projects, supported by different funding agencies, such as National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC), NSFC International Cooperation Plan, and Excellent Talents Supporting Programs. He has published more than 60 papers as a leading coauthor and has reviewed journal papers and project proposals.
xiii
Sajid Bashir received his Ph.D. in Analytical Chemistry from the University of Warwick, England, 2001. He was a postgraduate research associate at Cornell University to conduct research in the field of plant genetics. Currently, he is a Full Professor at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK) and a Faculty Fellow at the US Air Force. He has directed and participated in more than 20 projects supported by the Welch Foundation, TAMUK, Texas Workforce Commission, and US National Institutes of Health. He has coauthored more than 80 book chapters and peer reviewed journal articles. He is a Fellow and Chartered Chemist of the Royal Society of Chemistry and a Chartered Scientist. During his service in TAMUK, he trained more than 3,000 students on both undergraduate and graduate levels. He created online courses and established safety training protocols in conjunction with the risk management. Currently, he collaborates with the local law enforcement as a consultant.
Jingbo Louise Liu received her Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from the University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2001. She is a Full Professor at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK) and is focused on materials preparation, characterization, and applications. She is the Fellow of Royal Society of Chemistry and DEBI Faculty Fellow at the US Air Force Research Laboratory. She has authored and coauthored books and book chapters and peer reviewed journal articles (more than 90). During her 12-year services in TAMUK, she taught more than 8,000 students and trained about 150 students and scholars to conduct leading edge research. She directed and/or participated in the projects (more than 40) supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) (USA and China), Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC), ACS Petroleum Research Funds, and the Department of Education as principal investigator (PI), Co-PI, and senior personnel.

About the Authors
Dr. Nancy KingSanders’ background in higher education spans more than 27 years to include a current appointment as Associate Vice President for Student Success at Texas A&M University-Kingsville, a position she has held since 2011. Prior appointments include Associate Dean for Graduate Studies, Administrative Intern for Academic Affairs, Graduate Music Education Coordinator, as well as attaining tenure and the rank of Full Professor in the Music Department at Texas A&M University-Kingsville. Under her administrative leadership at TAMUK, she established the Center for Student Success to include AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination) for Higher Education, the First-Year Experience, a two-semester First-Year Seminar Course, Centralized Academic Advising, the Graduation Pathway Success Mentoring Center, the Pathway Academic Assistance Tutoring Center, Freshman Interest Groups, Academic Career Literacy, Mapping First-Year Seminar curriculum to General Education Component Area options, and Javelina Common Read Program, resulting in a 15.9% increase in First-Time in College retention at Texas A&M University-Kingsville. She was also selected as a National First-Year Student Advocate by Cengage and the National Resource Center for the FirstYear Experience and Students in Transition. Dr. KingSanders’ other responsibilities include all academic support for undergraduate students and Co-Principal Investigator for a Title V Individual $2.625 Million Hispanic Serving Institution Grant to embed research into undergraduate courses.
xv
Weixin Song is a Ph.D. student in Materials Science at Imperial College London, United Kingdom. He started his Ph.D. in 2015 funded by the President’s Ph.D. Scholarship of Imperial College after he received his B.Sc. in 2012 and M.Sc. in 2015, both from Central South University, China. His research interests are materials electrochemistry and materials characterizations, particularly the applications in energy storage, electrocatalysis, and photoelectrocatalysis. He has 39 publications that have been cited more than 1,700 times and 17 licensed patents. He has been awarded the Armourers and Brasiers Rolls-Royce Scheme in 2018 and the STFC Early Career Award in 2016 from the United Kingdom. He was also awarded the national scholarship and the highest honor when he studied in Central South University. He is a member in Center for Doctoral Training (CDT) in Advanced Characterization of Materials and London Center for Nanotechnology.
Jun Chen is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Materials at the University of Oxford, United Kingdom. She received her Bachelor’s degree in Applied Chemistry in 2014 and Master’s degree in Physical Chemistry on Metallurgy in 2017, both from Central South University, China. Her Master’s research focused on the synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical application of titanium-based nanomaterials for energy storage devices. She was awarded the national scholarship and the honor of “Top Ten Outstanding Students” during her study in Central South University. She then started her Ph.D. in October 2017 in Prof. Jamie Warner’s group, fully funded by China Scholarship Council. Her research interest is in two-dimensional (2D) materials, particularly the atomic structure study of transitional metal dichalcogenides and their heterostructures for understanding their properties and behavior. She has 26 publications in peer-reviewed journals, with more than 1,000 citations since 2014, as well as 7 licensed patents.
xvi About the Authors
Carlos M. Costa graduated in Physics in 2005 and obtained his Master’s degree in Materials Engineering in 2007. In 2014, he received his Ph.D. in Physics from the Science School of the University of Minho. Currently, he is postdoctoral researcher at the same institution. His work is mainly focused on the development of advanced polymer composites and new materials and formulations for energy storage applications, i.e., lithium-ion batteries and printed batteries.
Renato Gonçalves graduated in Chemistry in 2009, in 2011 received his Master’s degree in Characterization Techniques and Chemistry Analysis, and in 2017 obtained his Ph.D. in Materials Engineering, all at the University of Minho, Portugal. Currently, he is working with Electroactive Smart Material group of the Physics Department at the University of Minho, Portugal. His work focuses on polymers composites, inorganic synthesis, and magnetoelectric nanocomposites with advanced applications like sensors and actuators. Recently, his work focuses on energy field at innovative green printed batteries for advanced devices. He also collaborated with the University of Basque Country, Spain; BCMaterials, Spain; and Cambridge University, United Kingdom, among others.
S. Lanceros-Méndez graduated in Physics at the University of the Basque Country, Leioa, Spain. He obtained his Ph.D. at the Institute of Physics of the Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg, Germany. He is Ikerbasque Research Professor and Scientific Director at BCMaterials – Basque Center for Materials, Applications and Nanostructures, Leioa, Spain, and Associate Professor at the Physics Department of the University of Minho, Portugal (on leave). His work is focused in the area of smart and multifunctional materials for sensors and actuators, energy, and biomedical applications.
About the Authors xvii
Bin Liu received his Ph.D. from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in China. He is currently a research scientist in the Electrochemical Materials and Systems Group in the Energy Processes & Materials Division at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. Dr. Liu has extensive experience in the development of electrodes and electrolytes for next-generation energy storage devices (i.e., Li-metal battery, Li-O2 battery, flexible Li-ion batteries, fiber supercapacitors, Mg-ion battery, and functional integrated devices). Dr. Liu has published 1 book chapter and more than 45 papers with total citations of over 4,200 and H-index of 30. Seven papers were selected as Thomson Reuters ESI 1% Highly Cited Papers. Eight papers were featured as cover and back cover of peer-reviewed journals. His studies were highlighted by American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), Nature Nanotechnology, Nature Photonics, Materials Research Society (MRS) Materials360, weekly Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC) Publishing press pack, Chemie.DE, Chemistry World, and China Central Television Channel 1 (CCTV 1). Dr. Liu holds three issued Chinese patents and one pending US patent as well.
Huilin Pan received her Ph.D. in Condensed Matter Physics from the Institute of Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences. She is currently serving as a research scientist in the field of electrochemical materials and systems at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. Dr. Pan has 8 years of experience in energy storage materials/chemistry and advanced characterizations in different electrochemistry systems, including lithium, sodium, and zinc batteries. She has published more than 30 papers on battery-related research and had filed 4 US patent applications. She was honored as the “TOP 1% author, highly cited in the Royal Society of Chemistry” in 2014. Her primary research interest includes the development of battery materials and electrolytes for energy storage and the underlying reaction mechanisms in battery systems.
xviii About the Authors
Wei Liu received her Bachelor’s inMaterials Physics from Beijing Normal University in 2008 and Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Tsinghua University in 2013. During the year 2010–2011, she visited the University of Tokyo for half a year. From 2013 to 2017, she worked at Stanford University as a postdoctoral scholar. She is currently Assistant Professor at ShanghaiTech University. Her research interests cover the area of materials science, nanotechnology, and solid state ionics, with a focus on studies of lithium batteries and fuel cells. Dr. Liu has been an author or coauthor of 47 papers published in journals such as Nature Energy, Nature Communications, Science Advances, AdvancedMaterials, and Journal of the American Chemical Society. She is also peer reviewer of journals including Joule, Nano Letters, and Nano Energy. In 2018, she was awarded as one of the Distinguished Young Scholars by the Thousand Talents Program.
Qiming Tang holds his Bachelor’s degree from Hunan University of Technology, China, in 2015, and he received his M.S. in the Department of Material Science and Engineering from Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen) in 2018. Tang is now Research Assistant in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at HITSZ, in Dr. Junwei Wu’s group. His research is mainly focused on the synthesis and application of metal-based chalcogenides anode materials for lithiumion and sodium-ion batteries, especially in Sn-based and Fe-based chalcogenides.
Qin Jiang received her Bachelor’s degree from Nanchang Hangkong University, China, in 2016. She is a graduate student in the Department of Material Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), under the supervision of Prof. Junwei Wu. Her current research mainly focuses on synthesis and applications of iron-based nanomaterials as anode materials for lithium-ion and sodium-ion battery.
About the Authors xix
Junwei Wu obtained his B.E and M.E from the University of Science and Technology Beijing, China, and a Ph.D. from West Virginia University, USA. He is now an Associate Professor in the Department of Material Science and Engineering at Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen). His research concerns the synthesis and characterizations of nanomaterials and their applications for energy storage and conversion, such as Li/Na-ion batteries, Li-S batteries, and full solid cell. He was awarded R&D 100 Award in 2011. He has published more than 50 papers in international journals.
Xingjun Liu obtained his B.E. and M.E. from Northeastern University, China, in 1988, and Ph.D. from Tohoku University, Japan, 1998. He is a Professor in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering and State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen). He focuses on thermodynamic energy changes related to changes of phase and phase transitions of materials, as well as computational analysis of materials, including analysis of metal materials, and functional materials. The analyses involve electronic packaging materials, composite materials, amorphous materials, high-temperature alloys, rare earth materials, etc. He holds 36 Chinese patents and has published more than 300 papers in national and international journals.
Dr. Yanbin Chen, Professor, candidate of the National Talent Project in China, and candidate of the Beijing Capital Technical Leading Talent Project, is currently the Vice President of Beijing Easpring Material Technology Co., Ltd. He was awarded Ph.D. by the University of Science and Technology Beijing in 2001. He has been engaged in research, development, and industrialization of the key materials for lithium battery for 20 years. Up to now, he has developed more than 50 products of three

series cathode materials, including lithium cobalt oxide, lithium manganese oxide, and lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide, has published more than 50 papers, has obtained 16 licensed patents, and has drafted 9 national and industrial standards. The Easpring is a global top supplier of cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries, providing high-end products to leading battery makers, including LG Chem, Samsung SDI, SK Innovation, Sanyo, Sony, CATL, Farasis, BYD, BAK, etc. The Easpring has been recognized as an Excellent Export Enterprise, National Technical Innovation Demonstration Enterprise, and National Accredited Enterprise Technical Center.
Professor Yafei Liu is currently the Director of Institute of Lithium-ion Battery Materials of Beijing Easpring Material Technology Co., Ltd. He is also an affiliate with the State Chinese Government Council Special Allowance Program as Topic Expert. He was awarded Ph.D. by the University of Science and Technology of China in 2001. He has been engaged in research, development, and industrialization of lithium-ion cathode materials and their precursors, fuel cell materials, and gas-sensitive and functional materials for a long time. So far, he has published more than 50 papers and has applied 52 patents.
Xiujun Qi received her Bachelor’s degree in School of Materials Science and Engineering, Liaocheng University, China, in 2015. She attended China University of Mining and Technology in the same year, pursuing her Ph.D. in School of Materials Science and Engineering under the guidance of Prof. Zhicheng Ju. Her current research focuses on the synthesis and electrochemical characterization of heteroatom-doped carbon materials for advanced batteries such as lithium-ion batteries and potassium-ion batteries. She has coauthored six research articles in peer-reviewed journals and has joined several international conferences.
About the Authors xxi
Zheng Xing received her Bachelor and Master degrees in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering from Shandong University, China, in 2007 and 2010, following which she began her Ph.D. at the School of Chemistry and Materials Science at the University of Science and Technology of China under the supervision of Prof. Yitai Qian. She received her Ph.D. in Inorganic Chemistry in June 2013. She then joined the School of Materials Science and Engineering at the China University of Mining and Technology as an Assistant Professor. Her research focuses on the study of the transitional metal oxides and new carbon-based functional materials for energy conversion and storage. She has published more than 30 research articles in peer-reviewed journals and has joined many international conferences.

Abstract The increase in global population has resulted in increased demand for stationary and portable energy, as well as increases in carbon dioxide emissions. The increases in greenhouse gases at the present trajectory will increase the global warming potential above the 2 threshold. At this threshold, it is anticipated that climate changes will adversely affect the land and sea masses. To minimize the potential of global warming and meet the increased energy demands, high-energy capacity lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries in portable electronics and electric vehicles offer one potential solution. Current Li-ion chemistries focus on lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM), lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), and lithium titanium oxide (LTO) as cathodes and lithium metal (Li-metal) as an anode. Other semiconductor materials are used as alloying anodes (Si, Sn) that also include chalcogenides (S), metal halides (Br), and polymers. These materials enable the cell to maintain a high charge density through enhanced Li and electron transport, lesser volumetric expansion, material dissolution, and surface reactions between electrode and electrolyte generating heat. In part, battery thermal management is controlled using passive cooling in addition to liquid cooling. However, the widespread usage of Li-ion batteries in electric vehicles also presents a problem in end-of-life disposal and adverse effects on leaching of active materials into the water table. A life cycle assessment of Li material extraction and
2 S. Bashir et al.
usage indicates that every watt-hour (Wh) of storage capacity utilizes 328 Wh of energy and generates 110 g carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2-eq.) emissions. The other components in the cathode, such as Ni and Co, may also pose toxicological adverse effects if released prematurely into the environment. The trend in battery design and evolution appears to indicate size and cost reduction; increased power density; recycling and transition to Li-S, Li-Air, or organic polymers to meet the anticipated energy demands; lower CO2-eq emissions; and electric vehicle demand by 2030.
US policy alignment on energy, transport, and the environment is rarely aligned, except for the Obama Administration attempt at Advanced Clean Coal projects [1]. US policy via the Energy Policy Act has traditionally focused on energy generation utilities which use coal and natural gas (operators) and separately transmission utilities (independent system operator, ISO). The oil crisis of the mid-1970s focused attention on hydro-, thermal-, and petroleum-ethanol blends derived from corn, biodiesel, wind, photovoltaics, and batteries related to electric vehicles. The driving force for these policy initiatives is broad, relating to air and water quality, job creation, rural development, alternative fuels, and vehicle emission policy to promote American energy independence while adhering to cleaner air initiatives that reduce the carbon dioxide and greenhouse gas footprint to lower the global warming potential below the 2 C threshold. The policy framework enacted from 1970 to 2006 followed a similar pattern with partisan optics. The members from the Democratic Party initiated more environmentalregulatory policies, while the members of the Republican Party support fossil fuel, tax incentives for grid and operators, and general tax cuts to promote job creation. During a national emergency such as oil embargo and Gulf War, the policy instruments converge, and tax incentives are used to promote research development [2] with the State enacting more regulatory push, particularly from the 1990s. Therefore entities in energy or automakers have volunteerism through federal incentives and compulsion through state regulation. The policies enacted at the state and federal level involved different coalitions with different policies and decision-making priorities but can be broadly classified into four groups.
Innovation and transportation technologies are often misunderstood, and their impact is overstated, leading to cost overruns. This might account for the evolution of the nuclear, clean coal, and solar industries which held promise of a near unlimited energy supply at low cost with low risk, but the actual rollout was quite different since there was no common agreement on adaptation of a specific technology platform, technical ignorance of policymakers, and uncertainty on how quickly early technologies would be adopted by the market [3].
From the 1970s, sustainable policies were added to existing fossil fuel-orientated policy, rather than aligned from the ground up [4]. This interplay is observed with the policy implementation of net metering and solar PV, which many coal and gas utilities failed to challenge because they underestimate the negative impact these policies would have on their fossil fuel business model. Likewise, policymakers did not design these policies to meet a specific challenge, e.g., foster energy independence, but to promote an
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 3
umbrella of policies that would foster change without changing the current fossil fuelbased businesses. The corn-ethanol blend in petroleum likewise was rolled out as a minor component that was insufficient to meet the policy goals of self-sufficiency and was crafted to allay the fears of the petroleum industry that their profits would not be affected through the introduction of blended and alternative fuels [5]. Once it becomes apparent that some of the policies would lead to revenue loss, the dominant industries resorted to lobbying and lawsuits. The political and financial cost of these policies in terms of tax rebates and payments to the consumer also led to greater pushback from the legislature, in the form of revised legislation. For example, Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) ethanol from cellulose and biofuel ramp up and California’s Zero-Emission Vehicle (ZEV) mandate were scaled back because of increased costs in terms of tax rebates for implementation of the technology to market [6]. These policies, often rolled in as add-ons to mainstream bills or as omnibus bills, are a demonstration that a common federal energy policy has not existed that tied need/want to ability and long-term planning but enabled policymakers to pass legislation that was perceived as difficult or not passing in stand-alone bills. Examples include addition of the Federal Production Tax Credit (PTC) to the 1992 Energy Policy Act or the Investment Tax Credit (ITC) in the 2015 Consolidated Appropriations Act. The main focus of these bills was the use of federal lands for mineral and oil exploitation and the introduction of vehicle fuel economy standards, not electric vehicle (EV) tax exceptions.
In many of the omnibus bills, a cap or sunset provision was added to limit political blowback on “unflavored policies,” which enabled renewable energy policy to be advocated as a minor component within an omnibus energy bill that focused on fossil fuels, regulations, and standards rather than a comprehensive energy transition policy to meet the goals of energy independence. Thereby, introduction components placed favorable opportunities piecemeal through Congress rather than as one major component. For this reason, many sustainable policies once introduced underwent incremental increases in either delay of the expiration or increase of the initial state scope or goal. One example was the modest introduction of 50 MW of electricity from solar to be deployed back into the grid that was followed by new standards, ITCs, and growth in solar PV deployment [7] and investment (during the Obama Administration) from beginning at least two decades earlier. Currently, with the Trump Administration, it appears these subsidies may be removed or roll backed. The policy related to batteries in EVs similarly began with California’s ZeroEmission Vehicle (ZEV) mandate which included a sunset provision, which was extended through incremental bills, because of the greater lobbying power of these nascent industries at the initial introduction. Fossil fuel tax credits that have been maintained since the Wilson Administration (1916, known as “depletion allowance,” which lets oil producers deduct 27.5% of their gross revenues) have been equivalent to more than a $500 billion rebate, while in contrast the tax incentives to the sustainable sector have had more uncertainty because of the provision of sunset clauses [8]. The expansion of renewables such as wind and solar and associated tax incentives has escalated costs and drawn political ire from fiscal conservatives to
4 S. Bashir et al.
minimize subsidies. A policy to foster innovation and technological maturity with a pilot to scale up deployment and cost of rebate at specific milestones of deliverables has not been attempted with political and policy costs associated, whereby policymakers are more risk-averse if a particularly favored policy or project had previously failed to meet expectations [9].
An example of the above paradox is net metering, where the consumer receives the same rate for electricity as a provider. The utility companies have objected since the consumer does not have infrastructure or grid costs except the solar panel, whereas solar panel or energy providers support parity since the consumer is providing energy that can be used elsewhere [10]. The RPS mandates have also been criticized by utility operators, who perceive this standard as advocating a specific technology. The tax exemptions were extended when the industry was less than 1% of the entire petroleum industry. However when the biofuels blend became a more significant market force, drawing profits away from petroleum companies, lobbying against further tax exceptions greatly amplified. The policymakers sought to defray criticism from the petroleum industry by converting the gasohol tax exemption into a tax credit, the volumetric ethanol excise tax credit (VEETC) which expired in 2012. A similar trend can be seen with EV tax credits, which when EV sales were less than 200,000 nationally received little criticism from autoand policymakers, but now EV have sales in the lower 800,000 with project costs of two million by 2020, so many states have allowed the initial rebates to expire. The transition to a sustainable energy mix requires federal and state policy to consider wind, solar, thermal nuclear, and appropriate energy storage technologies in addition to infrastructure and reconstruction to the transmittance grid, cleaner coal-based fuels, examples of ethanol blend past 10%, and risk and environmental factors. Policymakers must take account of the possible failure of some technologies to meet the policy framework of independence from foreign oil, lower greenhouses gas emissions, and creation of American jobs with lower taxation for utility operators and energy providers including mineral and oil exploration and exploitation.
1.1 Possible Battery and Electric Vehicle Road Map from 1970 to 2050
If renewable portfolio standards (RPS)-type mandates are extended including investment tax credits (ITCs), the current market momentum will carry lithium-ion batteries to 70% in portable electronics and mobility by 2030 with the global market for Li-ion batteries doubling to tripling, depending on the market model. The batteries in transportation will range from bicycles, scooters, and mopeds to mini, full-size sedans as well as buses and stationary applications both on-grid and off-grid storage. Market saturation will not occur for some time, because of limitations of electrically propelled vehicle endurance. The miles-per-gallon equivalence (mpge) is still lower than internal combustion engine (ICE)-based vehicles. This would be reflected in the popularity of the
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 5
hybrid automobile, where the ICE powers the automobile at higher speeds and an electric motor coupled with capacitor/generator at lower city speeds. It is estimated by 2030, almost 70% of the automobiles will still be ICE-based.
To ramp up production, battery technology will need to change to greater performance/price and a nearly exponential increase in worldwide battery production to meet the anticipated demand. The trends in the road map (Fig. 1.1) demonstrate using past trends and current US policy over the next decade for battery improvements with respect to anode design, new materials for cathode, energy density, increased life cycle, and increased safety, with the lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC) chemistry being dominant by 2020 and siliconbased lithium-ion batteries by 2030, as well as Li-sulfur (Li-S), Li-air, and other Li-alkaline earth metal or organic polymer derivative nano-engineered (Li+eng) batteries in the mix, with the Li4Ti5O12 (LTO, 175 mAh/g), lead-acid (Pb Acid) being relevant for stationary applications. While nickel-cadmium (NiCd) and nickel-metal hydride (NiMH) have given away to Li-ion batteries in portable electronic applications, they will retain a minor share in low-energy electronics
6 S. Bashir et al.
and detectors. Material costs are another major hurdle to overcome before mass market flow can be accomplished since about 65% of the final cost is related to the active material (intercalation of lithium). By moving to phosphorous, silicon, and organic-based nanomaterials, these costs can be reduced by 30% per kWh. The $100/kWh should also be reached by 2025, for Si and NMC battery chemistries. It is also likely that ITC will no longer be offered, as the lower battery pack will lead to a lowering of the price of electric vehicles since at present the battery is the largest single unit cost within an electric vehicle.
The policy will revise alternative fuel and car emission standards if ZEV-type mandates are considered, giving rise to liquefied natural gas as a fuel for trucks, to 10%, 15% and 85% ethanol blends (E10, E15, and E85). It is likely that further legislation will be crafted to take account of electric vehicle (EV) emissions, not from the tail pipe but in the generation of electricity to charge these vehicles, as charging becomes more widespread. Other less mature technologies like fuel cell (FC) vehicles are charged using off-grid photovoltaics (PV) or on-board photovoltaics, such as solar transitions from fragile panels to flexible polymers, where the automobile paint or color scheme may have residual PV capacity to charge the car while it is idle or parked. Other hybrid combinations of fuel cells to electric vehicles (FC-EV) include the current internal combustion engine (ICE)-electric stack-based vehicles (ICE-EV). Fuel cells like EV cars require energy, the most ecological of which is hydrogen (H2); however, hydrogen needs to be generated and requires energy. If photovoltaics/solar is used to electrolyze water to hydrogen and oxygen, these gases can be recombined chemically to generate electricity; therefore the next generation of hybrids could be electric vehicle-fuel cells (EV-FC). If fuel cells become more widespread, refueling with hydrogen, like charging stations, will be required. These charging stations could use water to generate hydrogen and oxygen using grid electricity (such as natural gas, coal) or could use sustainable energy in the form of solar that is stored at the refueling station using batteries which are consumed during hydrogen production. Alternatively, solar power could be used for electrolysis of water into hydrogen and oxygen which are inputs for the fuel cell to generate electricity and water as outputs. This would be a form of onboard hydrogen storage and usage (onboard H2-FC). Much historic legislation has been passed to preserve the fossil fuel industry via incremental increases as various technological-driven technologies become more widespread. The ability to fabricate all-electric vehicles with the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) for the first time yields the possibility of selfdrive, self-park automobiles. Because of the scarcity of these models, there is no legislation to address the technical and legal (liability) issues, but as cars transition to digital, the cockpit will incorporate AI features to replace human error. It is likely laws will be crafted to address AI in transport, as well as battery safety and taxation, as the transport sector transitions to mostly ICE-based to mostly EV-FC-based. It is also plausible to tie increased abundance of EVs to
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 7
newer CO2 emissions that incorporated generation of energy materials. Instead of CO2 per tank, newer rules will be based on CO2 net weight of the vehicle which in turn takes account of the raw materials and fabrication CO2 “costs.” This, in turn, may lead to more streamlined vehicles that have less CO2 generated (based on extraction, milling, moldings, fabrication, and energy consumption to manufacture the component) instead of combustion of gasoline. Lastly, like safety standards in gasoline stations, equivalent standards in hydrogen refueling or battery swap station/recharging stations are also anticipated.

sections.heading: 1.2 The Electron Economy: Background on Importance of Societal Impact of Energy Storage
sections.text:
Societal needs change, and to understand the role of portable power, such as lithium-ion batteries, it is necessary to understand how and why we have arrived at this juncture.
In the United Kingdom, during the mid-eighteenth century, the mix of technology and innovation led to the first industrial revolution [11].), where for the first time, mass production and consolidation of expertise were housed in specific locations [12]. The cog that connects the import of raw materials, the housing of workers, and the actual operation of machinery and factories was steam and electricity, steam for transportation in addition to the use of inland waterways (canal) and electricity for lighting and operation of machinery [13]. The world population at this time (1780) was approximately 850 million, and today (2018) it is estimated at 7.8 billion with an estimated increase to 11.2 billion by 2100 (Roser and Ritchie 2018) as shown in Fig. 1.2. This rise will increase both economic growths and require additional energy [14]. The International Energy Outlook and other sources estimate the world primary energy demand in 1800 was 0.48 billion ton of oil equivalent (t.o.e), whereas today it is 13.9 billion (t.o.e) and anticipated to rise to 18.5 billion by 2040 under the new policy scenario (Roser and Ritchie 2018; [16]), summarized in Fig. 1.3 [17].
8 S. Bashir et al.
Burning carbon-based fuels to generate electricity or movement, including heat, generates carbon dioxide which contributes toward global temperature fluctuation as a greenhouse gas (GHG) [18]. World energy-related carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions rose from 33.9 billion metric tons in 2015 to 39.3 billion metric tons in 2040, an increase of 16% over that period [24]. This trend has mirrored the rise in primary energy demand from approximately 6647 million t.o.e (1983 = 100%) to a 39%
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 9
increase by 2000 or 100% in 2018, while the sum of non-carbon-emitting sources of energy remained constant during the same time period [21] as illustrated in Fig. 1.4. The continued sum rise (although the percent rate has slowed) has resulted in the more cumulative release of GHGs of which carbon dioxide is by volume the largest component [25]. This emission will increase from approximately 30 gigatons per year to 140 if no action is taken, modeled as business as usual (BAU), intended nationally determined contribution (INDC, [26]). The INDC is modeled with no continued improvement after the target data (strict) [27] or continued improved (continue) after the INDC target date 2025 (United States) or 2030 (most countries) are approaches to tackling GHG emissions [28]. It appears that while the carbon dioxide emission rate and overall CO2 levels will drop, they will not drop sufficiently to limit global temperature fluctuations by 2 C, which most models predict will adversely affect global weather patterns [29]. Therefore some countries have adopted a stricter plan above INDC in an attempt to lower CO2 emissions sufficient to meet the 2 C [30] as plotted in Fig. 1.5. These are as a result of combustion of liquid, solid, and gaseous fuels in a number of industries [35] and shown in Fig. 1.6 [41]. The tonnage emission of GHG has closely paralleled CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere (Dlugokencky and Tans 2017) and shown in Fig. 1.7. The percent of CO2 emissions attributed to energy generation (59%), transport (16%), and commercial and residual (9.8%) in 2010 of 34.42 million gigagrams of CO2 [45, 46] indicates that transition of the transportation and stationary power systems sector from a carbon-intensive regime to a low-carbon regime, such as battery power (electron economy), can decrease CO2 emissions, in addition, to extend natural resources, summarized in Fig. 1.8.

sections.heading: 1.3 Environmental Factors Affecting Transportation
sections.text:
While coal and natural gas dominate the source for generation of electricity in transportation, the dominant energy mix is petroleum-derived liquid fuels [49] requiring most industrialized countries to import, since consumption is greater than production. The percent share of oil has averaged 40% (1966–2013), although over the last decade (2006–2016), it has averaged 33% [21] because of improvements in materials (strength and weight) and reduction of friction in
automobiles [50]. With material substitution, streamlined design to generate less friction [51], automobile gasoline consumption is anticipated to drop by 10–20% [52, 53], and rechanneling breaking energy loss because of heat and friction can extend efficiencies and lower dependence on gasoline [54] in automobiles. Heat loss via the exhaust and mechanical losses represent over 70% of the measured losses, and newer developments in the internal combustion engine (ICE) can further extend efficiencies [55] in addition to improvements in recovery of waste heat to work thermoelectric subsystems [56].

sections.heading: 1.4 Electric Vehicles and Battery-Based Storage and Electrification
sections.text:
In an electric vehicle, the electric motor replaces the ICE for traction and a flywheel or battery as the energy source. The drivetrain consists of three subsystems, the electric motor (EM), energy pack (B), and auxiliary or secondary power unit (SPU). The motor subsystem is further comprised of a controller unit (CU), the power converter (PU), the electric motor, mechanical transmission (T), and wheels. The energy system contains the battery pack (or flywheel, supercapacitor or fuel cell), energy management unit (EMU), and refueling/recharging assembly. The auxiliary contains the power steering (PS), climate control (CC), and secondary power unit. The control unit channels inputs from the accelerator or braking subsystems to the electric converter to regulate power flow between energy pack and electric motor including reverse power flow because of regenerative braking. This procedure results in energy recovery and efficiency gains. This enables the vehicle to be configured into a number of different conformations with integration and simplification of the drive train. In one configuration the axles point at drive wheels that contain the traction motor, enabling each motor to operate inner wheels at one speed and outer wheels at a different speed when taking corners. Alternatively, the tractionmotor can be placed inside a wheel (IW), where a gear is used to reduce the motor speed and increase motor torque to provide a responsive reduction ratio [57]. Lastly, an inline configuration of the input and output shaft can also be employed to streamline the mechanical transmission where the out-rotor and in-wheel are connected, thereby eliminating the mechanical gear transmission assembly [58]; therefore the speed control of the motor directs the wheel speed [60] and summarized in Fig. 1.9 [59].
While electric vehicles have the potential to displace ICE-based vehicles in the long term, the performance of battery systems such as energy or power density, charging rate, cycle lifetime, and endurance is not to the same level as with ICEs. The employment of nanomaterials has enabled power profiles to be improved and appear to be within reach at 250 Wh/kg at a full time to charge 3 h are within reach [61]. The cost of a vehicle battery is $ 100 kWh by 2030 [62].
With the US Department of Energy recommendation of a driving range of 500 km, a specific energy of 250–350 Wh/kg would be required [63]. Therefore the selection of the battery is not a critical parameter but does have a bearing on performance and cost. Two parameters used to evaluate the type of battery are massenergy density (kWh/kg) and volumetric energy density (kWh/m3) with different batteries exhibiting different profiles.

sections.heading: 1.5 Technical Specification for Different Battery Technologies
sections.text:
The US Advanced Battery Consortium initial performance benchmarks for batteries are summarized in Table 1.1 [64] and Fig. 1.10 for the weight-volume energy density [65].
Not all battery technologies can meet all of the goals. The performance criteria of common battery platforms are summarized in Table 1.2 [71].
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 13
While lead-acid (Pb-A) batteries are not ideal, because of their low-energy weight and stored energy/volume ratio, they have had the longest development and are the most inexpensive options and are routinely found in electric golf carts, scooters, wheelchairs, and automotive batteries [74]. The battery supplies power to the starter and ignition system to start the engine. They also supply the extra power necessary when the vehicle’s electrical load exceeds the supply from the charging system. A car battery acts as a voltage stabilizer in the electrical system. The battery evens out voltage spikes and prevents them from damaging other components in the electrical system. In smaller powered engines, the battery powers the motor that drives an electric vehicle, such as a forklift truck or wheelchair. These batteries have no memory and can be configured either as
deep cycle mode for boats or campers, where they are used to power accessories like trolling motors, winches, or lights, or as standby to supply electrical power to critical systems in the event of a power outage or automotive or motive uses. However, they have a short life cycle and lower specific energy and power.
Nickel-cadmium (NiCd) have a low-energy weight ratio but have the highest life span (charge/discharge cycle of 1500); however like Pb, Cd is a heavy metal that is toxic to wildlife and mammals [75]. While they have high specific energy and power, they exhibit a memory effect. Over time, the charge/discharge efficiencies decrease, where

sections.heading: 1.6 The Extended Range Requires Some Type of Storage Capability
sections.text:
Lithium-ion batteries are common because of the advent of portable electronics. In 2008, two billion cells were produced [81]. Lithium-ion is an electrochemical reaction between lithium cations and cathodic active materials [82]. The cells contain a liquid electrolyte, with the electrodes being separated by a porous membrane composed of polyethylene or polypropylene to transmit the cations [83]. The cathode is not lithium metal but lithium metal oxides, while the anode is graphite and dimethyl carbonates containing dissolved lithium salts [84].
The charging and discharging cycles of the battery occur between the anode and cathode via the electrolyte. During charging of the ions from the cathode (Li metal oxide) to the anode (graphite), the discharge cycle occurs in the reverse direction [85]. The electrochemical performance, therefore, is dependent upon the identity of both the cathode and anode materials as well as the type of electrolyte employed in Fig. 1.11 [86].

sections.heading: 1.7 Lithium-Ion Battery Technology Current Development and Road Map
sections.text:
Lithium-ion batteries have high energy and specific densities of 300 Wh/I and 125 Wh/kg, respectively [88, 89], and fast charge/discharge cycles [90]. Adachi reported charging time constant of 200 ms at 90% charge which maintained over 3500 cycles (78% round trip, [91]). These parameters (summarized in Eqs. 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, 1.8, 1.9, 1.10, and 1.11) therefore have a good combination of characteristics in terms of response time and battery weight which are ideal for electric vehicles, where a short time scale application is required, because of Li battery high daily self-discharge 1–5% [92]. Lithium batteries are prone to overheating, maintaining safe voltage, have limited operational temperature range, and because of self-discharging are not a suitable backup option [93]. The schematic of a Li-ion battery is shown in Fig. 1.12.
There are four metal oxides of lithium that are traditionally used instead of lithium metal. They are lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA, LiNiCoAlO2, 250 Wh/ kg), lithium cobalt oxide (LCO, LiCoO2, 200 Wh/kg), lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC, LiNiCoMnO2, 200 Wh/kg), lithium manganese oxide (LMO, LiMn2O4, 140 Wh/kg), lithium iron phosphate (LFP, LiFePO4, 120 Wh/kg), and lithium titanate (LTO, Li4Ti5O12, 80 Wh/kg). These batteries have superior specific energy to traditional batteries such as lead-acid (PbA, PbO2|Pb 40 Wh/kg), nickelcadmium (NiCd, NiO(OH), 60 Wh/kg), and even nickel-metal hydride (Ni(OH)2, 85 Wh/kg) [89] (Table 1.4).
