A major safety concern is overheating [97]. In sensor technology, NMC and NCA cells are utilized because of lower material intensity but with good specific energy. In hybrid electric vehicles, a conventional internal combustion engine with an electric propulsion system is used to drive the vehicle. Here the power recovery from deceleration is stored in the battery for future use during acceleration. The electric system, therefore, is more auxiliary and as a result has a power of 2–3 kWh, insufficient for overnight charging. These types of vehicles do not have a plug-in port for recharging. Cars with 8 kWh or larger batteries require a separate plug-in port to charge the battery. This power is sufficient for an all-electric drive of 30 km, with the load being born by the ICE. In an EV, the ICE is replaced by an electric motor and requires energies of 18 kWh for a drive of 120 km [98]. The EV market is dominated by the NMC (higher lifetime)- and NCA (higher specific energy)-type Li batteries, because of their high specific energy or life cycle. The plug-in vehicle prefers the NMC type, while the EV prefer the NCA. The average ICE car can drive up to 310 miles on a 12-gallon tank, which takes 5 min to refill. The PbA batteries typically have a 3–8-year warranty, usually prorated after the third year. In comparison, the plug-in batteries have a warranty of 100 k miles or 3 years and EV 500–800 cycles or 8 years. However, the plug-in cannot currently drive 310 miles on a full charge or be recharged within 5 min. The current lifetime warranty is less than the possible endurance of these batteries since a 310 mile/ cycle at 800 full cycles would travel 248 k miles, well as the warranty period. It, therefore, appears that specific energies around 80 kWh and weight are pressing
20 S. Bashir et al.
technical concerns to make automobile performance (drive and refilling) to be on par with gasoline-powered cars [99]. Other related sectors include electric motorcycles, and bicycles, and forklifts that use a mix of LFP-LMO battery chemistries.
The engine power to specific energy (E) capacity of the electric vehicles also needs to be taken into account. The current ratio is between 3 and 5 for EVand 5 and 10 for plug-ins. It is unlikely this ratio may get larger with increases in specific energy and more efficient electric motors, summarized in Table 1.5 [100].
For this reason, global car sales reached a milestone in 2015 (one million units sold) and are the fastest-growing area in the automotive market today (Fig. 1.13) [102]. Bloomberg New Energy Finance predicts that by 2038 the major type of car sold would be the electric vehicle as opposed to the ICE and by 2040 just under 60 million units will be sold, although there will still be over 1.2 billion ICE cars still in operation BNEF [105].

sections.heading: 1.9 Stationary Power Supply Systems
sections.text:
The uninterrupted power supply needs to be load-level both for constant power delivery and for frequency and voltage. The electricity demand is not constant but varies by time of day or seasonal or special event such as sports, music, and political events, where audience members at home use electricity for drinks and food during break time of the program or event. In addition, severe weather can affect heating or cooling in offices and households. These variations affect how electricity is generated (coal, nuclear, wind, solar, or gas), and restrictions are placed by grid regulators to ensure no utility operator is near their maximum capacity [106]. Therefore for a steady output, the grid utilizes energy
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 21
storage units to offset against peak demand via pumped hydro storage. Over the last decade, there has been a slow shift toward more renewable energy mixes such as photovoltaics and wind [107], resulting in decentralization where end-users can input energy into the grid as well as draw energy out [108]. This, in turn, has drawn attention to improved energy efficiency at all levels to lower the total electricity usage and lower carbon dioxide emissions [109]. Electrochemical storage, therefore, can play a critical role in the infrastructure of low carbon buildings [110], where Li-ion batteries have advantages over other electrochemical storage strategies. One disadvantage is the Li battery bank storage is more expensive at approximately $350/kWh with a lifetime of 2000 cycles. A cost of less than $175/kWh with a lifetime above 3000 cycles will place storage costs in the c$5/kWh range and make them competitive toward centralized and distributed power storage units [111]. Here the units could be used to maximize local usage of electricity from distributed renewable power generation units such as windmills that are local to each community of 20 houses [112]. The battery chemistry most favored under these circumstances is related to LFP, vanadium redox, and PbA batteries [113]. A side effect of the millions of units of EVs is the possibility of these vehicles serving as backup distributed units (vehicle-to-grid) in emergencies (hurricanes) where constant power is critical (hospital, care homes, office blocks, police, fire, emergency services) or even as a backup source for home residents who can sell the power during peak hours and recharge at off-peak hours [114].
Lithium-ion batteries can also be employed as electrochemical storage for an off-grid power supply such as with renewables, which is dominated by PbA batteries. Under a renewable-powered home (RPH), the battery can be placed inside the house if it is powered using photovoltaics or a windmill that is close by Jaiswal [115]. The battery packs could power the basic heating/cooling/lighting
function of an RPH by 2030 [108]. This has distinct advantages of gasoline or kerosene generators or heating sources since the prices of these fuels fluctuate more than the price of light-emitting diodes (for lighting) or LFP for storage [116]. This is attractive to societies with poor infrastructure since a national grid system would not be necessary. Each community could have their battery bank supplied by a windmill or solar panels centrally located (light harvesting farm) or on each building [117].

sections.heading: 1.10 Li Battery Usage Trend
sections.text:
The storage capacity of Li batteries worldwide, either actual or anticipated, is in the lower GWh/y and is doubling every 5 years. In part, this is a consolidation of older portable storage devices, in partial replacement of NiMH and NiCd and in part new demand [118]. The trend is illustrated in Table 1.6.
The Li-ion battery demand for portable electronics is growing at an average annual rate of 10%. The Li-ion battery demand for portable electronics is likely to reach 45 GWh in 2020 and 100 GWh in 2030. The Li-ion battery demand for transport may reach 65 GWh in 2020 mainly attributable to EV because of their higher demand relative to hybrid vehicles. For storage, the demand is coupled with market penetration of wind and solar and is also expected to increase. With increased demand, the likely cost will decrease to $118 $/kWh. One of the largest sub-costs for a Li battery is because of the materials for the cathode (25%), the anode, separator and electrolyte (8% each), and other components (16%) with cell assembly contributing another 35% of the cost. The cell within the battery is approximately 2/3 of the total cost. Most auto manufacturers buy the cell but assemble their own battery packs, the cost of which is rolled into the vehicle, for example, a $3700 Tesla (10 kWh NCA) battery pack, the cell of which is purchased at $470/kWh [118]. As the EV and laptop batteries include, the cost reductions toward a 5 kWh pack at <$1000 are practical in price/performance and market saturation perspectives. As the magnitude of Li batteries increases, not all Li battery chemistries will be increased. The long-term stability of LFP and specific energies of NCA types will increase at the expense of LMO. NiMH and NiCD are expected to decrease significantly, although PbA because of their proven record in stationary and motive applications will remain a strong contender for usage. With Tesla’s proposed Gigafactory and the cheaper material costs of LFP batteries, the two dominant platforms are expected to be LFP and
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 23
LMO for a market share up to 2030. As the number of Li-ion batteries increases, so does the population of batteries that have reached the end of life (power< 80%) and recycling becomes significant or repacking as batteries for storage [120].

sections.heading: 1.11 Life Cycle Assessment for Batteries
sections.text:
The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has set a number of industrywide standards that can be utilized in developing a life cycle assessment (LCA) model to understand both energy and material costs. The relevant standards pertain to ISO 14040 (Principles and Framework), ISO 14041 (Goal and Scope definition), ISO 14042 (Inventory analysis), and ISO 14043 (Impact analysis) and summarized in Fig. 1.14.
The LCA has been applied to investigate the gaseous emissions relationship in hybrid vehicles related to battery size [121]. The fuel mix to generate electricity for charging was also investigated in terms of creating a carbon neutral environment [122]. A study on the lifetime driving of an EV (93 k miles) demonstrated that global warming potential could further decrease from 10% to 24% with the substitution of ICE by EV resulting in lowered gasoline consumption [123]. The availability of EVs has led to companies generating more electricity from sustainable resources, and the fewer components resulted in fewer materials in the product chain [124]. When hybrid cars are compared using LCA, the global warming potential was 27% [125]. A simulated model incorporating design elements from LCA based on Pareto set points and a proprietary algorithm demonstrated that NiMH offered optimal fuel economy and Li-ion batteries the lowest operating cost and greatest global warming potential reduction relative to PbA [126]. The impact on the environment in terms of the
24 S. Bashir et al.
generation of gaseous pollutants and volatile organic compounds was compared between NiMH and LCO cells, and it was concluded the highest environmental impact was with NiMHs.

sections.heading: 1.12 Effects of Recycling on Costs and Adaptation in Electric Vehicles: Material Limitations and Potential Toxicity in Disposal at End of Life
sections.text:
Recycling is cost-effective since it minimizes the more energy-intensive extraction of raw materials process. Typically for batteries, the metals are recovered via smelting and refining. From this process transition metals such as cobalt, nickel, and manganese are recovered and can be reutilized in the car. Lithium and rare earth elements reside in the slag and are used as a building material in roadbeds and pavements. An alternative approach to recover rare earth is by leaching, which will become more paramount as the number of Li-ion cells that are at the end of life becomes significant, which is anticipated in the next decade [127].
LCA has also been applied to public and urban transport platforms such as buses, in which battery type, weight, specific energy, and traffic conditions are factors that affect the environment [128].
The LCA model has general ramifications that can apply to all industries, where decarbonization targets the reduction of global warming potential requiring rare earth and transition metals such as dysprosium, neodymium, cobalt, tin, nickel, and manganese. In addition to Li-ion batteries, metal oxides or salts of lithium are required [129]. These resources are not available uniformly and are concerned in a few regions. This requires manufacturers to strike long-term price agreements and researchers to transition to more available materials, in addition to ramping up recycling efforts [130] (Table 1.7).
Lithium is mined from ores of petalite (LiAl(Si2O5)2, lepidolite K(Li, Al)3(Al, Si, Rb)4O10(F, OH)2, spodumene LiAl(SiO3)2, and also subsurface brines. Chile and Australia are the world’s largest producers of lithium with their combined production being greater than 75% of the world’s production [135]. In brine, it is in the form of lithium chloride, which, when treated with soda ash (sodium carbonate, Na2CO3), precipitates into lithium carbonate [136]. Almost 80% of extracted lithium is from brine. In 2015, 65,108 tons of lithium carbonate were extracted [137] with 39% being used in the batteries sector, 30% in ceramics and glass, 8% in lubricating greases, 5% in polymer production, 5% in casting mold flux powders, and 13% others. The consumption for lithium in the battery sector has increased from 20,026 tons in 2008 to 77,821 tons in 2016, an almost quadrupling over 8 years [138]. The estimated battery storage capacity between 2020 and 2030 is approximately 2.5 TWh. This capacity translates to approximately 400,000 of lithium carbonate at 0.16 kg/kWh or almost 3% of the global reserve. If recycling, factored in other metals such as cobalt, can be recovered [120], it is now part of the framework incorporating LCA [139]. The average life cycle of Li-ion batteries in portable electronics is 5 years; for automotive applications, it is 12 years; and in power supply and storage, it is 10 years. The lithium recovery percentage is dependent on
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 25
the type of battery and system and varies from 80% for electronics to 95% for automotive/power systems. At present approximately 60%, ~30%, and <10% of recycled lithium are reused in the newer system, meaning on average, 40% of lithium is recycled into new components. Unfortunately, there is no systematic or uniform back distribution system, where end-users can return the spent batteries [140] and most batteries end up in disposal sites or landfills in the United States at end of life [141].
Lithium usually does not bioaccumulate in humans and its environmental toxicity is low [142]. Lithium is not an essential element for plants although it does stimulate plant growth [143]. Lithium has been used to treat bipolar disorder even though excessive doses can be fatal. For example, 10 mg/L in serum is the recommended treatment regime; however, patients that have taken more exhibit the signs of elemental poisoning (10 mg/L of blood). At higher (15 mg/L) doses, patients exhibit confusion and slurred speech that becomes fatal at 20 mg/L [144]. A provisional recommended daily intake of 14.3 μg/kg body weight lithium for an adult has been suggested [145]. To put these figures in context, 1 g/L alcohol will give the average individual symptoms of slurred speech, and 3–4 g/L (9 μg/kg) is considered fatal [146]. Lithium will undergo price volatility over the next decade as the newer longterm contracts are renewed or older mines close down. In glass manufacturing, other Alkali metal such as potassium and sodium can replace lithium in glass and ceramics, and calcium and aluminum can be used in lubricating greases [147], at present assuming $140/kWh, with lithium material intensity at 0.15 kg/kWh and $13,900 per metric ton (2017). This price is almost double the price from 2016. The
26 S. Bashir et al.
percent of lithium in a battery pack and price influence is <1.5%; therefore price fluctuation in the raw materials is unlikely to affect electronics or automakers.
Cobalt is mined in Canada and Morocco but also is recovered as a by-product of copper or nickel production from mines in Democratic Republic of the Congo, Russian Federation, Australia, and Cuba in the form of minerals cobaltite and smaltite (cobalt arsenide). Other cobalt-bearing minerals include erythrite, glaucodot, and linnaeite (cobalt sulfide) [148]. The Congo supply approximately 54% of the global demand (64,000 metric tons). Cobalt is used as a cathode material in Li-ion batteries and also in alloys and cemented carbides [149], in addition to being an essential nutritional element. Approximately 30% of the globally extracted cobalt is utilized by the Li battery sector [148]. Unlike Li, the share of Co to the final cell price is significant. Assuming $140/kWh, with lithium material intensity at 1.4 kg/kWh $81,000/ton (from $30,000 in 2017), the cost share of cobalt in the cell is 81%. For NMC and NCA cells, that share would be <10%. In these cases, price fluctuations could affect battery-pack prices in EVs. This critical need can be addressed by recycling and using cobalt-free cathodes with similar specific energies. Recycling could salvage up to 50% of the cobalt [150], and implementation of cobalt-free chemistries in LFP type, stationary storage, and alternates to cobalt in alloys and structures could also extend its usage [151].
Other less likely shortages are because of nickel and graphite, although these are not as critical as with cobalt [152]. Approximately 1.2 million tons of graphite is mined annually of which 3% is directed to the Li-ion battery sector [148]. The concern is that 65% of the mines are in China. The current mining of nickel is 2.25 million tons over the Philippines (22%), Russian Federation (11%), and Canada (11%) [148] and its use for metal alloys and in NMC, NCA, NiMH, and NiCd batteries, of which 3% is devoted to the battery sector. Li-ion batteries are classified as hazardous because of their lead (6.29> 5 mg/L), cobalt (0.16 kg> 0.008), copper (0.0987 > 0.0025 kg/kg), and nickel (0.0095 > 0.002) content. The disposal of batteries in landfills often led to leaching of chromium, lead, and thallium leading to eco and human toxicity particularly for Co, Cu, Ni, Th, and Ag [153].

sections.heading: 1.13 The Next Evolution of Li Battery Development Technology
sections.text:
The design of batteries has remained constant over the last 100 years with two electrodes, a conducting electrolyte and separator. The electrons move accordingly to the electrochemical potential difference between the electrodes, as a function of their unique chemistries via an external circuit from the more negative to the more positive potential. Ions are transported through the electrolyte/separator to maintain charge balance, and electrical energy is used. In rechargeable batteries, a reverse applied voltage pushes the electrons in the opposite direction. The magnitude of the electrical energy per mass is related to the cells voltage and capacity which in turn is related to cell chemistry.
The chemical to electrical potential can be enhanced by engineering a larger chemical potential difference between the electrodes, decreasing the volume of the
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 27
reactants per exchanged electron, and maintaining the electrolyte (e.g., for NiMH and Li-ion batteries).
In the lithium-ion battery, Li+ participates at both electrodes, being either inserted or extracted from the appropriate electrode. Lithium is attractive because of its high specific capacity (3860 mAh/g) and low redox potential (~ 3.0 V SHE). Here Li+ is exchanged between the anode consisting of graphite (LixC6) and transition metal oxides as a cathode (Li1 xTMO2). The transition metal oxides are cobalt, nickel, or manganese. This system can store up to 180 Wh/kg with an output of 3.8 V, much greater than lead-acid (PbA) batteries. While electric vehicles (EV) do not produce carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions at the tailpipe, the manufacturer of an EV and/or power source is not carbon-free. Approximately 70 kg COs/kWh is produced [154]. The breakpoint where EV become carbon neutral related to the power cell is approximately 120 charges (with 35% efficiency from the production of electricity from coal and 20% for an ICE), not in itself sufficient to lower the global warming potential by 2 , a suggested target. The next generation of batteries (Fig. 1.15) will need to increase specific energy and lower the carbon footprint.
The initial increase of electrode surface area leads to increased reactions with electrolyte resulting in electrolyte decomposition. However, when the active cathode material is intercalated between graphites, the secondary oxidation or reduction reactions were greatly reduced [155]. By carefully placing the TMO between layers of carbon, the kinetics are optimized, because of lower diffusion path for ions and electrons. Through careful adjustment of the packing plane or lattice, metal insertion or conversion can be achieved [156]. In metal insertion the local covalency and density of states of a semiconductor such as titania (TiO2) are altered through the careful addition of metal or metal oxide, enabling the band gap to be lowered or increased [157]. In conversion, the TMO is converted to metal (xM0) nanowire-type morphology embedded within the MO (e.g., Li2O2, Fig. 1.16). If the conversion “islands” are not controlled, there will be a large voltage difference between the charge and discharge modes, resulting in poor energy efficiency.
Similarly, nanodesign has been applied to solid electrolytes such as Al2O3 or TiO2 dispersed in polymers for fabrication of polyether-based electrolytes to increase conductivity at higher temperatures (80 C). Another approach to increasing conductivity is through local ordering using co-block polymeric fibers [159]. Since the hydrophobic and phase separation can be better controlled, this is one approach to optimize the specific energy of the battery. Ionic liquids that have low vapor pressures, which are nonflammable and have high conductivities, will enable batteries without thermal runaway to be fabricated and can potentially assist with overheating, although cost and low-temperature performance have not been demonstrated on par with current technologies.
Since lithium and cobalt are the limiting factors in terms of scale-up and resource allocations, the transition to cobalt-free and recycling of bio-batteries are potential solutions to scarce resources.
The most precise control at the biological level is deoxyribonuclease and protein synthesis that is templated and enzymatically driven to generate precise and wellordered systems. The enzyme-mediated synthesis of LiFePO4 cathodes would solve
28 S. Bashir et al.
many problems related to ordering and scarce resources [160] where virus or bacterium has been used to engineer Co3O4- and MnO2-based electrodes, respectively.
Many systems also employ iron-sulfur or iron storage in the form of apoferritin (protein without iron) and ferritin (with iron) [161]. Mimetic polymers could serve as
templates to chelate iron adsorbed on the surface of a conversion electrode to control the deposition/dissolution of TMxOy and Li2O crystals. Other approaches include the use of chemically active conjugative molecules like polyaniline [162] or redox polymers [163, 164] and sugars that can chelate lithium [C6H12O6]n + 2nLi
+ 2nē -> C6H10O5Li2 + 2 H
+ [165]. Since carbohydrates and polyketones are structurally related, they could be used for the design of biocompatible electrodes [166].

sections.heading: 1.14 Lithium and Lithium-Oxygen Battery Current Performance and Degradation Issues
sections.text:
Air electrodes and metal air are currently used in fuel cells but have the potential to be adopted for Li-ion batteries, where 2Li is oxidized to Li2O2 which can, in theory, have a specific energy of 372 mAh/g with the highest being around 350 mAh/g [167]. Because of the large activation energy, in fuel cells, platinum is used to overcome this barrier and facilitate catalysis. Porous 3D electrodes can separate gas (N2, CO2) or water away from either Li or Li2O2 to increase the energy efficiency, and ionic liquids that are hydrophobic will reduce water entry and contamination of the electrode surface, although at present hydrophobic ionic liquids and hygroscopic lithium salts have low compatibility and solubility.
Lithium as an anode has been deposited unevenly forming dendritic structures that lead to low efficiencies and overheating, because of passivation of the outer layer of lithium metal [168]. The application of dry polymer electrolytes has reduced but not eliminated passivation of lithium. This is for two reasons: (1) high fermi energy resulting in thermodynamic instability promoting reactions with electrolyte and passivation and (2) generation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layers, in addition to consumption of electrolyte resulting in increased internal resistance and lowered cycle life. The high volumetric aspect ratio of Li metal at the anode during periodic plating and stripping processes causes dendritic to be formed and lower efficiency.

sections.heading: 1.15 Suppression of Degradation via Electrolytes
sections.text:
Strategies to reduce dendrite growth are via optimization of the electrolytes. If co-additives that promote uniform morphology are added, dendrite formation can be minimized. One example is the use of cesium hexafluorophosphate (CsPF6) in propylene carbonate (PC), resulting in the formation of a smooth Li film with well-ordered nanorods on the copper substrate. The copper surface is passivated by lithium fluoride (LiF) in situ from the reduction of PF6
and the shielding effect of Cs+ [169]. Other approaches include the growth of Li nanorods in 1 M LiPF6/PC electrolyte and trace (50 ppm) water [170]. The hydrolysis of LiPF6 generated HF which was electrochemically reduced to LiF prior to deposition of Li, from the LiF-rich solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the Cu substratum without an increase in Li Coulombic efficiency. With 2% LiAsF6 and 2%, vinylene carbonate (VC) or fluoroethylene carbonate were added to 1 M LiPF6/PC electrolyte, smooth Li deposition with highly ordered Li nanorods were obtained, and Coulombic efficiency was increased to 96.5% [171] with the electrochemical reduction of LiAsF6 to LiF and LixAs. Here, LiF passivated the substrate, and LixAs was seed species for the growth of Li. The electrolyte VC or fluoroethylene carbonate was polymerized that bound the inorganic compounds and adhered to the Li metal surface, protecting the Li metal anode and cycle stability of the cell [172]. A similar approach used 4 M lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LfSI) in 1,2-dimethoxyethane [173]. The reactions between Li metal and electrolyte were decreased because of the larger particle size, which increased Coulombic efficiency to 99% and the inhibition of dendrite formation in propylene carbonate electrolyte using 4.9 mol/kg of LiFSI ionic liquids [174]. Lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide has also been used with a variety of solvents such as acetonitrile [175], 1,2-dimethoxyethane [173], dimethyl sulfoxide, and lithium nitrate (LiNO3) instead of LiFSI [176]. Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (7 M, LiTFSI) in 1,3-dioxolane and 1,2-dimethoxyethane [178] and LiTFSI in 1,2-dimethoxyethane [177] have all been used to suppress Li dendrite formation in Li-ion and Li-air batteries [174]. In all the above studies, highly concentrated electrolytes were used that promoted saltsolvent coordination, with fewer solvents available for Li metal to react with and the formation of an ionic-liquid interface [179], causing further degradation of the dendritic formation. The lower conductivities of these ionic liquids are offset by their high thermal stability, low volatility, high carrier density, and high reduction/ oxidation efficiency [180].
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 31
Li deposition in the form of nanowires can also promote cycling and retard dendritic formation and stability at the anode. The use of dual-salt electrolytes of LiTFSI and lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB)in ethylene carbonate and ethyl methyl carbonate (E/MC) generates uniform fibrous growth, which protects the metal Li anode. This arrangement leads to long cycling stability and fast charging with high-energy cathode materials (LiNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2/ethyl carbonate, NMC-type battery [181]. The addition of 0.05MLiPF6 to the LiTFSI-LiBOB/E/MC generates compacted wire-like Li deposits with conductive solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films on the Li metal surface. In addition, the remaining LiPF6 initiated polymerization of the EC molecules to form polycarbonates on the Li metal surface and also to protect the cathode substrate aluminum from corrosion by TFSI anions. Likewise, the Li metal anode is similarly protected by the inorganic/polymeric nanocomposite SEI layers during periodic Li deposition/stripping cycles, and the uniform Li wires promote high charging capability because of the lower charge-transfer resistance of the SEI films, lowering their chargetransfer resistance [182]. If the polymeric/electrolyte at the SEI layer is conductive, flexible, and compact, protection against dendrite formation and enhanced Coulombic efficiency can occur; however, if the morphology of the wire/fiber/polymeric nanocomposite is highly porous, insulating, or rigid, then protection does not occur, resulting in lower Coulombic efficiency and shorter cycle lifetimes (cf. Figs. 1.16 and 1.17).

sections.heading: 1.16 Suppression of Degradation via Membranes
sections.text:
Liquid electrolytes flow and interact with the porous electrolyte resulting in side reactions that degrade Coulombic efficiency [183]. Solid-state electrolytes do not have this limitation; however, their low conductivities at room temperatures (< 10 4 Scm 1) require high temperatures (80 C) as stated earlier in the chapter
[184]. The self-assembled polyanionic BAB triblock copolymers (see Fig. 1.16) finely tune mechanical properties, ionic conductivity, and lithium transport number at the same time. A triblock (ABA)-type polyelectrolyte based on poly(styrene trifluoromethanesulphonylimide of lithium) P(STFSILi) associated with a central A block based on a linear poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and terminating with the B-block was evaluated and demonstrated high ionic conductivity (1.3 10 5 S cm 1 at 60 C), carrier transport number (> 0.85), and electrochemical stability u to 5 V (relative to Li/Li) [185]. The mechanical strength at these temperatures was reduced, slowing but not eliminating dendrite formation.
Inorganic solid-state electrolytes contain a heteroatom such as sulfur and have been shown to be conducted at room temperature. Other electrolytes based on oxygen, SiO4, have slightly lower conductivities (10
3 Scm 1 for LiSICON and 10 4 Scm 1 for garnet solid-state electrolytes, respectively) [186]. All of these electrolytes are sensitive to moisture or air (sulfur) or are not stable against Li metal (oxygen) and require special insert fabrication environments [187]. While garnet-type solid-state electrolytes are stable with Li metal, the grain boundaries of the garnet promote Li dendrite formation, lowering the cycle life of the cell [188], in addition to the general higher interfacial resistance of solid-state electrolytes relative to the liquid carbonate-based electrolytes [189].
The interfacial resistance between the solid-state electrolyte based on garnet and Li metal anode can be reduced by fabrication of three-dimensional ion-conductive networks deposited by atomic layer deposits. Examples of such as an approach include deposition of Li7La2.75Ca0.25Zr1.75Nb0.25O12 (LLCZNO) electrolyte on Al2O3 [190] or Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) on Ge [191] or Li6.4La3Zr2Al0.2O12 (LLZAO, [192] ). These composites increase the Li conductivity of the solid-state electrolyte and decrease interfacial resistance. The sandwich of LLCNO-Al2O3 has no void space and excellent contact with Li, whereas LLCNO alone has pores and voids with poor interfacial interaction. Thin layers of LLCNO-Al2O3 improve the wettability of the garnet surface, similar to LiZr5(PO4)3 that was electrochemically stable to 5.5 V with low interfacial resistance to Li-ion transfer [193]. Even after 100 h testing, the electrolyte retained its solid dense morphology without any dendrite formation, suggesting that co-addition of LiZr2(PO4)3 solid electrolyte can inhibit Li dendrite formation. Thus, unlike a liquid electrolyte, the solid type can act as a membrane to block dendrite formation and to stabilize the anode (Fig. 1.17).
The Li metal anode can also be stabilized using SEI membranes; examples include use of an elastomer/lithium phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON) SEI membrane by using the mechanical protective properties of the elastomer layer and the chemical protective of the LiPON layer, allowing the anode to be stable up to 100 plating/ stripping cycles at 2 mAcm 2 [195].
Atomic layered deposition, used to coat Al2O3 at the anode, was able to protect the Li surface from corrosion from electrolytes, sulfides, and air, improving cycling stability of lithium-sulfur cells. Through surface structural engineering, a functional space was provided for Li to grow in the forms of columns rather than dendrites on the Cu foil. The arrangement of interconnected hollow carbon
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 33
shells was able to provide an avenue for the growth of Li-ion flux instead of deposition of Li in the form of treelike dendrites [196]. This two-dimensional arrangement was extended in three dimensions with the fabrication of carbon granules and enable over 95% of Li utilization (as Li-ion instead of Li metal dendrites) [197]. Other approaches include mechanical and chemical treatment of separators, where one face is coated with a conductive material facing the anode. The Li-ion flux toward the conductive face forms a dense dendrite layer without extending toward the cathode. A non-conductive 3D member was recently reported, where Al2O3 membranes infused with liquid electrolytes of LiTFSI/1,3-dioxolane/1,2dimethoxyethane [198] or LiTFSI/1-methyl-3-propylpiperidinium/SiO2/propylene carbonate. The propensity of dendrite formation was inhibited by using pore size in size-exclusion modality, limiting the size of potential dendrites which could be formed. Other strategies using the conceptualized approach described use porous polyimide 3D separator [199] or polymer nanofiber separators [200].

sections.heading: 1.17 Suppression of Degradation via Structural Redesign of the Anode
sections.text:
Most anodes have a tubular or flat 2D morphology which during cell cycling (charging/discharging) undergoes physical change because of Li stripping or deposition and often results in dendrite formation because of uneven Li-ion distribution on the electrode. To alleviate low Coulombic efficiency, the current collectors have been constructed from copper [201], nickel [202], graphene [203], or carbon fibers [204] to minimize morphological changes in the anode structure over prolonged use of the cell. One approach relied on the use of skeletal templating where the current collector was made from a reduction of CuOH2 fiber arrays [205]. The dendrite tips have a large charge density and act as the focus of Li deposition within the electric field. By creating an overlaid Skelton, the ends of the fibers act as nucleation sites for growth because of lower and uniform charge, leading to less sharp contours of deposited Li and higher Li cycling stability. Other potential designs are a fabrication of vertical column geometry, such as nanowires, to decrease Li-ion “hot spots” and to generate a more uniform ion distribution throughout the structure. Since there are fewer charge centers, there are fewer dendrites, relative to a 2D planar electrode as a current collector [206]. Graphene and graphene oxide (GO) have also been evaluated because of their intrinsic properties [207–209], where, often, Li metal is layered between the reduced GOs, generating a Li-rGO-Li-rGO multilayer composite. This arrangement lowers potential volume change at the anode [210]. Alternatively, modified Li anode on stainless steel and titanium formed a “sawtooth”-type arrangement, with Li nucleation being directed by the nano-notches at the expense of dendritic growth [211]. The processes discussed above are summarized in Fig. 1.18 and Table 1.8.
34 S. Bashir et al.

sections.heading: 1.18 Environmental Impact Policy RoadMap in Lowering Global Warming Potential
sections.text:
The environmental impact of the disposal of used batteries is a component within the LCA framework. To this analysis, the CO2 equivalence (eq) must be calculated. This is the energy required to extract, separate, purify, and fabricate the battery cell and is
Key: C3H6OCO2Li2 = lithium hydroxy({[hydroxy(oxido)methoxy]methoxy})methanolate, CE = Coulombic efficiency, CsPF6 = cesium hexafluorophosphate, DEC = diethyl carbonate, DME= dimethoxy ethane, DOL= 1,3-dioxolane, EC= ethylene carbonate, FEC= fluoroethylene carbonate, H2O = water Li2CO3 = lithium carbonate, Li2NSO2CF3 = (trifluoromethoxysulfinyl) azanide lithium, Li2S = lithium sulfide, Li2S = dilithium sulfide, Li2S2 = (lithiodisulfanyl)lithium, Li2S2O3 = lithium thiosulfate, Li2S6 = dilithiohexasulfane, LiCF3 = (trifluoromethyl)lithium, LiF= lithium fluoride, LiN3= lithium nitride, LiPF6= lithium hexafluorophosphate, LiTFSI= lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide, mAcm 2 = milliampere per centimeter squared, NSO2CF3 = [Dilithio(sulfamoyl)methyl]lithium, PC = propylene carbonate, ppm = parts per million, ROCO2Li = lithium(hydroxy) methanebis(olate) if terminating with H; (ROCO2Li = HOCO2Li); if R, use group name, for example, if R = CH3; then the name is lithium (methoxy)methanebis(olate) (ROCO2Li = H3COCO2Li), SEI film = solid electrolyte membrane
36 S. Bashir et al.
approximately 170 kg CO2-eq per kWh of battery capacity [218]. Since batteries are electrochemical cells, they discharge and charge in cycles, and the depth of discharge is 85%, with a battery life of 1500 cycles; the approximate travel of an electric vehicle would be 6 km/kWh which is equivalent to 2.2 kg CO2-eq per 100 km traveled. By increasing the Coulombic efficiency through better anode design, the increase in battery life to 2000 cycles and reduction of CO2-eq from 2.2 kg to 1 kg CO2-eq per 100 km traveled, the total carbon emissions can be reduced to 100 kg CO2-eq per kWh of battery capacity. This corresponds to approximately burning 11.24 gallons of ethanol-free gasoline or 9.8 gallons of diesel [219] or 2.38 kg of CO2 from burning 1 kg of coal (assuming that 65% by mass is carbon). Other important factors that impact the environment are the use of copper, lithium, and aluminum. While lithium is not toxic, the extraction from seawater by evaporation, ion-exchange cleanup, purification, and carbonation is a high-energy process and will generate more carbon dioxide than is eliminated by savings in gasoline consumption/combustion [220].
A study compared two equivalent auto models (VW Gold and eGolf) and determined the former would utilize 8 l of gasoline to travel 100 km, generating approximately 9 kg of CO2 through direct combustion, while the latter would utilize 16 kWh of energy, and CO2-eq was 9 kg CO2-eq, while in less industrial advanced countries, the output was between 0.9 kfCO2/kWh (India) and 0.05 kgCO2/kWh (Paraguay) [221]. To reduce global warming potential, replacement of ICEVs by EVs alone is not sufficient. An integrated approach is required by moving toward sustainable energy sources including nuclear power and carbon capture technologies or decarbonization of generation of power. Over the last 5 years, the fastest-growing sector in energy has been sustainable energies related to wind and solar. There has been a decline in coal and a slight increase in the use of natural gas for the generation of electricity. In the United States, natural gas is the single largest energy carrier used in the generation of electricity, which can also tap into waste in cogeneration systems to heat the plant itself [222].

sections.heading: 1.19 Addressing Role of Batteries in Addressing Intermittency: Off-Grid Storage and On-Grid Vehicle-to-Grid Applications
sections.text:
Intermittency of wind and solar is addressed through energy storage with a variety of battery platforms including Li batteries to provide a localized off-grid energy solution [223]. In addition, some communities have adopted a distributed grid system with local wind or solar power within the homes or nearby, depending on generating capacity [224]. The locally generated power is stored and consumed without using the general or national grid. An expansion of this concept would require secondary storage including the use of existing capacity in the form of vehicle-to-grid (V2G) to facilitate the electrification of the road and home (e.g., solar home systems) network [225]. The role of recycling is often overlooked but is critical in reclaiming the Li, Al, Cu, Ni, and Co and reducing the carbon dioxide emitted during the manufacturing processes [226].
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 37
The role of energy in the United States was governed by the SecondWorldWar [227] followed by the “Space Age” using a mix of regulatory incentives, tax credits, quotas, and caps from foreign competition and privatization of some federal agencies to facilitate innovation [228]. While the utility operators were few, the market price was relatively constant and encouraged private capital investment, overcapacity, and spikes in pricing. The “oil crisis” refocused federal policy on nonpetroleum energy sources such as hydro, nuclear, wind, and battery [229]; however concerns about nuclear plant safety and escalating costs led to less investment and less expansion of nuclear as an energy mix, because of limit profits from such enterprises [230]. During the Reagan Administration, the policy favored privatization and deregulation and restructuring of the electricity marketplace to increase competition and lower consumer pricing. During the last two decades, the utility operators have focused on transmission, rather than a generation to control market prices. This is reflected in the corporate structure of the various utilities with the bulk (prior to the Reagan) administration being private investorowned utilities which supplied over 80% of the electricity. This decreased to 40% after restructuring, which split energy into generation and transmission [231]. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) regulates interstate natural gas pipelines, wholesale electricity markets, regional transmission authorities, and independent systems operators (ISOs). These changes have a defocused investment on energy generation, adding resilience to the transmission grid and updating aging equipment, in addition to regulating emissions of greenhouses gases, which are regulated by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) [232]. The regulatory framework historically (except for nuclear and biofuels) has been state-level mandates for renewables such as state renewable portfolio standards (RPS), state net energy metering (NEM), and California’s Zero-Emission Vehicle (ZEV). The Federal level has focused on rebates and tax concessions such as the Federal Production Tax Credit (PTC), investment tax credit (ITC), and federal tax incentives (FTIs) [233]. The expiration of the business energy tax credits and implementation of the 1992 Energy Policy Act attempted to stabilize the cost of electricity by renewables through a tax credit of 1.5 ¢/kWh for the first 10 years of production fromwind [234]; until the Energy Policy Act of 2005 phased out tax credits, the policy was successful in promoting the development of wind power while also meeting state-mandated RPS requirements [235]. The RPS mandates require a fixed percentage of the state ’s energy mix be derived from sustainable energy resources, not prescriptive in nature of which technology, and have allowed 37 states [236] to meet the requirement from wind power (68%).

sections.heading: 1.20 US Energy Policy (1960–2016) Toward Sustainable Energy Platforms: Photovoltaics and Biofuels
sections.text:
Photovoltaics-based net metering policies have been adopted in 43 states, which guide the level of compensation of distributed power supplied to the grid, first deployed in California [237]. The 2005 Energy Policy Act introduced a 30% ITC for commercial and residential (ceiling of $2000) systems, with residential credits capped at $2000, [238] and are expected to expire in 2021, unless renewed.
38 S. Bashir et al.
Biofuels have had two periods of support, excise tax incentives from the late 1970s to the mid-2000s (1978–2011) and as blending mandates (2005–today), to counter high oil prices and assist the rural farming communities from transition from feed crops to energy crops, as well as address environmental concerns [239]. The 1978 National Energy Act promulgated a 4 ¢/gallon excise tax exemption for “gasohol” (i.e., gasoline with 10% alcohol/v.) which was extended to 1992 by the 1980 Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax Act, and the 1980 Gasohol Competition Act place a 54 ¢/gallon ethanol import tariff to dissuade foreign imports. The 1992 and 1998 Energy Policy Acts extended the tax credits to other blends up through 2007. The increased use of ethanol fuels after 1998, when methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE), a fuel which oxygenates gasoline, was found leaking into groundwater and was a potential source of cancer [240] led to protests. In response, many states banned the use of MTBE as a fuel additive, leading refineries to use blended ethanol as a substitute [241]. The increase in ethanol usage and associated tax exemption leads to the 2004 Volumetric Ethanol Excise Tax Credit (VEETC) which replace a tax exemption with a tax credit to fuel blenders of 51 ¢/gallon of ethanol, which was reduced to 45 ¢/gallon in 2008 and allowed to expire by 2012. This increase in part was fostered by the RFS mandate which required fuel providers to blend a minimum quantity of biofuels into the US petroleum supply each year [242]. The mandate required 2% fuel oxygen content, primarily as a means to lower ozone and smog production because of incomplete fuel combustion. In addition, it promoted US fuel security and rural agro-farming jobs [243]. The oxygenates were utilized to stabilize fuels after lead [244] was phased out during the 1970s [245] because of the toxicity of lead in children and adults [246].
The impact of the initial renewable fuel standard (RFS) mandate was to add four billion gallons of biofuels to the petroleum grid by 2006, raising it by 7.5 million by 2012. The Gulf War during the Bush (W.) Administration led to higher gasoline prices, which in turn fostered a more ambitious expansion of the RFS standard. The revision mandate increased the blending targets to 36 billion gallons by 2022, nearly 1/5 of anticipated motor fuel consumption [247]. The bill conflagrated two distinct policies, the first to increase market uptake and stabilize the marketplace and fuel prices favored by the Republican Party, in addition to promoting energy independence, another Republican Party-favored policy. The House and Senate members of the Democratic Party favored expansion of ethanol biofuels to cellulosic biofuels and submandates for life cycle greenhouse gas reductions. The democratic favored policy toward greener energy and jobs within the framework of the pro-ethanol alliance [248]. Higher startup costs associated with cellulose have slowed cellulosic ethanol, and these submandates have been revised downward. In the current iteration of the RFS mandate, the fuel blend of 10% ethanol (E10) has already been met and poses no technical issues to automobiles or trucks; however additional blends of 1% (E15) and 85% (E85) require hardware changes to automobiles and trucks. While new models (2013 and beyond) can tolerate E15, older models cannot since ethanol at the higher blends is corrosive to rubber gaskets, absorbs more
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 39
water that dissociates into two layers in the gas tank, and clogs up fuel lines. Only flex-fuel vehicles can tolerate E85 blends; therefore further blending would require additional changes to the ICEs.

sections.heading: 1.21 US Energy Policy (1960–2016) Toward Sustainable Energy Platforms: Hybrids, Batteries, and Electric Vehicles
sections.text:
The push for cleaner air centered on a number of initiatives at the state level, principally in California, because of the propensity of smog in the major metropolitan cities. The Zero-Emission Vehicle (ZEV) mandate was designed to meet the Federal Clean Air Act (CAA) ozone standards, a component of smog [249]. The potential to lose Federal funding because of non-compliance with CAA regulations focused on policy in California to examine the role of car emissions. The state legislature set up the California Air Resources Board and tasked it to assess air quality and regulations to reduce vehicle emissions [250]. The board developed a Low Emission Vehicle (LEV) and Clean Fuels Program which included near-zero and Zero-Emission Vehicle standards and mandate [251]. The LEV standard has been periodically revised and currently requires 15% of vehicles sold in California to meet the ZEV standard by 2025, which includes flex fuels and hybrid vehicles. Because of the associated high startup costs, the lawmakers were also able to push for federal tax incentives [252].
The tax policy also coincided with the Bush (W.) Administration goal of reducing oil imports and the 1992 Energy Policy Act of opening up federal lands for oil exploration and the introduction of regulations to make automakers design and build more fuelefficient automobiles. The bill introduced Production Tax Credit (PTC), extended previous biofuel tax credits including income tax credit for purchasing new EVand an additional income tax deduction for purchasing a clean-fuel vehicle (Clean-Fuel Vehicle Tax Dedication (CFVTD), flex fuel liquid natural gas, E85, EV, Fuel cell) that tapered down from 2002 to 2004 after which the rebates/incentives would expire [253]. The rebate drawdown was revised in further legislation, and in the 2005 Energy Policy Acts, the CFVTD was replaced by the Alternative Motor Vehicle Tax Credit (AMVTC) to promote hybrid vehicle uptake, which gave US automakers tax credits for the first 60,000 hybrids sold. This benefited US makers because of their introduction of hybrids later in the market. By this time, most of the Japanese car makers had sold more than 60,000 models (during the time period when the AMVTC did not exist [254] while allowing the EV tax incentives to expire. The 2005 Energy Policy Act allowed the EV tax credits to expire but was revived via the 2008 Emergency Economic Stabilization Act capped at 250,000 vehicles nationwide. The 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (“stimulus package”) expanded this to 200,000 vehicles per automaker through 2014, which was extended by the 2014 American Taxpayer Relief Act [255] and subsequently rolled back as EV sales rose and the cost of the tax incentive increased.

sections.heading: 1.22 Perspectives, Conclusion, and Policy Implications: Li-Ion Battery Pitfalls, Challenges, and Development Road Map
sections.text:
The rollout of Li-ion batteries as the primary platform for high-end electronics, cell phones, and most electric vehicles has indirectly displaced coal as the primary resource for the generation of electricity in the United States. However, Li-ion batteries are not carbon neutral, as the extraction of the metal and metal oxides requires energy that is not offset by usage in electric vehicles, although the emissions are lower than corresponding gasoline internal combustion engine-based vehicles. Li-ion batteries have the potential to become an energy sustainable resource but would need to increase change density through redesign of the anode/current collector, electrolyte, and membrane. The dependence on cobalt will need to be reduced to meet future global demand, and this effort should be integrated with integrated recycling, and more importantly, the carbon footprint should be decreased.
The electrification of the home and road transport has to be integrated with demands for power generation, and transmittance from sustainable resources instead of fossil fuels, because the lower electric vehicle (EV) emissions from vehicles are not sufficient to reduce the global warming potential below 2 C. This requires a switch to nuclear, hydro, thermal, and sustainable resources with secondary battery storage to offset intermittency issues and load leveling. The fabrication of Li-ion batteries is an energy-intensive process, and this contributes toward greenhouse emissions. Recycling the components would promote more efficient usage and lessen the burden on mining or extraction of Li from seawater, which appear to be the driving force in current pricing and availability. A longer-term potential bottleneck is the availability and price of cobalt, a key component in cathode fabrication, and use of lithium cobalt oxide (LCO)-based cells in portable electronics. Research in cobalt-free electrodes, with high-energy densities, is required, particularly in lithium iron phosphate (LFP) and lithium manganese oxide (LMO) cells. As EVs past one million units sold worldwide (projected 1.9 million by 2018 contrasted with 81 million internal combustion engines (ICEs) globally) newer global standards are required to minimize, waste, greenhouses gases (GHGs,) recycling and battery lifecycle and cost reductions.
With two million units to be sold by 2019, the vehicle-to-grid, secondary life battery storage to extend their utility will become significant because of market penetration and wider availability. These capabilities will ensure that batteries are used to their maximum usage before battery depth of discharge (DoD) (defined as the percentage of the battery that has been discharged relative to the overall capacity of the battery) has been reached before recycling or disposal. Off-grid storage such as that used in solar home systems can provide local infrastructure, a road map for electrification of communities in rural and underdeveloped regions of the world.
The energy density of Li-ion batteries could be accomplished through Li anode redesign, where low Coulombic efficiency (CE) is attributed to the formation of dendrites, as well as overheating and potential chemical fire generation. Some of these
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 41
disadvantages may be eliminated or reduced through the incorporation of solid-state electrolytes, although the Li metal at anode and anode interface optimization has not been solved. The redox flow battery platform offers potential benefits in high-energy secondary storage scenarios; however, there remain series of technical hurdles before flow batteries become mainstream. This is because of the limited redox potential of species in non-aqueous electrolytes of materials for cathodes and anodes that can generate a stable couple. Newer materials that can push the redox potential of the anode to lower values to maximize the cell voltage are required. Hybrid flow batteries with lithium metal anodes suffer from cycling instability where the lithium metal deteriorates by dendritic formation during the deposition phase, in addition to secondary reactions with the electrolyte leading to low Coulombic efficiency during repeated charging and discharging. If the short-term liquid electrolyte will continue to be used, strategies will need to be employed to reduce Li dendrite growth through restriction of changes to the volume. Current approaches focus on the metal host to limit Li volume changes during deposition. These hosts as 2D or 3D matrices limit dendrite growth resulting in CE degradation and promote nucleation of the Li thorough the matrix because of the porous nature of the template. The anode/electrolyte also needs to form a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film or a passivated protected layer to promote high CE of the Li metal anode. Generally, this is accomplished through the incorporation of high conductivity oxides or nitrides such as LiF, Li3N, and Li3PO3 compounds.
The cell performance is also related to the uniformity of the electric field on the electrode surface, which in turn is related to morphology changes during deposition/ stripping. Incorporation of a porous buffer layer-based transmission channel can promote uniform stripping and plating, where electrostatic shielding because of the presence of cations can facilitate homogeneous Li deposition. Anode metals with lower potential and high-energy capacity are required to replace Li metal. Newer designs focus on electron transfer between active metals at the electrode and current collectors, via a redox shuttle. The shuttle, in turn, is charged/discharged in a secondary storage tank that is filled with the active material, using LiCoO2 and LiVPO4F as cathode, and lower potential materials, like Li4Ti5O12 as the anode. To lower the overpotential loss, the potentials of the redox molecules need to be better matched.
The key challenges for efficient and long-term Li battery design should focus on better characterization of the nanomaterials used in the fabrications of the electrodes, using electron microscopy, templating the reaction between anode and electrolyte such that contact is minimized and CE is set at 99% or greater; electrodes should be designed to yield high charge current densities (>1 mA cm 2) and area utilization (4 mAh cm 2), with thermodynamic modeling of lithium intercalation with (N/S/O) heteroatoms than Li||Al or Li||Cu cells. Another redesign should factor in use of non-Li anodes to limit dendrite formation; limit Li metal volume change upon cycling (<10% volume change) particularly at the Li/Separator face and by using low electrical conductivity 2D/3D structured templates to direct Li deposition on the scaffold. In addition, Li deposition on anode current collector should be better controlled using 1/2/3 D optimized geometry current collectors. Simplifying Li metal stabilization process and overall battery box design for more efficient recycling and second life usage, as well as leach-free disposal, would lower costs and reduce the carbon and environmental burden.
42 S. Bashir et al.
Many of these design limitations require fabrication of specific topologies that rely on the application of nanomaterials to limit dendrite growth but promote Li nucleation and limit gross morphological changes during charging/discharging cycle which will be extended to newer platforms such as Li-sulfur and Li-air technologies. While the focus of the current book chapter is on Li-ion batteries, storage technologies also include lead-acid, zinc bromide, sodium sulfur, sodium-nickel chloride, polysulfide bromine, vanadium redox, and nickel cadmium which offer solid cycling capacity and intermediate power densities and high round-trip efficiencies.

sections.heading: 1.23 Perspectives, Conclusion, and Policy Implications: Energy Storage and Recycling
sections.text: A storage policy should include a mix of battery technologies and wind or photovoltaics (PV) for energy generation. The cost of energy generation using life cycle assessment (LCA) should also include the loss of power probability, intermittency, and environmental impact. As the loss of power probability decreases, the cost of energy and cells in the storage stack increases, requiring some optimization between cost and reliability. As the population of EVs localized sustained energy in the form of wind and solar increases, the environmental impact of lead, cadmium, cobalt, and aluminum should be considered as part of an LCA. Wind/PV systems for battery DoD values ranging from 50% to 80% (stationary power) and 80% to 100% (EVs) would require battery cell replacement at more frequent intervals than the project life replacement of 25 years; therefore increasing battery energy density and lifetime is critical to lower carbon emission and potential toxicity because of end of life. Some of the newer battery technologies address these pitfalls, but currently, no battery platform has the desired lifetime, energy, and cost matrix.

sections.heading: 1.24 Perspectives, Conclusion, and Policy Implications: Historic
sections.text:
Framework (1970–2006)
The absence of an effective policy regarding battery deployment and recycling is disappointing but not unexpected as these technologies have not reached critical mass but are anticipated before 2025, which would necessitate lawmakers to implement policies similar to the ZEV policy from the State of California in the mid-1990s. The federal government across numerous several administrations (Carter to Bush (W.)) has not adopted a policy that has an integrated environment and energy. In many instances, federal policies have been formulated because of external stress (oil embargo, Gulf War, recession), to decrease dependence on oil import, and protect American jobs in key sectors through tax cuts, rebates, and incentives. The Obama Administration for the first time attempted to align energy and environmental policy through the Clean Coal Act, which limited electricity generation from coal, and promoted natural gas and sustainable resources through a combination of
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 43
regulative fixes and monetary concessions to end-users, as well as utility operators. Many energy policies were renewed, such as Energy Policy Acts or, extended beyond the initial mandate (e.g., biofuels), or passed as part of large omnibus energy bills. Many policies were incrementally revised upwards or downwards with cost estimates being short of actual targets. Some energy policy was highly partisan and polarizing on renewable energy [256]. US policymaking has not adopted a planned long-term policy but rather a series of policies that have been revised depending on the current stress and political considerations. Sustained advocacy coalitions in many instances had led the states to enact specific mandates related to sustainable energy transitions to avoid policy retrenchment particularly to tax incentives to Li-ion batteries in the EV sector.

sections.heading: 1.25 Perspectives, Conclusion, and Policy Implications: Obama Administration Energy Policy (2009–2011) – A Snapshot
sections.text:
Under the Obama Administration to highlight how policies can change during the lifetime of an administration (first term, 2009–2013, House/Senate majorities D + 79/D + 14), the Democratic Party had a supermajority in the Senate for approximately 7 months. From 2009 to 2011, over 50 energy-related policies to clean coal and renewables were started. The general framework of these policies overall was related to clean coal, bioenergy, energy storage, geothermal energy, offshore wind energy, and smart grid:
Federal cost-sharing for projects at the demonstration stage was rigorously maintained, without consideration of risks for specific projects.
The federally funded clean energy project was highly partisan or gained polarized opinion across the political spectrum, partly fueled by limited data sharing from the project to potential end-users and stakeholders.
In some cases, industrial or public pressure accelerated scale-up of demonstration projects before they were mature and ready for deployment, such as carbon capture, utilization, and storage for power generation and lastly risk aversion.
Policymakers wanted experimental technology to behave akin to mature technologies with zero risks. Under the Obama Administration’s first term, projects managed by the Department of Energy that did not meet the benchmarks were canceled. This may be because of the passing of the Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E) component within the Stimulus Bill [257] or congressional imposed fiscal austerity by the Congress who controlled both Houses of the Congress (Republican Majority, House/Senate R + 49/D + 4) and potential hostility to a president from the Democratic Party. The lessons from the Obama Administration’s first term, which from the first midterms until the end of his presidency was controlled by members of the Republican Party, had been that the federal government can effectively shepherd newer technologies past the innovation and testing phase.
44 S. Bashir et al.
1.26 Perspectives, Conclusion, and Policy Implications: Trump Administration (2016–2018) and the Plausible Future (2019–2021)
Before an analysis of the Trump Administration is given, it should be noted that the present administration is only 1.5 years old and the 2018 midterms are still 6 months [258]:
Prioritized economic growth is stimulated through tax cuts and deregulation. It appears that many of the strategies favored under the Obama Administration related to Clean Power Plan (CPP) and its Clean Energy Incentive Program including carbon capture and storage (CCS) are abandoned [259].
Natural gas will continue to be a significant component of US energy portfolio given the magnitudes of natural gas reserves, low natural gas prices, and cleaner combustion relative to coal [16]. It appears that fracking for natural gas, directives to utilize more coal for electricity, and further deregulation [260] of environmental regulations specifically arising from CPP/CCS [261] will continue [262]. Policies towards oil independence will continue through the implementation of the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines, enabling greater access to and streamlined exploration permits to be issued for federal lands [263]. In addition the markets are being regulated through incentives and tariffs, specifically promoting US steel for pipeline construction tapered with 10–25% tariffs on aluminum and steel [264] for foreign imports which may retard growth and stagnate domestic demand for transportation fuels from US oil refiners, although this may also increase export opportunities to export liquefied natural gas (LNG) to India, China, South America, and Asia [265]. The trade imbalance and potential lifting of international tariffs on US goods may free access to export light crude, LNG, and import inexpensive feedstocks benefiting refiners and petrochemical companies and potentially utility operators that can sell electricity to Canada and Mexico and import fuel supplies using current and proposed pipelines. If US partners (North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA consisting of the United States, Mexico, and Canada), European Union (EU)) do not enact trade-free legislation and trade disputes escalate over NAFTA/ EU/China, this may negatively impact import of raw materials and export of refined oils and selectivity and is an uncertainty for the energy sectors [266]. If no agreement can be sought and trade tariffs as proposed are implemented, then import and export costs would increase and are not offset by the recent tax bills for US oil, steel, coal, and utility companies [267].
The other environmental and energy policies from the Obama Administration that are likely to be rolled back are exceptions for inadvertently killing birds (operators can inadvertently kill 4200 bald eagles a year without penalty), wind and solar power subsidies, and potential rolling back federal ethanol mandates passed under the Bush (W.) Administration. It is also likely that the Trump Administration will facilitate Yucca Mountain storage facility for spent nuclear fuel to begin operations and potential deregulation and tax concessions for operators to design and build small molten salt reactors powered by thorium. An increase in a hydropower-based generation (reversing policy from the Obama
1 Technology Policy and Road Map of Battery 45
Administration) and the construction of natural gas export terminals allow American energy companies to export natural gas (a policy that was also blocked under the Obama Administration). It is uncertain how effective this policy will be if countries in the EU/China and NAFTA impose an “energy tax” in response to the current and future tariffs proposed by the Trump Administration [268].
While the present administration is less than 2 years old, a number of general policy frameworks can be discerned. These are:
Focus on policy reversal instead of correction, conservative coalition using fossil fuel industry executives to align environmental policy within the context of energy, and independence of energy policy Comprehensive reform and expansion of coal and natural gas development, including upstream expansion and downshift deregulation to promote American jobs coupled with import (caps?) and tariffs on select industries Potential promotion of nuclear power to expand civilian sector nuclear capacity and capability in line with increasing American jobs and a general withdrawal or rollback from multilateral agreements which affect jobs, particularly in the fossil fuel, manufacturing, and infrastructure arena [269]
The post-2018 domestic energy policy is unclear because of the approaching midterm elections. In the case of the Obama Administration, after the Democratic Party lost control of the House in 2011 and Senate (2015), the energy policy was altered from 2011 onwards to take account of the bifurcated nature of governance. Policies that were perceived as partisan or polarizing could not pass both houses (under Republican majority) to be signed by law by the President (from the Democratic Party). The Trump Administration spanned the 114th (House/ 1320 Senate) R + 57/R + 9 and session of the 115th Congress (R + 42/R + 2), and although currently enjoys a Grand Old Party (GOP) majority in both houses as well as the presidency, the majority in the 116th Congress may not materialize. Like the Obama Administration, a recalibration between energy independence and policies that promote the environment including tax incentives for sustainable energy platforms may be reintroduced including a rollback of favorable coal legislation to reflect the political realities on the ground for the new Congress. Assuming there are no new political realities and the GOP retain small majorities the policies that are likely to be enacted based on current presidential executive orders or memorandum or selection of cabinet secretaries from (conservative states with pro-fossil fuel credentials) are likely to continue.
