sections.heading: 2.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Electrochemical energy storage and conversion have become the unquestionable challenges and critical technologies in the world, in response to the decreasing availability of fossil fuels and environmental pollution. The energy storage and conversion systems that can electrochemically produce energy have been seriously considered as the alternative power sources, as long as these systems are designed economically and environmentally friendly [1]. These systems include batteries, electrochemical capacitors (supercapacitors), and fuel cells, some of which have been widely used in electronic products, electric vehicles, and the smart grid. Although the mechanisms of these three kinds of devices for energy storage and conversion are different, they still share some common features in electrochemistry. Their electrochemical reactions take place at the interface between the electrolyte and electrode where electron and ion transport are separated to storage/release the energy through the charge/discharge process. There are many different kinds of battery technologies on the market or under development, ranging from primary batteries to rechargeable batteries and solar cells. Supercapacitors include electrochemical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors, distinguished by the processing mechanism whether non-Faradaic or Faradaic. Fuel cells have many categories in terms of the properties of electrolytes. Figure 2.1 displays the operation mechanism of three selected kinds of devices, namely rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, pseudocapacitors, and solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC), and all of them consist of some basic components: cathode, anode, and electrolyte with two electrodes contacting with the electrolyte solution.
Both batteries and fuel cells store and release charges through the redox reaction of the electrode materials and stored fuels, respectively that own chemical energy. These chemical reactions are associated with Faradaic charge transfer between an electrolyte and electrode surface, and attendant phase changes. The discharge process is usually taken as the nominal defining process for an energy storage and conversion device, so the term, negative electrode is anode where the oxidation reaction at this side usually take place at lower electrode potentials than the cathode side (positive electrode). This definition of electrode directions is only suitable for the pseudocapacitors which process the energy via Faradaic reaction but meaningless for the EDLC systems which use physical adsorption/desorption of the ions at the electrolyte/electrode interface, termed as electrical double layer.
62 W. Song and J. Chen
In lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), the redox reactions of electrodes are accompanied by the Faradaic charge-transfer between the electrolyte and electrode surface, moving lithium ions in a rocking-chair way to realize the discharge/charge process. The electrode reactions of LIBs are highly dependent on the electrode potentials; thus, the cyclic voltammograms usually display typical oxidation and reduction current peaks, and the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles show voltage plateaus. As a result of the kinetic barriers for electron transfer such as Ohmic resistance, and ionic transport difficulty, the redox reactions of electrodes take place at potentials substantially different in discharge and charge process, with anodic peak more positive than cathodic peak. The electrode reactions are irreversible around the thermodynamic reversible potential; thus, the anodic and cathodic overpotential is required to drive the respective reactions at specific net rates. Accordingly, the cycle life of rechargeable batteries is usually limited and the relatively slow chemical reactions require a long time for charge/discharge.
In EDLC, the electrostatic storage arises by separating charges in a Helmholtz double layer at the interface between the surface of a conductor electrode and an electrolyte solution. In the double layer structure, one electronic layer is located in the surface lattice of the electrode and the other layer, outer Helmholtz plane (OHP), is distributed in the electrolyte with opposite polarity from the dissolved and solvated ions. These two layers are separated by a thin layer of specifically adsorbed ions losing their solvent shell, termed as the inner Helmholtz plane (IHP). The solvent molecules in IHP are physically adsorbed on the electrode surface and act as the molecular dielectric. The intrinsic process of a physical electrostatic adsorption/desorption enables EDLC to have ultrahigh power capability and fast charge/discharge rate.
In pseudocapacitors, the electrical energy is stored by Faradaic charge-transfer reaction of de-solvated and specifically adsorbed ions, achieved through the redox reactions, electrosorption, or intercalation on the electrode surface. This process is inevitably accompanied by a non-Faradaic contribution from static EDLC. In Faradaic reaction of a pseudocapacitive electrode, the electrons are transferred to or from the valence orbitals of the redox reagent clusters near the electrode surface at a distance, l (2Dt)½, where D is the diffusion coefficient (cm2 s 2) for chargecompensating ions and t is the time (s). The Faradaic reaction in pseudocapacitors is a fast reversible process and there is no formation or breaking of chemical bonds, and usually coupled with compensating reactions with protons, Li+ or Na+ ions [2].
In fuel cells, the chemical energy of a fuel is converted into electricity through an electrochemical reaction between hydrogen fuel and an oxidizing agent, oxygen, and the continuous supply of fuel and oxygen is required to sustain the chemical reaction. For fuel cells, the energy storage means the storage of fuels is in the tank while the energy conversion is in the cell; thus, the local separation in energy storage and conversion of fuel cells is distinguished with other electrochemical systems. The cathode and anode are just charge-transfer media in fuel cells usually assembled with a specific catalyst to promote hydrogen oxidation and oxygen reduction reactions, respectively. Fuel cells are classified by the type of electrolytes, and SOFC, as schematically represented in the figure, uses solid oxide or ceramic electrolyte to allow oxygen ion transport.
64 W. Song and J. Chen
Batteries, especially the lithium-ion batteries, have been dominating the market of power sources in comparison with supercapacitors and fuel cells. However, the current performance of batteries is still insufficient to meet the increasing demand in many applications, such as the electric vehicles. In comparison with combustion engines and gas/steam turbines, the electrochemical energy storage and conversion systems still need unremitting development to improve the output capabilities in energy and power densities and lower the cost. To evaluate the energy contents of a system, the terms specific energy, which is expressed in watt-hours per kilogram (Wh kg 1), and energy density, which is expressed in watt-hours per liter (Wh L 1), are used. The rate capability is indicated by specific power in W kg 1 and power density in W L 1. In another style of expression, gravimetric and volumetric are used. The as-known Ragone plot which diagrams the energy and power capabilities of the specific energy system is developed in Fig. 2.2. Batteries owning intermediate energy and power characteristics are located in the gap between high-energy fuel cells and high-power supercapacitors. Some new-type electrochemical devices that combine electrodes of different reaction mechanisms and advantageous properties have been developed to improve the whole performance in both energy and power densities. These devices include asymmetric-electrode supercapacitors which consist of EDLC-type and pseudocapacitive materials as the actives of two electrodes and hybrid-electrode supercapacitors which have battery-type and capacitive electrodes. The combination of different types of electrodes in an electrochemical device aims to remarkably improve at least one of the energy or power capability without much sacrifice of another.
The properties of these electrochemical devices in energy storage and conversion are highly dependent on the electrode materials confined by both thermodynamics and kinetics. Nanostructured materials have attracted tremendous interest because of
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 65
their unique mechanical, optical, and electrical properties and the benefits from the synergy of bulk and interfacial properties for efficient and effective energy conversion and storage [3]. Nanostructured materials are playing increasingly important roles in electrochemical energy storage, and especially the booming development of nanotechnologies have afforded emerging but effective tools in designing advanced energy materials [4]. It is a sizeable topic to understand the advantages and disadvantages of the nanomaterials used for energy storage and conversion, as well as the synthesis protocols and the control of the properties [3]. Although there are many novel concepts in fabricating devices and materials, it is beyond the scope of this chapter to present an exhaustive summary of different kinds of electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices and the assembled nanomaterials. Here, we focus on the typical materials and their synthesis strategies in the development of high-performance lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors. The basic electrochemistry fundamentals associated with the materials are also reviewed to understand the mechanism of electron and ion conduction in the materials.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Thermodynamics
sections.text:
The electrochemical reactions in electrochemical energy storage and conversion devices obey the thermodynamic and kinetic formulations. For chemical reactions in electrochemistry, thermodynamics suits the reversible electrochemical reactions and is capable of calculating theoretical cell potentials and electrolytic potentials. An equilibrium in the thermodynamics of an electrochemical cell means the reversibility in both chemical reaction and thermodynamic energy, leading to the reversible reaction in mass and energy. The reversibility in the chemical reaction of an electrochemical cell requires the electrode reaction in charging is the exact reverse reaction in discharging. The reversibility in thermodynamic energy implies that the energy in charging equals to the value in discharging, and both the systems and surroundings return to their original states when the cells work close to the equilibrium conditions where an infinitesimal current is applied. sections.heading: 2.2.2 Kinetics
sections.text:
Electrode kinetics mainly studies the net rate of electrochemical reaction and follows the same general considerations for chemical reactions. However, there is still some difference in the interface reactions. In electrochemical reactions, the potential drop in the double layer along the interface of electrode/electrolyte directly affects the activated species and the interface reaction is in a two-dimensional manner. The potential drop takes place when the current is drawn to the battery in comparison with the open-circuit voltage (Eocv), resulting from the electrode polarization (V). The difference between the irreversible electrode potential and equilibrium potential (Eocv) is termed as overpotential (η) and three types of kinetic limitations lead to the polarization (V).
Ohmic polarization is related to the resistance of the cell components and contact problems between these components (Ω).
Concentration polarization, due to the mass transport limitation in the cell operation, causing the ionic concentration near the electrode is different from the bulk.
Activation polarization, also termed as electrochemical polarization, is associated with the electrochemical redox or charge-transfer reaction at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces where the kinetics affects the charge state of the electrode.

sections.heading: 2.3 Nanostructured Materials in Lithium-Ion Batteries
sections.text: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are based on single electron intercalation chemistry [4] and have achieved great success in energy storage used for electronics, smart grid. and electrical vehicles (EVs). LIBs have comparably high voltage and energy density, but their poor power capability resulting from the sluggish ionic diffusion [6] still impedes their wide application in EVs. The performance of LIBs in energy storage has been improved greatly since the first commercialized one in 1991 by Sony, benefiting mainly from the development of advanced electrode materials. The cathode materials have been pointed out to leave less room to further improve the energy density depending on the already existed materials, but the anode part is still promising to achieve higher energy and power densities [7]. This session provides a brief summary on the nanostructured materials for use as the electrode actives in LIBs.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Cathode Materials
sections.text:
The basic requirement for a cathode material in LIBs is high free energy of Li+ ions and low free energy of electrons in comparison with the anode materials, then the difference in the chemical potentials of both sides establishes a working voltage [8]. The well-known cathode materials mainly process two mechanisms to host the Li+ ions, namely intercalation and conversion. Basically, the research in cathodic host materials started from the 1970s when a variety of chalcogenides, such as titanium disulfide (TiS2), work as the cathode and metallic lithium as anode producing a limited cell potential of 2.5 V versus Li+/Li [9]. Later, manganese and vanadium oxides were investigated. The pioneering work by Goodenough and coworkers invented layered lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) and spinel lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4) as cathode materials for lithium rechargeable batteries in the 1980s and the cell voltage extended above 4 V versus Li+/Li [10, 11]. After the release of reversible lithium insertion into graphite by Yazami and Touzain [12], the development of lithium-ion batteries using graphite anode and lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) cathode by Sony Inc. led to the successful commercialization of lithium-ion batteries in the 1990s. Thereafter, many other layered transition metal oxides including lithium nickel dioxide (LiNiO2), lithium manganese dioxide (LiMnO2), and vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) were developed as potential alternatives to the LiCoO2 cathode. Goodenough and coworkers [13] then reported a polyanion framework material, namely lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4), as prospective cathode material which has been commercialized by A123 Inc. and Sony Inc. Lithium iron phosphate displays appealing advantages in environmentally benign, low cost, very stable electrochemical properties with structural stability, high thermal stability, and a distinct working plateau [14]. The plots of electrochemical potentials versus specific capacity of the LIBs cathode materials are illustrated in Fig. 2.3a, and some of the commercialized cathode materials with the related properties are listed in Table 2.1. The current
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 75
research focuses on cathode materials are to develop high-voltage and highcapacity materials to increase the energy density (E) of the batteries which is subjected to the reversible capacity (Q) and operating voltage (Vop).
E ¼ QVop (2:50)
These intercalation compounds can be divided into several crystal structures, such as layered, spinel, olivine, and favorite, as shown in Fig. 2.3b–e, and their discharge profiles are displayed in Fig. 2.3f [15]. Among these cathode materials, NCM shows great promise in the target of high specific capacity by changing the ratio of the three transition metals. Figure 2.3g shows the phase diagram of the ternary system between LNO, LCO, and LMO with representative compositions. The number following NCM demotes the ratio of x:y:z in lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (LiNixCoyMnzO2).
Lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM523) is a commercial cathode material with high nickel content, but the high reactive Ni4+ at the end of charge reaction leads to undesired side reactions with the electrolyte, causing gas evolution and capacity degradation. The temperature stability of the ternary cathode material decreases with an increase in nickel content, magnifying the safety issues. The high nickel content also leads to a Li/Ni cation mixing and formation of inactive phases on the electrode surface. Lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM811) in the prolonged cycling leads to cracks along the boundaries of the secondary particles, gradually increasing the surface area and active sites for parasitic reactions. The cracks formed in the cycling are observable from the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images as shown in Fig. 2.3h, i, the cross section of a fresh NCM811 electrode, and after 100 cycles at C/3 at 45 C.
Conversion-type electrode materials have a solid-state redox reaction in the process of lithiation/de-lithiation, normally accompanied by the change in the crystal
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 77
structure and breaking/formation of chemical bonds. These cathode materials include metal halides comprising high valence metal ions and solid chalcogens including sulfur (S), selenium (Se), and tellurium (Te). Most conversion-type materials have very poor electron conductivity and moderate potential plateau as cathode materials, but their specific capacities are relatively high, up to 1675 mAh g 1 for sulfur [15].
Nanotechnologies for the synthesis of cathode materials have been widely used to control the morphology and dimension of the products. The synthetic methods mainly include freeze drying, template-direct growth, solvothermal and hydrothermal, supercritical fluid synthesis, ionothermal method, biosynthesis, solid-state reaction, and coprecipitation, but in a practical process, some of these methods are usually combined together. Figure 2.4a shows the SEM images of porous and hollow microspheres of lithium manganese nickel cobalt oxide (Li1.2Mn0.6Ni0.1Co0.1O2) in the synthetic process and Fig. 2.4b schematically explains the route. The precursor solutions coprecipitate the manganese(II) carbonate (MnCO3) nanoparticles and the following calcination forms manganese(IV) oxide (MnO2) microspheres. As the intermediate, MnO2 microspheres continue to react with lithium (Li), nickel (Ni), and cobalt (Co) sources at high temperature to obtain the final product. The formation of the hollow structure has been explained by the nanoscale Kirkendall effect and Ostwald ripening [18]. The hollow structured Li1.2Mn0.6Ni0.1Co0.1O2 displays a discharge capacity of 242 mAh g 1 at 50 mA g 1 with high Coulombic efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 2.4c. The cobalt(II) hydroxide [Co(OH)2] hexagonal nanoplates via a coprecipitation process was used to synthesize LCO nanoplates by a solid-state reaction as shown in Fig. 2.4d1, d2 [19]. The synthesized nanoplates have a hexagonal structure with exposed (001) planes confirmed by the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image in Fig. 2.4d3 and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 2.4d4. The synthetic route in Fig. 2.4e keeps the exposed (001) plane of cobalt(II) hydroxide [Co(OH)2] precursor in the final product and the Li+ ion diffusion is facilitated. The as-synthesized LCO releases a discharge capacity of 140 mAh g 1 at 100 mAg 1 and 113 mAh g 1 at large current rate of 1000 mAg 1, as shown in Fig. 2.4f.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 Anode Materials
sections.text:
Anode materials act as a reductant in a reversible battery opposite to the cathode and should be in high energy level but with the low ionic energy of Li+ ions. The anode materials have been classified into three categories according to the lithiation mechanisms, namely insertion (graphite, titanium-based materials), alloying (metals, semi-metals), and conversion (MaXb, M=metal, X= O, S, F, P, N, etc., and a/b are stoichiometric mole ratios) [7]. All these anode materials have both advantages and disadvantages: insertion-type materials have high cycling stability but low capacity, alloying-type materials have large capacity but suffer the large volume changes, and conversion-type materials display large capacity but unsatisfactory cycling stability and energy efficiency [7].

mechanism takes place on metals and nonmetal substances that can form alloys with lithium metal. The alloyed compounds and intermediates have distinct crystal structures and physiochemical properties from the reactants. Conversion mechanism happens in a redox reaction by reducing the materials, e.g. CoO, with lithium and forming electrochemically inactive lithium oxide, Li2O. Thus, Li2O leads to large irreversibility in the following reactions. The conversion-type anode materials can deliver high specific capacity by reducing metal ions to zero oxidation and are usually environmentally friendly, attracting great interest for next-generation lithium battery anode materials [23]. Some metal oxides have the synergistic mechanism from alloying and conversion processes and give a large and stable performance in the lithium storage. Nanotechnologies have been widely applied in the fabrication of nanomaterials aiming to improve the electrochemical properties through the control of the size and morphologies.
Graphite, as the most successful anode material in commercialization, has been studied extensively from both theory and experiment. However, there are still contrary understandings to the storage reaction of graphite with lithium in the transformation to graphite intercalated compound (GIC). The staged process takes place under specific potentials and a voltage of 0.2 V versus Li+/Li is usually the onset of state 4 GIC, and continuous lithiation promotes the staging reaction to stage 1 GIC. In the staging process, there are two developed mechanisms: Rüdorff model gives the sequential filling up mechanism when the lithium ions intercalate alternating graphene interlayer spaces without structure distortions. Daumas–Herold model proposes the intercalation would induce deformation around the intercalated lithium ions in the flexible graphene layers. Many in situ techniques, such as Raman spectra, have been developed to study the real-time characteristics of the graphite in the electrochemical reaction and provide insights into the mechanism of lithium storage [22]. Anode materials have been studied extensively within the structures of zero, one, two, and three dimensions, including carbon-based materials, sulfides and nitrides, metals and nonmetals, metal oxides, and polyanions.
Figure 2.6 displays the schematic illustration of a series of hollow carbon nanostructures with high graphitization, and these structures have been used as the sulfur host in lithium-surfer batteries because of the high conductivity and affinity to sulfur [24]. Similarly, these hollow carbon hosts are also able to accommodate other low-dimensional and small-size materials to provide improved performance in the lithium storage because of the suppressed volume change within the space of hollow structures and high conductivity of the carbon matrix. In comparison with the hollow structure, double- and multi-shell structures are proposed to provide more effective confinement to the incorporated materials. Porous shells are developed to contribute large surface area with the actives in the electrolyte and hosted materials, and the porous shell and core components can provide a better electronically connectingmatrix. Despite the advantages of the above, the hollow carbon bowls are able to accommodate highdensity actives in the hollow space, beneficial for the improvement of the volumetric density of the electrode. When the structures are processed down to one dimension, the high aspect ratio can better act as an electrically conducting network in the electrode leading to improved reaction kinetics and rate capability. The continuous processing within the hollow carbon structures, such as hollow carbon fiber, can derive novel tubein-tube structures which are rich in the channels and voids for the diffusion of lithium
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 81
ions and the actives accommodation. These structures, shown in Fig. 2.6b–f, h, i, can be considered as the derivatives of hollow spheres (Fig. 2.6a) and hollow tubes (Fig. 2.6g), which can perform better in the energy storage by introducing more channels and conduction matrix.
To understand the benefits of the host structures to the actives in the electrochemical energy storage, we take the easily-dissoluble sulfur as an example of actives and introduce several host structures to accommodate sulfur. In Fig. 2.7a, the schematic protocol shows the steps in forming a composite owning cobalt hydroxide (CH) inner shell and a layered double hydroxide (LDH) out shell loaded with sulfur (CH@LDH/S) [25]. The corresponding TEM images of the product of each stage are displayed in Fig. 2.7b, illustrating the morphology of zeolitic imidazolate framework-67 (ZIF-67), yolk-shell ZIF-67@LDH, double-shell CH@LDH, and CH@LDH/S. The double-shell CH@LDH nanocages have abundant polar surfaces to chemically adsorb lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and the complex shells are able to suppress their outward diffusion. In addition, the rich hydrophilic/hydroxy groups
and the possible electrocatalytic properties of LDH might enhance the adsorption of the soluble LiPSs and promote to convert to the short-chain polysulfides. In the synthesis of the double-shelled CH@LDH nanocages, ZIF-67 polyhedrals are used as a sacrificial template. The reaction between ZIF-67 and nickel(II) nitrate [Ni (NO3)2] results in the hollow LDH shell-coated ZIF-67 particles (ZIF-67@LDH), which then undergoes a solution reaction with Na2MoO4 to convert to CH@LDH. A high content of sulfur (75 wt%) is then loaded into CH@LDH matrix via the meltdiffusion method to form CH@LDH/S and this as-prepared double-shell composite has displayed significantly improved cycling stability in the lithium storage [25].
Figure 2.7c displays a schematic illustration of one-dimensional (1D) hollow carbon fiber (HCF) filled with MnO2 nanosheets (MnO2@HCF). This 1D HCF has a high aspect ratio and conductivity, plus the holes enhancing the porosity, together with facilitating both ion and electron conduction in the electrochemical reaction. The inner MnO2 nanosheets provide strong chemical adsorption for LiPSs and effectively prevent the dissolution [26]. Hollow nanospheres with highly conductive shells composed of titanium monoxide (TiO) nanoparticles and a thin carbon layer (TiO@C-HS) have been prepared as the sulfur host (Fig. 2.7d) [27]. The shell is highly conductive and about 20 nm in thickness (see Fig. 2.7e). After the melt diffusion, the hollow space is filled up with sulfur with a high content of 70 wt%. TiO@C-HS/S thick electrode with a high sulfur loading of 4.0 mg cm 2 can deliver high specific capacities at different current densities with a stable cycling performance (Fig. 2.7f). In this protocol, a polar and highly conductive host has been developed for effective accommodating of sulfur.
Hollow nanostructures with multi-level architectures have been attracting great interest in the fabrication of the anode materials in hierarchical structures because of the outstanding buffering to the volume variation in the electrochemical reaction and improved tap density by utilizing the inner cavities in a hollow space, in comparison with the single-shell hollow structures [28]. Multi-level hollow nanostructures including yolk-shell, multi-shell, and multi-chamber structures have been proposed and prepared for the use of energy storage [29]. These complex structures make better use of the inner hollow space and effectively increase the fraction of the electrochemical actives. These multi-level skeletons have strong structural stability [30] to ensure a high capacity retention in the long-term charging-discharging cycles. The widely used synthetic strategies for the hollow nanostructures mainly include Ostwald ripening, nanoscale Kirkendall effect, hard and soft templating method, spray pyrolysis, and heterogeneous contraction.
Figure 2.8a, b displays the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of the yolk-shell nanoprisms of nickel cobalt (Ni0.37Co) oxide by a thermally driven heterogeneous contraction reaction. The prism has a pyramid-shaped apex at both ends, and the yolk-shell nanoprisms compose of numerous polycrystalline nanoparticles. The galvanostatic cycling of the as-prepared nanoprisms in Fig. 2.8c indicates that a high reversible capacity of 1028.5 mAh g 1 over 30 cycles at 200 mAh g 1 is maintained implying high stability of the electrodes [31]. The hard-templating method is common to fabricate the hollow structures and carbonaceous material (CM)-based templates are widely used to form multiple shells
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 83
and chambers. As shown in Fig. 2.8d, the adsorption and penetration of metal precursors take place in the porous carbon structures usually with rich functional groups to form metal glycolates (CH2(OH)COO
M+). The subsequent annealing in the air combusts the carbon template and oxidizes the metal precursors to metal oxides where the temperature gradient along the radial direction in the annealing process results in the gradual removal of carbon and formation of a multi-shell hollow structure. The structure parameters of the products such as the shell number, shell thickness, porosity, and chemical composition can be tuned by the control of metal ion concentration, solvent category, pH value, annealing temperature and rate, reaction atmosphere, etc. TEM images in Fig. 2.8e–g clearly display the identical multi-shell hollow spheres of binary metal oxides (CoMn2O4, Co1.5Mn1.5O4, and MnCo2O4) from the penetrationsolidification-annealing protocol.
The self-templating method has been extensively used to synthesize complex hollow structures by using the self-engaged templates which are usually the inorganic/organic hybrids composed of metal ions and clusters. Figure 2.8h displays the cobalt sulfide (CoS4) nanobubble-composed hollow prisms prepared through a two-step diffusioncontrolled process in the conversion from cobalt acetate hydroxide nanoprisms to ZIF-67 hollow prisms and subsequent sulfidation reaction to form CoS4 bubble-like particles [32]. The annealing process preserves the prism morphology and forms interconnected CoS2 nanobubbles, as shown in Fig. 2.8i. The as-obtained CoS2 displays extraordinary reversible rate capabilities at current densities ranging from 0.2 to 5 Ag 1 (Fig. 2.8j). The chemical compositions of the shells can be manipulated in the synthesis, and the hybridization of two electrochemically active components in one composite can contribute extra benefits to structural stability, conductivity, and electrochemical activity. Multi-shell Co3O4@Co3V2O8 nanoboxes are fabricated by controlling the amount of vanadium oxytriisopropoxide (VOT, [OV(OCH(CH3)2)3]) in the reaction with cubic ZIF-67 precursors [33]. In the annealing process, the intermediates of ZIF-67 nanocubes with the cobalt vanadium oxide (Co3V2O8) shell are transformed into double-shell (D) and triple-shell (T) Co3O4@Co3V2O8 nanoboxes (D-Co3O4@Co3V2O8 and T-Co3O4@Co3V2O8), displayed by the TEM images in Fig. 2.8k, l. As evidenced from the elemental mapping results in Fig. 2.8m, the shells have different chemical compositions with a Co3V2O8 outermost shell and two Co3O4 inner shells in T-Co3O4@Co3V2O8. The nanoprocessing of structures is as expected, helping to enhance the lithium storage properties resulting from a synergistic effect from the complex configurations and compositions [29].

sections.heading: 2.4 Nanostructured Materials in Supercapacitors
sections.text:
The development in the physical and chemical properties of nanomaterials and the improved understanding of their synthesis, characterization, and electrochemistry lead to a breakthrough in the field of supercapacitors for energy storage. The principle of supercapacitors is elucidated in terms of the resulting electrochemical characteristics and charge storage mechanisms, i.e., double-layer capacitance or pseudocapacitance. The electrochemical behaviors and charge storage mechanisms are also dependent on the size or thickness; notwithstanding, the materials may be electrically insulating semiconductors. There are increasing numbers of electrode materials, such as transition metal oxides, hydroxides, conducting polymers, etc., that display electrochemical characteristics neither purely capacitive nor purely Faradaic [2]. Before introducing the electrode nanomaterials of the two types of charge storage mechanisms, we use the band theory for semiconductors and electrochemical characteristics in i-V and V-t curves to understand the origin of the capacitance and the principle.
Electron transfer takes place in electronically interactive or separated redox-active centers, highly depending on the electron conductivity of materials. The electrons in the outer most orbit of an atom experience least attraction force by the nuclei and have high kinetic energy. In Fig. 2.9a, the separated and noninteractive atoms have electrons in the atomic orbits, and these orbits form a discrete set of energy levels. The low-energy levels are filled with electrons with fixed energy level, while the high-energy levels are empty. In a molecule composed of two atoms, the original atomic orbits are split into separate molecular orbits of different energy levels. The amount of molecular orbits is determined by the atomics, p, d, or f orbits, that are occupied by electrons [34]. The molecular orbits of low-energy levels are occupied by electrons and of high-energy levels are empty. When a number of atoms are brought together into a molecule, the electrons of one atom experience forces of other atoms and this effect is the most pronounced on outer most orbits. These atomic orbits split into separate molecular orbitals of different energy. When a large number of atoms (1020 or more) are brought together to form a solid, the orbital number is extremely large and the difference in energy between these orbits becomes small. These energy levels form continuous bands rather than the discrete energy levels of the atoms in isolation. The intervals of energy levels containing no orbits form band gaps between the highest level of one band and the lowest level of the next.
The core bands composed of core-level orbits (both the bonding and antibonding levels) are completely populated, so they have small overlapping in molecules and thus little contribution to bonding. The valence orbits of adjacent atoms have strong

interaction and have a large bandwidth. In valence orbits, the bonding orbits have energy lower than the atomic orbits, mostly in-phase, but each of the bonding orbits still has slightly different energies. The antibonding orbits show an increase in energy compared with the atomic orbitals, mostly out-of-phase, and each of the antibonding orbits also has little difference in energy. These energy levels for all the bonding orbitals and antibonding orbits are so close that they form valence band and conduction band, respectively. In most existing solids, the valence band is partially occupied by the valence electrons resulting from the original atomic orbits that are not fully occupied. The valence electrons are able to move through the occupied and unoccupied orbits contributing to semiconductivity, which are delocalized in the valence band [34]. The degree of delocalization of electrons or the zone sizes is the typical difference in metals, semiconductors, and insulators.
The Nernstian reaction, that the Faradaic charge transfer in isolated redox centers, takes place in solid insulators or liquid electrolytes whose valence electrons are localized. All these transferred electrons are from the orbits of the same or very close energy level but different redox centers; thus, the electron transfer occurs at potentials in a very narrow range close to the equilibrium potential. This results in
current peaks in the cyclic voltammograms and potential plateaus in galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles. When these redox centers have a strong interaction with each other in the valence band, which might be due to the short separation or high conductivity or both, their energy states are so close to merge together into a broadband. In this case, the electron transfer at these energy states is continuous over a wide range of potentials, leading to a constant current flow. For pseudocapacitance, each electron in the band model is explained to transfer to a particular energy level shared by many atoms. There is no fixed stoichiometry between the number of electrons and the compensated species over a potential range.
Electrochemical characteristics of electrode materials mainly including i-V and V-t curves provide real-time reaction information in the specific electrolyte solution. As explained for the charge-storage mechanisms in electrochemical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitor from surface redox reaction, the capacitortype responses should have rectangular cyclic voltammograms (Fig. 2.10a, b) and linear voltage response at constant current (Fig. 2.10c). In contrast, battery-type responses have prominent and widely separated peaks in cyclic voltammograms (Fig. 2.10g, h) and nonlinear voltage profiles with characteristic plateaus associated with the redox reactions of the active centers. The redox peaks of a battery reaction can be widened by enlarging the electrochemically active surface area with increased contribution from Faradaic charge-transfer reaction (see Fig. 2.10g). As a result, the voltage-time profile should have a degenerated voltage plateau, which is neither a battery nor a capacitor response. An intermediate behavior between these two extremes indicates the pseudocapacitance from intercalation, as shown in Fig. 2.10d–f. Niobium oxide (Nb2O5) in organic electrolyte has displayed a welldefined intercalation/de-intercalation mechanism by lithium ions and MXenes show reversible redox peaks in the same reaction mechanism. The judgment of a material whether belonged to battery-type or capacitor-type can follow this information: (i) electrochemical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and surficial pseudocapacitance should have rectangular i-V curves and triangular-shape charge-discharge profiles; (ii) intercalation pseudocapacitance should display reversible redox peaks although these peaks may be pronounced [6]; (iii) the kinetic parameter, b in the equation i = avb correlating peak currents and sweet rates of potentials, is 1 implying a capacitive material while 0.5 denoting battery material of a semi-infinite diffusion. Any value far from 1 and 0.5 indicates a mixing reaction mechanism from capacitive and diffusion process. These characteristics in electrochemistry are highly dependent on the material type (e.g., metal, metal oxide, etc.), reaction system, and the size and state (e.g., thin film) of materials.

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Electrochemical Double-Layer Capacitor
sections.text:
Electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) store charges at an electrode–electrolyte interface when a voltage bias is applied. The maximum capacitance of EDLC is on the order of hundreds of farads per gram, which is numbers of magnitude larger than that of a traditional dielectric capacitor of which the capacitance is only microfarad
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 89
per gram. A large capacitance is achievable when the charge separation distance is extremely short (<1 nm) at the electrode–electrolyte interface, and the electrode materials have an exceptionally high specific surface area (SSA) which is key to lead to a high gravimetric capacitance and hence high energy density. The highest energy densities of the commercial EDLC using high-SSA activated carbons are nevertheless still below 12 Wh kg 1, much smaller than that of Li-ion batteries. Carbon nanomaterials including carbon nanotubes activated carbon and graphene are typical electrode materials in EDLC and have been widely studied because of their high specific surface area and excellent electrical and mechanical properties. The research now is focusing on increasing the energy density of the carbon nanomaterials in EDLC without sacrificing the power density and cycle life.
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are promising electrode materials in supercapacitors as a result of their high aspect ratio, large specific surface area (SSA), and high electrical conductivity. A free-standing mat composed of entangled multiwall nanotubes (MWNTs) has been reported to have a specific capacitance of 102 F g 1 with a power density above 8 kW kg 1 and an energy
density of 1 Wh kg 1 in hydrosulfuric acid (H2SO4) electrolyte [35]. A higher specific capacitance of 180 F g 1 was achieved on the single-wall nanotube (SWNT) distributed in a random network (Fig. 2.11a) working in potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte [37] and the maximum power density and energy density are 20 kW kg 1 and 10 Wh kg 1, respectively. Contrary to the random entanglement of CNTs, the vertically aligned CNT (VA-CNT) arrays have been fabricated with vertically aligned tubes and well-defined tube spacing, as shown in Fig. 2.11b, c [38]. This arrangement allows more contact area between the electrode and electrolyte, thus enhancing the participation in the charging/ discharging process of each aligned tube (Fig. 2.11d). Furthermore, the etching processing such as the plasma can open the top caps of these VA-CNTs (see Fig. 2.11e–g), and the access to the inner cavity of these tubes by electrolyte has greatly improved the properties in energy storage [39]. In the opening of the tube tips, plasma etching also introduces defects and oxygenated functionalization to the surface of the nanotubes, enhancing the capacitive behavior by combining the double-layer capacitance and redox pseudocapacitance. As shown in Fig. 2.11h, the aligned carbon nanotubes with excellent contact with the current collector and rich active area reacting with the ionic liquid electrolyte have displayed a high cell voltage (4 V), high specific energy (148 Wh kg 1), and high specific power (315 kW kg 1) [36], which might be the delegate of the high-performance supercapacitor and exceed the current electrochemical capacitor technology.
Graphene, a two-dimensional hexagonal lattice structure of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms covalently bonded along the single atomic planar sheet [40], has aroused tremendous interest due to its intrinsic characteristics such as physical [41–43], mechanical [44], and electrical properties [40, 45, 46] since the discovery of its freestanding form in 2004. The sp2 bonds formed by s, px, and py atomic orbitals hybridization can result in 120 C C-C bond angles and the honeycomb layers. Also the remaining pz orbital on each carbon could overlap with its neighboring carbons to form π bonds. The valence band and conduction band consist of π orbitals and anti-bonding π orbitals and the cross of bands gives rise to Dirac points K and K0 per Brillouin zone [47]. So far, many protocols including mechanical exfoliation [40], epitaxial growth [48], chemical vapor deposition [49, 50], and oxidation-exfoliation reduction of graphite [51, 52] have been developed for the synthesis of graphene.
Free-hanging graphene is the thinnest conceivable nanocarbon, and, in particular, as a result of the overlarge surface area and mechanical strength [53–55], graphene has been considered promising for energy storage [42, 49, 56–59] including rechargeable lithium-ion batteries [60, 61], supercapacitors [62–64], and fuel cell devices [65]. In comparison with single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), graphene exhibits an electrical conductivity ~64 mS cm 1, approximately 60 times higher [45] and owns an extremely high theoretical surface area (2675 m2 g 1) [66], twice larger than that of CNTs (1315 m2 g 1) [67]. A fast heterogeneous electron-transfer rate with an order of 0.01 cm s 1 has been found at the edges and basal plane defects of graphene [68]. These reported characteristics of graphene imply a high potential of graphene as an electrode material in supercapacitors. The intrinsic specific capacitance of monolayer graphene
2 Understanding the Energy Storage Principles of Nanomaterials in Lithium. . . 91
was found as 21 μF cm 2, equal to 561 F g 1 if the theoretical surface area (2675 m2 g 1) could be used sufficiently, setting the upper limit for electrical doublelayer capacitance for all carbon-based material [66]. Meunier and Ajayan et al. suggest that the specific capacitance of the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) graphene and reduced graphene oxide can increase to 80 and 394 μF cm 2 [69]. However, a variety of graphene-based materials derived from graphene oxide (GO) indicated unsatisfied electrochemical behaviors [70], mainly attributed to the restacking of graphene sheets during processing via the sheet-to-sheet van der Waals interaction.
None-restacking curved graphene [71], solvated graphene [72], and laserscribed graphene [62] have been obtained which show the enhanced performance of 154, 215, and 265 F g 1, respectively. Ajayan et al. use a laser writing technique to directly convert graphene oxide (GO) to reduced graphene oxide (rGO) within a porous structure (Fig. 2.12a) by decomposing the functional
groups and adsorbed water molecules [70]. The patterned in-plane and sandwich designs are formed in rGO-GO-rGO configuration by using GO with a substantial amount of water, as the ionic conductor but electrical insulator. The microsupercapacitors show the highest capacitance of 0.51 mF cm 2 for the in-plane structure, nearly twice larger than that of the sandwich structure, resulting from the anisotropic nature of ion mobility and transport distances. Kaner et al. reported a method to reduce GO by the laser using a LightScribe compact disk/ digital video disk (CD/DVD) optical drive, and the resulted graphene has an extremely high conductivity of 1738 S m 1 and specific surface area (SSA) of 1520 m2 g 1 [62]. Supercapacitor devices with the as-prepared graphene as electrodes exhibit ultrahigh energy density values in different electrolytes of aqueous, organic, and ionic liquid and maintain a high power density in the long-term cycling. The high flexibility of the material and device implies the potential use in high-power, flexible electronics. Ruoff et al. studied the capacitive behavior of graphene in terms of the layer number, from one to five (see Fig. 2.12b). The quantum capacitance effect near the point of zero charge makes the capacitance suppressed near neutrality, and the correlation between the electrode and electrolyte enhances the capacitance only when the thickness is below few layers. They prepared an activated graphene oxide (AGO) with the super-high surface area (3100 m2 g 1) via the activation with potassium hydroxide (KOH) by microwave [75], and AGO with a three-dimensional porous structure presented high specific capacitance (150~200 F g 1). The enhanced electrochemical performance of AGO is due to its two-dimensional plane and produced edge planes which have much high electron transfer kinetics over the basal [76]. The oxygen-functional groups at the edges of graphene sheets cause a controversial electrochemistry influence [63, 77], not only on the heterogeneous electron transfer rate but also on the adsorption/desorption of molecules [67, 78]. To understand the factors arising from graphene structure that affect the electrochemical results, the electrochemical characteristics of GO, RGO, AGO, and reduced AGO (RAGO) were prepared through a top-down method, as shown in Fig. 2.12c [74]. Graphene oxide was prepared by Hummers method [79] and chemically activated to AGO in situation A (SA), with smaller GO fragments and a larger ratio of edge to basal plane, then going to situation B (SB), with pore defects and higher specific surface area (SSA). The approximate monocrystalline characteristic of GO is transformed to polycrystalline after activation, demonstrating that the activated defects have distorted the crystalline structure of graphene oxides. RGO and RAGO were synthesized via chemical reduction by hydrazine monohydrate using GO and AGO as precursors, respectively. As represented in Fig. 2.12d, the ratio of edge plane to basal plane [63, 76], defects involving edge defects and pore defects, chemical impurities of metal oxides and surfactant [80, 81], oxygen-functional groups [63, 77], and the underlying supporting electrode [76] are key factors to influence the electrochemistry of a graphene supercapacitor. The edge ratio, SSA, edge defects, and metal impurities

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Pseudocapacitor
sections.text:
In comparison with the carbon materials which mainly contribute double-layer capacitance, the pseudocapacitive electrode materials are highly interesting and the current studied pseudocapacitor materials include metal oxides, metal carbide or MXenes, metal sulfides, metal nitrides, layer hydroxides, and conducting polymers. However, most pseudocapacitive materials suffer from high resistance for electron and/or ion transfer, setting restriction to their capacity, rate capability, and cyclability. Nanotechnologies have offered to enable rational designs to optimize the structure and size of these materials leading to an improvement in the performance of energy storage.
Pseudocapacitors store charges through the transfer of charge between electrode and electrolyte, and the resulted pseudocapacitance (Cpc) is proportional to the amount of the charge transferred, which is described in the following equation [82, 83]:
Cpc ¼ Q dθ=dVð Þ (2:51) where Q is the Faradaic charge required for adsorption/desorption of ions, dθ is the change in fractional surface coverage, and dV is the change in potential. The value of dθ/dV is not always linear in a voltage range; the capacitance is thus not always constant and termed as pseudocapacitance [84]. The redox pseudocapacitance occurs in the surface redox reaction by electrochemical adsorbing ions on/near the electrode surface and transferring electrons at the redox active sites. The intercalation pseudocapacitance arises from the electrochemical intercalation of electroactive species in the layered structure of the electrodes without crystallographic phase change. Both the redox and intercalation pseudocapacitance is more popular in the development of pseudocapacitors and their faradaic reactions are very fast without ionic diffusion limitation, which is distinctive from the solid-state diffusion process in batteries. In the following content, we mainly introduce the development of pseudocapacitive materials owning redox and intercalation pseudocapacitance.
Ruthenium oxide (RuO2) is a typical redox-reaction pseudocapacitive electrode material and has been extensively studied in an acidic electrolyte, giving the reaction mechanism as shown in Eq. (2.52). The charge/discharge process enables the rapid reversible electron transfer which is compensated by the electroabsorption of protons on the surface of RuO2, and the oxidation states vary from Ru +2 to Ru+4:

1, close to its theoretical value of 1400 F/g (Fig. 2.14a) [85]. The advantages in high conductivity and reversibility of RuO2 in the electrochemical reaction allow a high-rate capability in charge storage. As displayed in Fig. 2.14b, the capacitance retains 75% when the scan rate increases from 2 to 500 mV s 1. Although RuO2 has a promising performance in the electrochemical energy storage, the high toxicity and cost restrict the large-scale use of RuO2. Other transition metal oxides have
been intensively studied as alternatives to RuO2 in the application of supercapacitors. Most transition metal oxides are semiconductors and suffer the poor electrical conductivity, causing low charge-transfer kinetics and sluggish ion diffusion in the redox reaction. Manganese dioxide (MnO2) is another typical metal oxide giving pseudocapacitance but the thick electrodes usually give low capacitance ranging between 200 and 250 F g 1. The nanosizing thin film of MnO2 dramatically increases the capacitance to large than 1000 F g
1 resulting from the enhanced ion-accessible surface area. To figure out the shortage of electronic conduction, compositing with conductive matrix has been a popular method. Figure 2.14c shows the TEM images of a composite of nanocrystalline MnO2 distributed in the nanoporous gold (NPG) matrix. The electron transfer of this composite is facilitated and the resulted capacitance is as high as 1145 F g 1 approaching the theoretical value of MnO2 (see Fig. 2.14d). MnO2 nanoflowers were reported to grow on the flexible NPG wires, which own enhanced electronic/ionic conduction. The absence of binder in this electrode also benefits the activation of electrode materials in reaction. Figure 2.14e displays an NPG@MnO2 structure scrolled by CNT/carbon paper for use in all-solid-state, highly flexible supercapacitors. This supercapacitor has a high voltage of 1.8 V in the charge/discharge process, delivering a high energy density of 5.4 μWh cm 2 and a maximum power density of 2531 μW cm 2 (see Fig. 2.14f). sections.heading: 2.5 Conclusion
sections.text:
Nanomaterials, thanks to the large progress of nanoscience and nanotechnologies, have exhibited great advantages in improving the electrochemical properties of the energy storage and conversion devices. These merits are mainly due to the optimized properties in nanoscale by offering high surface area, large surface-to-volume ratio, high conduction property, altered physical and electronic properties, and confinement effects in nano dimensions. Nanoparticulate electrodes or electrocatalysts are able to lead to high contact area at the interface of electrode/electrolyte, hence the high rate in the electrode reaction. Nanotubes have a high surface-to-volume ratio and display high reactivity in the electrochemical reactions with this particular morphologies. These advantageous nano effects of nanomaterials originate from the methodologies to manipulate and control materials at the atomic or molecular level and the understanding of the synthesis protocol from nanoscale. Nanomaterials have been designed with a specific target in use through a variety of ways, such as morphology fabrication, electronic structure doping, nanosizing, compositing, etc.
A growing number of materials and materials of different structures have been proposed to be used in the electrochemical systems to enhance the performance in energy storage and supply. For example, the carbon nanotubes have been used in lithium-ion batteries as a three-dimensional conductivity network, greatly enhancing the high-rate and cycling performance. However, there are still some issues related to the electrochemical systems by using nanomaterials. The fundamental understanding of the energy chemistry in the process of energy storage and conversion on the nanostructured materials is still far more enough. The scarce knowledge of the relationship between the structure and performance of the material restrains the rational design of specifically targeted materials. There is vague understanding upon the interfacial effects and structure properties of nanomaterials in the form of hybrids or composites, as well as the resulted electrochemical behaviors. Many functional nanomaterials exhibiting high performance in energy storage and conversion have to go through a routine trial-and-error cycle to develop.
In addition, nanostructured materials are not perfect and still need huge development to meet the increasing demand in the energy area. No matter the materials used for lithium-ion batteries or supercapacitors, all the following aspects can be considered for further improvement of nanostructured materials in processing. The high conduction in both electrons and ions is urgent for high-rate electrochemical devices and materials can be developed by heteroatom doping, compositing with conductive networks. The downsizing of materials indeed has brought large improvement in the electrochemical performance of devices but simultaneously caused more side reactions and changed reaction mechanism. Also, effective means are still highly needed to ensure the uniformity of nanomaterials and avoid agglomeration in micro or nanoscale.

Further, the generated electrical energy should be stored for improving mobile applications, being batteries the most used system for this purpose. Lithium-ion batteries are the most promising battery type and are composed of three main elements: cathode, anode, and separator/electrolyte. The active material of the cathode is primarily responsible for the battery capacity, and
