sections.heading: 3.1 Introduction
sections.text:
In order to reduce dependence on fossil fuels, eco-friendly renewable energies, such as wind, solar, and biomass, must be increasingly used due to global warming caused by increasing energy use and population increase [24, 171].
The energy produced by these systems must be stored, and batteries are the type of energy storage most used for different applications, such as consumer electronics, medical applications, hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), and pure electric vehicles (PEVs), among others, due to their high power and energy density [50, 68, 209]. In particular, for HEVs and PEVs, it is necessary to increase the energy density of batteries.
The main components of a lithium-ion battery are the two different current collectors, typically copper and aluminum, two electrodes (negative and positive), and the separator/electrolyte [192].
The negative electrode, anode, should present a low potential in order to provide high cell voltage with the positive electrode, cathode, that is responsible for the cell capacity and cycle life [89, 189].
Regardless of the type of electrode, they consist of an active material, a conductive material, and a polymer binder at different ratios [69]. These three components are typically mixed in a solvent where the polymer is dissolved, and the active material and the conductive additive are dispersed to obtain good dispersion without sedimentation.
Considering that the active material of the cathode is primarily responsible for the battery capacity, this chapter focuses on the recent advances in the active cathode materials most commonly used in lithium-ion batteries. Further, new opportunities in this field are discussed.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Electrode Main Components
sections.text:
Figure 3.1 shows a schematic representation of a battery and the main components of the electrodes. In the electrodes, each constituent has a specific function: the polymer binder has the role of binding the active material and conductive additive; the conductive additive increases the electrical conductivity of the electrode; and, in the case of the active material for the cathode, lithium ions must enter and leave repeatedly, its structure containing a readily reducible/oxidable ion [151]. In relation to the conductive additive, the most used materials are carbon black and acetylene black due to higher electrical conductivity and low cost [61].
106 C. M. Costa et al.
For the polymer binder, poly(vinylidene fluoride), PVDF, and poly(tetrafluoroethylene), PTFE, are the most used binders due to excellent mechanical strength, high chemical resistance, and high melting temperature [66, 239].
The active materials used for cathode development must show high reactivity with lithium, incorporation of large amounts of lithium, reversibility in lithium incorporation with structural stability, high lithium diffusion, good electrical conductivity, and insolubility in the electrolyte. The active materials most used in lithium-ion batteries are presented in Table 3.1 [139]. Table 3.1 shows the crystal system, theoretical capacity, and typical potential for each active material.
These active materials are synthesized by different methods including mechanochemical activation, carbothermal reduction, microwave heating, hydrothermal synthesis, sol-gel synthesis, spray pyrolysis, and coprecipitation, among others, in which their morphology and size are controlled [13, 17, 72, 145, 153, 186, 256].
It is to notice that each synthesis method shows specific advantages and disadvantages. Thus, the hydrothermal method is very used due to its low-energy costs, low cost (relatively cheap reagents), pollution-free (closed system reaction), large dispersion (reaction time), low operating temperature (facilitates industrialization), high reaction rate (higher efficiency), and nucleation control [210].
The control of morphology and particle size is essential for obtaining cathode electrodes with high cycling performance, as particles of small size show shorter Li+ ion diffusion length, which can further improve Li-ion migration rate [28].
Further, in order to reduce the capacity fade and improve the electronic and ionic conductivity of these active materials, those structures have been doped with metal, nonmetal, or rare earth elements, among others [143, 259].

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Recent Advances in the Most Commonly Used Active Materials
sections.text: In this chapter, each one of the active cathode materials reported in Table 3.1 will be addressed. For each one, the main properties, synthesis methods, and electrochemical properties will be presented. Some of the active materials are illustrated in Fig. 3.2 by its specific capacity versus cell voltage (Li+/Li) in order to compare their characteristics.

sections.heading: 3.1.2.1 Lithium Cobalt Oxide (LiCoO2)
sections.text:
Lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) has been one of the most widely used cathode materials in commercial Li-ion rechargeable batteries, due to its good capacity retention, high structural reversibility (under 4.2 V vs. Li+/Li), and good rate capability. This active material was originally suggested by Goodenough et al. [166], and in the early 1990s, Sony Corporation commercialized it [42, 165]. The undoped LiCoO2 cathode material shows a structure along the c-axis with CoO6 octahedra separated by Li+ layers, where the LiO6 octahedra are elongated. The LiCoO2 unit cell in the hexagonal setting is composed of three layers in rhombohedral symmetry [30]. The layered LiCoO2 with the rhombohedral unit cell is characterized by a space group R3m with a = 2.8166 Å and c = 14.045 Å [211]. The
108 C. M. Costa et al.
layered crystal structure of LiCoO2 with a density of 5.1 g cm 3 is ideal to accommodate lithium ions. The active material also presents magnetic properties [174]. This property led to different applications being its use in cathode material in lithium batteries one of the most promising due to the deintercalation of lithium LixCoO2 (x < 1). The experimental band gap (Eg) is about 1.7–2.7 eV [3].
A large anisotropic volume change is verified when LiCoO2 converts to Li0.5CoO1.5 during the charging. This volume change of the host lattice is about 7% and occurs in the c-axis direction. Consequently, it is verified a peeling between the conducting material and the active material particles that results in problems in capacity fade and poor rate capability of the cathode. The main reason for this fact is due to the material dispersion into the electrolyte [165]. During the charge, the migration of Li+ ions from the layered crystal lattice causes a nonstoichiometric Li1 xCoO2 formation, and the oxidation of Co3+ changes for charge compensation [42].
The theoretical electrochemical capacity of LiCoO2 is around 274 mAh.g 1, but due to the instability of the structure and the limitation of Li+ removal from the hexagonal lattice (0.5), this capacity is reduced to around 140 mAh.g 1 [42].
Some efforts have been made in order to recycle the active material [182, 275]. Zhang group used ultrasound radiation on LiCoO2 previously calcinated at 500 C in order to remove all the carbon and binder of the cathode. The treatment consists of the application of hydrothermal ultrasound radiation during 6 h (600 W) at 80 C in a concentrated solution of lithium hydroxide (LiOH). The renovated active material shows a discharge capacity retention of 99.5 and a first discharge capacity of 133.5 mAh.g 1. It is shown that after 40 cycles the electrochemical properties of commercial batteries were achieved [275].
Different methods and synthesis routes, such as sol-gel [12, 65], flux-coating [165], one-step electrochemical-hydrothermal [8], combustion [200], microwave
[84], hydrothermal [21], thermal decomposition [164], and auto flame [215], were used to produce the LiCoO2.
In Azib’s approach [8], thin films of LiCoO2 were synthesized via electrochemicalhydrothermal route using ethanol and water blends as a solvent. The influence of parameters such as ethanol-water ratio, pressure, temperature, current density, and reaction time was evaluated on the R3m layered phase formation and in the electrochemical response of Li batteries. The results show that well-crystalized LiCoO2 with preferred orientation (101) without traces of spinel-like phase and cobalt oxide impurities were achieved and show a capacity of around 120 mAh.g 1 [8].
In another study [12], thin films of LiCoO2 were prepared by spin coating deposition via a sol-gel process. The annealing temperature of 275 C shows to be effective in the crystalline nature with a preferred orientation along the (003) plane of the rhombohedral structure. Above 416 C, the material degrades. It was found that the conductivity of the samples decreases from 10 3 to 10 9 Ω 1 cm 1 and that the band gap energy decreases from 2.51 to 3.4 eV with annealing temperatures from 275 C to 475 C, respectively.
Two kinds of crystallographic structures of the LiCoO2 can be achieved according to the synthesis temperature. The cubic spinel structure is formed around 350 C, and around the 750 C, the layered trigonal (hexagonal) structure is formed. It is observed that the structure with the layered lattice shows a better electrochemical performance when compared with the structure with a cubic spinel lattice [42].
Nanostructured approaches have been used in order to enable buffering of the stresses caused by the volume variation, improving the electrochemical performance and the structural durability through the increased surface area and decreasing the diffusion length of lithium ions in the extraction/insertion reaction. Higher capacities at high charge/discharge rates are achieved due to the shorter diffusion pathways for ionic transport and electronic conduction [165].
Neutron scattering of a battery with LiCoO2 during the charge/discharge process shows no difference of the active material at 25 C and 50 C operation. In the same study, it was verified that the lattice parameter c of the rhombohedral structure and cell volume increases during the discharge process (more noticeable at 25 C) [30].
Different approaches to overcome the nanosized materials problems, such as particle aggregation that results in capacity fade due to low tap density and the not homogeneous distribution, were evaluated. One of these methods was the growth of an additive-free nanosized LiCoO2 crystal layer directly on the current collector [165].
In order to improve the overcharge of the LiCoO2 (discharge energy of 96%), a coating with AlPO4 was used, and the over-insertion tolerance maintains to over 99% of the discharge energy after ten cycles. Also, the AlPO4 coating prevents crystal structure changes and suppresses irreversible cation Li and Co exchange in the octahedral layers of the LiCoO2 during the over-insertion of Li + ions [39].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.2 Lithium Manganese Oxide (LiMnO2)
sections.text:
Lithium manganese oxide (LiMnO2) layered structure is a very attractive material (compared to LiCoO2) from the environmental and economic perspective. This material shows two structures: orthorhombic with space group Pmmn and rhombohedral, being
110 C. M. Costa et al.
the orthorhombic structure thermodynamically stable. In order to obtain the layered material, the ion-exchange technique was used. Contrary, the rhombohedral structure is thermodynamically unstable due to the low spin of the Mn3+ [244, 271]. Both of them involve distortion in the oxygen arrays from the ideal cubic close packing. The orthorhombic structure also shows the advantage of being easy to prepare and air stable, showing high capacity (285 mAh.g 1) and high potential vs. lithium. Other advantages are also observed once the reduction of manganese oxide (MnO2) does not release gases and MnO2 is a low-cost material [211]. Lithium manganese oxide batteries were first used to power calculators, memory backups, and watches. This material is the most common active material used in lithium batteries with 80% of the market share [97].
During the cycling process, it is observed poor electrochemical properties and a drop in the voltage profile, due to both orthorhombic and rhombohedral LiMnO2 transformation in a spinel structure, once this phase shows low crystallinity, Mn dissolution, and large strain (Jahn-Teller activity) [271]. Jin group observed the transformation of orthorhombic lithium manganese oxide (LiMnO2) to spinel LiMnO2 phase during cyclic voltammetry (Fig. 3.3) [95, 194]. The main difficulty in obtaining layered LiMnO2 (compared with LiCoO2 and LiNiO2) is attributed to the fact the ion Mn3+ and Li+ have the closer size [194].
In order to stabilize the layered structure, different approaches with cation doping with aluminum (Al), cobalt (Co), chromium (Cr), and titanium (Ti), among others, were carried out [26].
Different types of synthesis routes were used to obtain this material, including low temperature [288], high temperature [43], hydrothermal [136, 255], flux method [241], solid state [5], and quenching [117].
The work developed by Xiao’s group [255] reported that morphologies as rod and nanoparticles show different properties. The rods exhibit higher discharge (200 mAh.g 1) capacity and better cyclability. The nanoparticles show a capacity of 170 mAh.g 1, but after 30 cycles it decreases to 110 mAh.g 1, whereas the rods decrease from 200 to 180 mAh.g 1 after 30 cycles. The rod morphology plays an important role in the electrochemical performance once it favors the electron transport along the length pathway and accommodates the volume changes originated by the charge/discharge process.
In order to improve the cycle life of LiMnO2, coatings with cobalt oxide (CoO) and alumina (Al2O3) were realized. This improvement is due to the prevention of the Mn dissolution and lattice instability from the Jahn-Teller distortion [31, 32]. Other methods as doping with Boron were also used to improve cycling performance of LiMnO2 batteries, in particular at high temperatures (60 C), by the reduction of surface reaction and/or transition metal dissolution. The improvement of the B-doping on the Coulombic efficiency ranges from 69.7% in pristine LiMnO2 to 99.0% in ten at % B-doped [288].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.3 Lithium Manganese Oxide (LiMn2O4)
sections.text: Lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4) was proposed by Thackeray’s group [226] in

sections.heading: 1986 as the cathode material. This cathode corresponds to the third generation, with
sections.text:
LiCoO2 representing the first and LiFePO4 representing the second. Composed by a
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 111
transition metal oxide, LiMn2O4 is characterized by a space group fd3m (a= 8.2476–2), a density of 4.2 g cm 3, the Li and Mn occupying the tetrahedral (8a), and octahedral (16d) sites in the intervening cubic array of oxygen atoms (32e sites). The spinel structure shows a high lithium extraction ratio of 0.6 (Li1 xMn2O4, 0 < x < 0.6) that provides a stable internal spinel structure and exhibits a theoretical capacity of 148 mAh.g 1 [74]. The three-dimensional (3D) crystal structure allows also the 3D lithium diffusion [173], the electronic conductivity is about 10 4 S cm 1 [185], and the Li1 xMn2O4 (0.27 < x < 1) active material can be cycled at about 4 V vs. lithium.
The main advantages of LiMn2O4 as a cathode in lithium batteries are the low-cost, low toxicity, and thermal stability. The extra lithiation (Li2Mn2O4) ensures a high amount of lithium-ion insertion/extraction in the structure. Therefore, the theoretical capacity of this cathode is doubled as the number of charge carrier (Li+) is also double, with respect to LiMn2O4.
MacNeil group reported that LiMn2O4, when compared with LiCoO2 and LiNiO2, shows higher thermal stability at high temperature, when in contact with the electrolyte. This property shows that spinel LiMn2O4 suits to high power batteries [140].
On the other hand, the main obstacle to its commercialization is due to the fact that spinel LiMn2O4 shows significant capacity fading during the cycling and storage processes. This capacity fading at room and high temperatures are due to two main reasons: (1) the manganese (Mn) dissolution into the electrolyte and (2) the JahnTeller instability caused by the ion Mn3+ at the octahedral sites [140]. Further, at high voltages (>4.3 V) and elevated temperatures (>55 C), the capacity fade also increases. Capacity degradation of this cathode is thus mainly originated by the dissolution of the Mn ions from the interface between cathode and electrolyte and its subsequent deposition on the anode surface that increases cell impedance [29].
The LiMn2O4 active material can be synthesized by different synthesis routes, such as spray drying [247], hydrothermal [36], coprecipitation [227], sol-gel [278],
and solid state [264], among others. Synthesis routes providing a fine particle size and uniform composition (such as sol-gel) lead to high electrochemical performance [265].
Efforts to overcome/improve the electrochemical problems and high-temperature performance include ion doping [93], reducing particle sizes [265], different morphologies [254], and metal oxide coating [29].
Yi et al. [265] synthesize spinel LiMn2O4 by adipic acid-assisted sol-gel and studied the influence of the synthesis temperature (350 C, 800 C, and 900 C) on phase formation and electrochemical activity (Fig. 3.4a–d). The results show that the samples calcinated at 800 C show better ordering of the local structure, higher crystallinity, and lower lattice strain. Thus, it is possible to control the particle size by controlling the sintering temperature, the samples synthesized at 800 C showing lower lattice defects, being the Mn chemical valence closer to 3.5.
Finally, nanoscale surface modifications have been investigated [29] (Fig. 3.4a). Xiao group [257] evaluated the effect of morphology (porous and hollow) of LiMn2O4, obtained by precipitation synthesis using manganese cobalt (MnCo3) (Fig. 3.4b) as template and manganese oxide (MnO2) as intermediate (Fig. 3.4c), in ion the electrochemical response of the cathode. It is concluded that the microspheres with a porous surface (Fig. 3.4e) exhibit a higher reversibility capacity and rate capability than the hollow surface sample (Fig. 3.4d). The current charge/ discharge of the porous structure deliver a reversible capacity of 117.2 mAh.g 1 at 1 A.g 1 and 92.1 mAh.g 1 at 10 A.g 1.

sections.heading: 3.1.2.4 Lithium Ferrous (II) Phosphate (LiFePO4)
sections.text:
Lithium ferrous (II) phosphate (LiFePO4, LFP) was first reported by Padhi’s group [187]. It is a member of the olivine family, crystalizes in the orthorhombic system with a Pnma [D2h] structure. Lithium ferrous (II) phosphate exhibits a distorted hexagonal close-packed oxygen framework with lithium and iron located in half the octahedral sites and phosphorous ions located in one-eighth of the tetrahedral sites. The interatomic distances are a = 10.332(4) Å, b = 6.010(5) Å, and c = 4.692(2) Å with a unit cell of 291.4(3) Å3 [81]. The bulk LiFePO4 exhibits paramagnetic (form induced magnetic fields in the direction opposite to that of the applied magnetic field) behavior at room temperature [234].
LFP has received a singular attention as cathode active material due to its ability to reach theoretical capacities of 170 mAh.g 1 at moderate current densities and not generating oxygen under conditions such as electric overcharging and shortening [97].
The electrochemical extraction of lithium from the LiFePO4 active material gives (Fe2+/Fe3+) redox potential at ca. 3.5 V vs. lithium, with reversible intercalation/ deintercalation of one lithium per each LiFePO4. This active material has excellent cycling performance, the cubic lattice volume and crystal parameters slightly varying in this process, the volume variation during the lithium-ion deintercalation decreasing by 6.81%, and the density increasing by 2.59%.
The advantages of this material are low-cost, iron abundance in nature, no memory effect, non-toxicity, resistance to overcharge, environmental friendliness, stable voltage plateau, and improved safety compared with cobalt oxides materials
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 113
[97]. Consequently, this active material is the first choice to use as a cathode in lithium batteries with medium-large capacity and medium-high power density.
Despite this, the intrinsically low electronic conductivity (10 7–10 9 S cm 1) and low diffusion coefficient of lithium ion (10 11–10 13 cm 2 s 1) of bulk LiFePO4 result in capacity losses during the high-rate discharge. Further, comparing the olivine structure with the spinel and layered ones, the olive structure is less dense, leading to a lower volumetric energy density. The theoretical density of LiFePO4 is just 3.6 g cm
3 which is low compared with other materials such as LiCoO2 (5.1 g cm
3) [97], but commercial LiFePO4 exhibits a density around 1.0–1.3 g cm
3, which shows that efforts should be taken to improve this material.
Different types of synthesis techniques were used to produce the LiFePO4 particles, including microwave [266], solid-state reaction [201], template method [137], sol-gel [294], coprecipitation [11], hydrothermal [230], and mechanical activation [236], among others.
In order to enhance the electronic conductivity, different strategies such as the addition of carbon, surface treatment with carbon layers, substitution or doping, and reduction of particle size have been used.
The carbon used on the surface of LiFePO4 should be thin and not exceeding a few wt.%, with a thickness of around 3 nm. With the surface treatment, the electronic conductivity of the active material could increase up to seven orders of magnitude. This carbon layer could be reached by the addition of organic materials as a carbon precursor and is limited to cathodes with low voltage response. In high voltage cathode materials, carbon will be electrochemically oxidized in the coating process and by the highly applied potential in the charging process [271]. The carbon coating (1) provides, after deintercalation, electron channels to balance the charge of active material; (2) increases the surface area of the active material due to the carbon nanometer sized by the production of fine LiFePO4; (3) avoids the production of Fe
3+; (4) prevents the polarization during the charge/discharge process; and (5) enhances the electronic conductivity [152, 233, 244].
Nanostructured LiFePO4 particles has been produced in order to overcome some issues such as (1) the decrease to nanosize reduces the distances for the (de)intercalation of lithium ions, decreasing the capacity fading at high current density; (2) the increase of the surface area can increase the theoretical capacity and Coulombic efficiency due to the higher lithium quantity adsorbed on the surface; (3) increases the redox reaction interface; (4) ensures a bigger electrolyte immersion, among others [244].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.5 Lithium Cobalt Phosphate (LiCoPO4)
sections.text:
Lithium cobalt phosphate (LiCoPO4) is one of the most stable active material used as cathode due to its intrinsic properties and unique olivine structure with the orthorhombic system (Pnma, Z= 8); lattice parameters a= 10.2048 Å, b= 5.9245 Å, and c = 4.7030 Å; and a density of 3.7 g cm 3. The redox potential of this material is 4.8 V vs. lithium and shows a flat voltage profile. With a theoretical capacity of 167 mAh.g 1, this active material also shows a small structural volume change [35].
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 115
This material has the advantage of exhibiting a high working potential compared with LiFePO4 and a larger theoretical performance compared with LiCoO2. On the other hand, the active material intrinsically exhibits poor rate capability, low lithiumion diffusion, and low electronic conductivity (<10 9 S cm 1) due to the one-dimensional ion transport channel. The poor cyclability of this material is due to the oxidation of cobalt (Co2+ to Co3+) and also by the decomposition of the carbonated electrolyte under charging between the 4.8 and 5.1 V. This reaction contributes to low Coulombic efficiency and capacity fading during cycling.
The Pnma-LiCoPO4 phase is the most explored by the scientific community, but two more metastable LiCoPO4 phases, Pna21 [C2V] and Cmcm [D2h] LiCoPO4, were discovered. These two phases, in contrast with Pnma [D2h], do not exhibit any significant electrochemical performance, but both exhibit interesting magnetic properties, showing complex magnetic interactions at low temperatures that should be explored [155].
Different methods were used to synthesize this active material and to obtain different electrochemical performances (Fig. 3.5), including coprecipitation, microwave, mechanochemical, hydrothermal, solid state [104], spray drying, and supercritical fluid, among others.
In order to form a stoichiometric LiCoPO4 without impurities, the precursor compounds used during the synthesis should have a strong Co-P bonding, preventing the formation of Co metal, lithium phosphate (Li3PO4), and cobalt oxide (Co3O4) phases [35]. Further, the synthesis performed in an argon atmosphere and carbon addition improves the conductivity of LiCoPO4 [242, 243].
To enhance the LiCoPO4 performance (increase electrical conductivity and rate capability), efforts in decreasing particle size [250], change morphology [156],
116 C. M. Costa et al.
carbon coating [251], and lattice doping with supervalent metals ions [116] have been made. In the Wang group approach [237], it was shown that the addition of vanadium (V) improves the electrical conductivity of the active material around 5.3 times. Through carbon coating, different factors, such as carbon source, thickness, homogeneity, and carbon content, influence the electrochemical performance.
The nanoflake morphology was investigated by Hou group [83] with the objective of enhancing the electrochemical performance of the LiCoPO4. The nanoflakes were coated with a thin carbon layer that orients the lithium-ion transport channels. With this treatment, the aggregation of particles is avoided improving the stability of the electrode material. The carbon coating was obtained by the carbonization of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (C6H6O3) and levoglucosan (C6H10O5, (1R,2S,3S,4R,5R)6,8-dioxabicyclo[3.2.1]octane-2,3,4-triol) that further inhibit the growth of (010) facets that create more exposed lithium-ion transport channels, also creating a conductive layer.

sections.heading: 3.1.2.6 Lithium Manganese Phosphates (LiMnPO4)
sections.text:
Lithium manganese phosphates (LiMnPO4) crystallize in an olivine structure with a density of 3.4 g cm 3, and, as all phospho-olivine structures, the oxygens ions are strongly bonded by covalent bonds with the phosphor (+5) to form the PO4 3+ tetrahedral polyanion stabilizing the framework. It exhibits an orthorhombic Pnma space group [D2h], and the typically crystallographic parameters are a= 6.106(1) Å, b = 10.452(1) Å, and c = 4.747(1) Å. With this structure stabilization, LiMnPO4 shows improved stability and safety for high operating voltage. Furthermore, manganese (Mn) and lithium (Li) occupy the octahedral 4c and 4a sites, and the P atoms occupy the 4c sites. Comparing with lithium-ion phosphate, LiMnPO4 draws the attention of the scientific community due to its higher theoretical energy density (171 mAh.g 1), higher operating voltage (4.1 V), and working within the stability window of the common nonaqueous electrolytes. Further, this cathode active material has advantages as low cost, environmentally friendlier nature, working ability at high temperatures, and non-toxicity [4].
When compared with LixFePO4, LixMnPO4 presents lower electrochemical performance. Furthermore, the LiMnPO4 active material exhibits low electronic conductivity (<10 10 S cm 1), relatively poor cycling stability (Jahn-Teller anisotropic lattice distortion and interface volume strain of 8.9%), and weak lithium diffusion.
In order to overcome these negative properties, different methods and synthesis routes were applied to improve these drawbacks by the manipulation of its morphology/structure [292], cation distribution [252], and electrochemical properties. Hydrothermal synthesis [63], precipitation methods [45], solid-state reaction [187], template methods [134], sol-gel synthesis [195], electrospinning followed by calcination [154], and solvothermal reaction [292], among others, were used to prepare this active material.
To enhance the low intrinsic electronic conductivity, methods such as decrease particle size, carbon coating, and cation doping were explored. The nanoparticle approach is commonly used because with this method it is possible to improve the power rate and rate capability of the LiMnPO4 battery due to the reduction of Li + and
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 117
electron length diffusion. The carbon coating on the LiMnPO4 surface enhances electronic conductivity by the reduction of particle agglomeration and by the formation of an effective conduction network between the layer and particle. Different carbon sources such as graphene and β-cyclodextrin (C42H70O35, Heptakis (hydroxymethyl)-tetradecaoxa-octa-cyclonona-tetracontane-tetradecol) were studied. The conductivity can be also improved by the doping with heterovalent and isovalent heteroatoms through the reduction of volume between the lithiation and delithiation phases. LiMnPO4 doping with transition metals is usually used because not only it increases its conductivity but also increases or maintains its capacity. Lu group [154] studied doped Mg-LiMnPO4 with fiber morphology (Fig. 3.6) and obtained a battery performance of 135 mAh.g 1 at a C/10 rate (15 mAh.g 1) that is superior to the one of LiMnPO4.
This sample shows a good cyclability without capacity fading during 200 cycles and the ability for being applied in flexible batteries. Li’s team [134] designed a 3D structure binder-free LiAlO2-LiMnPO4/C cathode material with improvement in the electrochemical performance when compared with LiMnPO4/C. The sample exhibits a capacity of 105 mAh.g 1 and 98.4% of capacity retention at a high discharge rate of 10 C, after 100 cycles. This structure can solve drawbacks such as the poor conduction of the active materials.

sections.heading: 3.1.2.7 Lithium Nickel Dioxide (LiNiO2)
sections.text:
This active material is very attractive for being used in lithium-ion batteries due to higher discharge capacity (~275 mAh.g 1), low cost [261], higher potential [55], and small variation of unit cell volume [183], and it is starting to be used in automotive application [270]. The cell volume varies from 101 to 98.5 Å3 in the composition range 0< x< 3/4 for Li1 xNiO2, which corresponds to about 2.5% shrinkage on oxidation [183]. The lithium-ion diffusion of LiNiO2 is higher when the temperature increases, and it is described by simple ion hopping with an activation energy of 0.6 eV [180]. Some disadvantages of this material are the low capacity retention and thermal stability
[289]. As for the other active materials, the morphology and particle size influence the cycling performance of LiNiO2 [213], smaller particles showing higher capacity, but larger particles providing higher thermal stability [121]. At room temperature, the electrical resistivity of this material is 4 Ω.cm 1 [163]. Due to the nickel (Ni) element, this active material shows magnetic properties [15], the antiferromagnetic phase (the magnetic moments related to the spins of electrons align in a regular pattern with neighboring spins pointing in opposite directions) increasing in contact with the ferrimagnetic (whose strength depends on that of the applied magnetizing field and which may persist after removal of the applied field) with nickel/lithium Ni/Li defect LiNiO2 due to increasing Li content [227]. Its electrochemical window, surface energy, and morphology were theoretically studied within the density functional theory (DFT) framework, and it was observed that tetragonal (t) Li-terminated surfaces are characterized by lower surface energies than those of the oxygen surfaces irrespective of facet direction. Further, Ni-exposed surfaces are the least stable [33]. Also, this theory was used for studying the effect of non-stoichiometry (extra-Ni-defects) on the electrochemical performance of Ni-rich layered oxides, and it was verified that extra-Ni-defects trigger a charge disproportionation reaction that reduces the Jahn-Teller distortion [114].
One simple synthesis of this structure is by heating a mixture of hydrated lithium hydroxide (LiOH.H2O) and nickel (II) hydroxide, Ni(OH)2 (Li/Ni = l.1/1 in molar ratio) in the range from 500 C to 900 C for 5 h in air or oxygen. It was observed that the structure prepared in an oxygen atmosphere at 700 C exhibits the highest discharge capacity of 200 mAh.g 1 in the voltage range from 3.0 to 4.3 V and the charge transfer resistance is related to the structural transformation of Lil xNiO2, 0.15< x< 0.75 [261]. Different lithium precursors have been used for obtaining this compound, lithium nitrate (LiNO3) [172, 176], LiOH.H2O [216], and Li2CO3 [232], as well as different synthesis methods, such as coprecipitation [205], emulsion [111], combustion [196], solid state [216, 218], and nanoscale MnCO3 treatment [282], among others.
In order to improve its thermal stability and consequently battery performance, different coatings with cobalt (Co) and manganese (Mn) [49], SiO2 [169], and vanadium (V) oxide (V2O5) [258] were carried out. The coating layer of Co, Mn particles improved the electrochemical properties of lithium nickel dioxide (LiNiO2) through decreasing the impedance growth at the interface between the electrodes/electrolyte during battery cycling [49]. It has been shown that silica (SiO2) coating at 2 wt.% leads to high structural stability and reversible capacity [169] and that a V2O5-coating layer works as hydrogen fluoride (HF) inhibitor and/or HF scavenger (from in situ precipitated cathode surface), which contributes to a significant improvement in cycling performance and storage characteristics in electrolyte [258].
Also for improving the electrochemical properties, this compound has been doped with iron [73], cobalt and manganese [178, 283], aluminum [149], and cerium [170]. Further, a novel inorganic nitrate salt synthesis was proposed [73].
The emulsion method has been used to synthesize this compound, and the optimal conditions for this synthesis were 750 C and 24 h in an oxygen stream, as represented in Fig. 3.7 [111].
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 119
Aluminum doping in LiNiO2 reduces lithium deficiency, stabilizes the crystal structure, and improves electrochemical cycling [149]. The doping of cerium leads to high Coulombic efficiency, high electrical conductivity, and low irreversible capacity loss [170].
Surface modification of LiNiO2 was also achieved by the addition of titania (TiO2) or zinc (II) oxide (ZnO), and it was observed a decrease in the discharge capacity but improved cycling performance [216].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.8 Lithium Nickel Cobalt Oxide [LiNi1 xCoxO2 (0.2 x 0.5)]
sections.text:
This active material results from the combination of lithium cobalt oxide (LiNiO2) and lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2), the addition of cobalt into LiNiO2 improving the thermal stability and cycling performance [46], as well as the delivered capacity, due to the stabilization of the structure with respect to LiCoO2 [119, 202]. Considering the enthalpy of formation of this active material, the cobalt compound is significantly more stable than the nickel analog [232]. The magnetic properties of this material have been studied indicating the existence of randomly oriented magnetic moments even at 2 K, i.e., a disordered state [177].
Different methods have been used for synthesizing these particles, such as sol-gel [60, 175], solid-state reaction [101], heat treatment [112], coprecipitation and rheological phase reaction [124], rheological phase reaction [235], and gel combustion [245], among others.
It was demonstrated that LiNi1 xCoxO2 (0.1 < x < 0.3) shows a low capacity fade rate when compared to that of LiCoO2, being suitable for commercial batteries [119].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.9 Lithium Nickel Manganese Cobalt Oxide (LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2)
sections.text:
Lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2) is a very promising active material as a cathode electrode, being used in electric vehicles applications [19] and semisolid flow batteries [90]. It shows higher capacity and tap density and better thermal stability, lower cost, less toxicity, and safety in comparison to other active materials [75]. Recently, it was demonstrated that it can be used also for anode electrodes [240]. The magnetic properties of the material were evaluated, and it was verified that both frustration and disorder play important roles in the formation of a spin glass state [18]. In order to investigate the changes in its crystal structure stability, calculations were carried out through the discrete variational (DV)-Xα molecular orbital method based on the self-consistent Hartree-FockSlater model compounds. Using known symmetries (C3v) the radial function for molecular orbitals of model cluster atoms method is used to compute the energies in the order of the transition metal layer affecting the charge/discharge cycle characteristics [103]. For this compound, Ni precipitates act a redox species and change from 4+ to 2+ during charging. Further, Ni4+ becomes Jahn-Teller active Ni3+ at intermediate states during charge and Mn [168]. The analysis with in situ Auger electron spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of this compound during charging and overcharging shows that Mn is redox active below ~4.3 Vand that O becomes redox active above ~4.2 V. Ni and Co also participate in surface redox [225]. Typically, the diffusion coefficient is in the range 10 11–10 12 cm2.s 1 [274].
The analysis of overpotentials in this active material shows that the characteristic overpotentials during charge (delithiation) and discharge (lithiation) are state of charge (SOC) and depth of discharge (DOD) dependent, respectively [105]. It was also demonstrated that the specific capacity fades during cycling at constant specific currents can be mainly attributed to the increase of the delithiation (charge) hindrance [106].
This active material presents poor electronic conductivity that affects its electrochemical performance, and, therefore, different approaches have been used to improve its electric and ionic conductivity, including adding graphene, which decreases the charge transfer resistance [231], developing composition between this active material and lithium phosphor sulfur (Li3PS4) [6], and co-coating [41] and coating with lithium boron oxide glass [52] and carbon nanotubes/graphene (CNT/G) [132].
In all-solid-state batteries, the interface between the active material and solid electrolyte is essential for obtaining high ionic conductivity, and this interface was studied for argyrodite (Li6PS5Cl), demonstrating that the oxidation processes of the solid electrolyte do not hinder the good cyclability of the battery [7].
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 121
Several experimental techniques have been used for synthesizing this compound such as redox synthesis [9], coprecipitation [18, 22, 80], solid-state reaction [40, 100], heating [62], pre-sintering [77], convenient rheological phase reaction [75, 191, 197], microwave pyrolysis [76], sol-gel [78], chemical vapor deposition [82], polyol medium [128], spray dry [123], using manganese (II) carbonate (MnCO3) both as a self-template and Mn source [126], acetic acid (C2H4O2) leaching and maleic acid (C4H4O4, cis-butenedioic acid) leaching [135], Pechini method [204], nitrate-melt decomposition [206], microwavemediated hydrothermal [212], high-temperature ball milling [228], hydrothermal [249], mechanochemical activation [260], combustion [268], sacrificial template [277], and combining coprecipitation with the hydrothermal method [284].
The preparation of this compound through the Pechini method allows reducing calcination times and minimal lithium evaporation [204].
In the combustion method, it was studied the effect of the addition of triethanolamine (TEA, C6H15NO3) in the synthesis, showing that synthesis with TEA exhibits lower polarization, better cycling ability, and significantly improved rate performance [268].
It has been shown that different carbonate precipitators affect its synthesis and consequently battery performance, the best discharge capacity value being obtained for sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) [198].
A new synthesis process based on the sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) coprecipitation method was developed for this active material. The obtained morphology and elemental distribution are shown in Fig. 3.8a [80]. It has been also shown that using Na2CO3 as a precipitant improves the electronic conductivity of the electrode, which contributes to improved rate capability [283]. Calcium carbonate (CaCO3) template was also used for the synthesis of this active material [276].
The chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method with sucrose as a source of carbon for the coating of this active material was developed, allowing better uniformity, higher quality, and better electrochemical performance in comparison to the thermal evaporation method [82].
Nanoplates of this active material with exposed [010] active facets were synthesized in a polyol medium (ethylene glycol, EG, C2H6O2), and these facets can lead to more channels for Li+-ion migration, resulting in an improvement in their electrochemical performance [128].
The impact of the different morphologies on the electrochemical performance was studied, in which highly dense materials exhibit the best power performances in terms of volumetric figures as shown in Fig. 3.8b [22].
xLi2MnO3.(1 x)LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 (x = 1/4, 1/3, and 1/2) hollow microspheres have been fabricated (Fig. 3.8c) with high specific capacity and capacity retention for x = 1/3 [129]. Further, xLi2MnO3.(1 x)LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 was also synthesized by the molten salt method, and, in this case, x = 0.4 presents better electrochemical performance [267].
Structural stability and consequently battery performance by reducing capacity fade have been improved by doping/modifying with different elements such as sodium (Na) [27, 67, 133] as illustrated in Fig. 3.8d, aluminum (Al) and iron (Fe) [142], silicon
122 C. M. Costa et al.
(Si) [179], phosphate (PO4) 3 [38], chromium(III) oxide (Cr2O3) [79], ZrO2 [85], lanthanum oxide (La2O3) [94, 224], alumina (Al2O3) [110, 190], titania (TiO2) [122], aluminum phosphate (AlPO4) [130], manganese oxide (MnOx) [258], lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4) [262], zirconia (ZrO2) [263], fluoroborate glass (MO–MF2–B2O3, where M = metal like Pb) [193], lithium titanium phosphate [LiTi2(PO4)3] [279], and europium (III) oxide (Eu2O3) [290] coatings. These different coatings also suppress the increase of charge transfer resistance (Rct). Improved performance has been also achieved in cathode composites of this active material with lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) [150], vanadium(V) oxide V2O5 to improve electrochemical
performance [162], lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4) to improve rate capability [181], lithium vanadate (LiVO3) [184], and polypyrrole (PPy, [C4H2NH)]n) [273].
Beyond improvements in the active material, scientific advances have been achieved in the electrode slurry by using water in its production. Thus, for this compound, γ-alumina (Al2O3) and silica (SiO2) significantly enhance the electrode performance of the water-based cathode [159] as well as new binders such as polyacrylic latex [286].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.10 Lithium Nickel Manganese Oxide (LiNi0.5Mn0.5O2)
sections.text:
Lithium nickel manganese oxide (LiNi0.5Mn0.5O2) shows a high theoretical capacity of 280 mAh.g 1, and it is also inexpensive and nontoxic and shows thermal stability and cycle life being a possible alternative to LiCoO2 [161]. It shows some disadvantages such as substantial Li/Ni disorder, poor intrinsic rate capability, and structural impurity [102]. The oxidation states of the transition metals in this active material are Mn4+ and Ni2+ in which their structure and unit cell are shown in Fig. 3.9 [44].
It has been observed on delithiation of Li1 xNi0.5Mn0.5O2 that Mn is electrochemically inactive and remains at Mn4+, whereas the Ni is oxidized from Ni2+ to almost Ni4+ through an intermediate stage of Ni3+ [44].
The relative energy positions and shape of the density of states of O2p and Ni3d have been investigated for this active material, and it was verified that O2p electrons are itinerant and exist in the vicinity of the Fermi energy more than Ni3d electrons [207].
The electrode/electrolyte interface of this active material was investigated, and after one electrochemical cycle, it demonstrated the strong influence of the variation of potential [53].
124 C. M. Costa et al.
Lithium nickel manganese oxide (LiNi0.5Mn0.5O2) has been synthesized by different methods such as solid solution [161], freeze drying [214], in situ conversion route [148], coprecipitation [51] [208], combination of hydroxide and molten salt methods [92], wet chemical [222], solid-state reaction [246], hydrothermal method [281], and ultrasonic irradiation in coprecipitation method [272].
For the coprecipitation method, a morphology composed of hexagonal cubes was obtained, which improves the electrochemical performance [51].
The synthesis of this active material through ball milling was proposed, leading to materials with very small capacity fading [253]. This structure was doped with fluorine (F) element to reduce cation mixing and improve the poor rate performance [86]. The same was observed by ruthenium (Ru) doping of LiNi0.5Mn0.5O2 [222].
Composites of LiNi0.5Mn0.5O2 with lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2) and lithium manganese oxide (Li2MnO3) were prepared by spray drying in which the discharge capacity increases with increasing cobalt (Co) content [219]. Similarly, a composite cathode with lithium manganese alumina (LiMn1.9Al0.1O4) was developed, leading to the improvement in the electrochemical performance through structural stabilization [229].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.11 Lithium Vanadium Oxide (LiV2O5)
sections.text:
Lithium vanadium oxide (LiV2O5) has the advantages of higher energy density (~450 Wh.kg 1) [47], long cycle, and low environmental impact, but it has as a disadvantage a high capacity fading resulting from structural modifications [10]. Their structure was reported to be the space group Pna21 [C2V] but refined in Pn21a where the Li atom has a crude octahedral coordination with one distance [to 0 (6)] considerably lower than the others [2].
The electronic properties of α-LixV2O5 (x= 0.5 and 1) were investigated through density functional theory (DFT) in which the intercalation of Li into V2O5 does not change the electron transition property of V2O5, which is an indirect band gap semiconductor [120].
The ω-phase of LiV2O5 consists in the stability of its tetragonal structure (ΔV/ V < 1%) as the Li insertion/extraction proceeds and, at a higher rate above of C/5, the capacity decreases through a significant dissolution process of the vanadium oxide, leading to the presence of V4+ and V3+ species in the electrolyte [118].
Through NMR spectra of the fully discharged LixV2O5 cathode, it is observed a changing of V ion from V+5 to V+4. The lithium intercalated LixV2O5 system has been studied using ab initio calculations in which different phases were obtained during the reaction ((omega) ω- Li3V2O5 and (zeta) ζ-Li2V2O5) [199]. For intercalation amounts larger than one, the (delta) δ-phase is transformed into a (gamma) γ-one via an irreversible reconstruction mechanism [48].
The lithium insertion/extraction of this active material in the 4–2.15 V potential range was analyzed through Raman micro-spectrometry, being detected the emergence of various LixV2O5 phases in the wide Li composition range 0 < x < 2 [10].
This electrode was prepared using the plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) technique in which the optimized substrate temperature and radiofrequency (RF) power are 250 C and 50 W, respectively [141].
3 Advances in Cathode Nanomaterials for Lithium-Ion Batteries 125
The carbothermal reduction method was used for synthesizing this active material that demonstrated a high reversible specific capacity of 130 mAh.g 1 [14].
Further, this active material was synthesized by the sol-gel method; it shows nanostructure and is capable of reversible cycling [23].
(gamma) γ-LiV2O5 was synthesized via a simple solvothermal method and exhibits a better electrochemical performance [127].
Three-layered Al2O3/LixV2O5/LiV3O8 was prepared, and the LixV2O5 middle layer contributes to the improvement of interfacial electrochemical properties of the hybrid electrode [221].

sections.heading: 3.1.2.12 LiV3O8
sections.text:
Lithium vanadium(V) oxide (LiV3O8) is an active material very interesting for rechargeable batteries considering its high specific energy, long cycle, and low cost [238]. In addition to its properties and application as cathodic material, it has been also investigated for the anode, but with low capacity value [113].
Its specific capacity of about 280 mAh.g 1 has been achieved corresponding to the reversible intercalation of three equivalents of Li per mol Li1+xV3O8 [157].
The atomic structures and the phase transition for Li1 xV3O8 were calculated through the local density functional theory as a function of lithiation and the structure of 1 + x = 1.2 and 1 + x = 4 coincide with the predicted low-energy configurations [16]. Its lithium insertion kinetics was affected largely by the small diffusivity of Li+ in the Li4V3O8 phase formed for x > 1.5 upon lithiation [109].
The diffusion coefficient for this active material is relatively low (~10 12–10 13 cm2 s 1), and it is observed that it decreases with the intercalation of Li+, which slows down the mobility of the Li+ ion [20]. During the first lithium electrochemical insertion/extraction process in the electrode surface, it is observed the formation of LiF as well as compounds containing phosphorus originated by solid electrolyte interface (SEI) formation [34, 37].
The effect of oxygen defects in the structure has been analyzed and it has been observed the formation of new sites available for the occupation of Li+ ions [108].
Their final properties of the active material depend on the conditions and methods of synthesis, which include sol-gel (citric acid, C6H8O7, and (hydrogen) peroxide, H2O2) [57, 238], solution reaction [54], solid state [57], hydrothermal [57, 144], aqueous precipitation [57], mechanochemical [115], microwave [248], soft chemical via a low-temperature heating process [58], spray pyrolysis [96], and solid-state routine with quenching in freezing atmosphere [147].
The influence of the synthesis method on its electrochemical performance was evaluated, and it has been verified that the active material produced from the sol-gel citric acid method and the aqueous precipitation route presents excellent results [57].
The polymer polyvinylpyrrolidone was used in the polymer precursor method for synthesizing this active material, leading to good cycling stability [203]. Another polymer such as polyethylene glycol (PEG, C2nH4n+2On+1) was used in its synthesis [220].
The obtained morphologies are nanobelts (Fig. 3.10a) [70], nanorods [287], spheres [96] (Fig. 3.10b), and flake like [58].

It has been demonstrated that the nanorod morphology with high crystallinity greatly improves the stability of the crystallographic structure during cycling [146].
For improving electrical conductivity and cycling performance, this compound was doped of with manganese [107], molybdenum (Mo) [217], chromium [59], chlorine
[125], and titanium [99] and prepared in composites with polypyrrole [ ] [56],

sections.heading: In this chapter, the main promising cathode active materials were presented and their main properties analyzed. Different kinds of materials are used as a cathode material, and some of them are already commercialized. A variety of active materials with a
sections.text:
high range of specific capacities can be used on lithium-ion batteries for a different application. Different synthesis routes have been used to fabricate these materials including hydrothermal, sol-gel, precipitation, solid-state method, mechanochemical, microwave, soft chemical via a low-temperature heating process, and spray pyrolysis, among others. For each synthesis procedure, it is possible to control one or more specific particle properties and therefore reaching a better and improved cathode material. It is also possible to state that nanosize and carbon coating has a crucial importance in the electrochemical performance. Another possible treatment is doping of the active material, allowing to overcome some intrinsic drawbacks of the pure active materials.

Abstract Along with the state-of-the-art lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries approaching their limitation in specific energy density, “beyond Li-ion” battery technologies have become alternative energy storage solutions due to their higher specific energy density. Among them, rechargeable lithium metal battery (LMB) has been considered as one of the most promising battery technologies that promises a great increase in energy density. Among the known anode materials, the Li metal has some unique and attractive features, such as an ultrahigh theoretical capacity (3,860 mAh g 1), a lowest negative electrochemical potential ( 3.04 vs SHE), and a low gravimetric density (0.534 g cm 1). Therefore, Li metal has rendered as

1 for Li-S batteries) with a great reduction in battery cost due to the high abundance and broad distribution of O2 and S sources. However, the use of Li metal anode in LMBs still causes some critical issues, including the well-known Li dendritic growth, uncontrolled interfacial reactions with electrolytes, and large volumetric change during Li plating/ stripping process. The “short circuit” of the battery by dendrite formation and the continuous depletion of electrolytes/active bulk lithium have been significantly challenging the practical application of rechargeable LMBs. In this chapter, we will discuss the fundamental challenges for both Li anode and cathodes and the proposed strategies for rechargeable LMBs. A perspective on the future research direction is also presented to initiate more helpful thoughts and promote to solve the critical issues in this research field.

sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction
sections.text:
The growing markets for portable electronics, electric vehicles, and stationary energy storage systems have already triggered a rapid increase in the ever-changing demands for energy storage devices [1, 2]. Among various energy storage systems, rechargeable lithium (Li)-ion batteries (LIBs), as one of the most promising power sources, have successfully revolutionized communications and the transportation style of our modern life, driving mobile phones/laptops, and more recently electric vehicles [3, 4]. However, the state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries using graphite anodes with a low theoretical specific capacity of 372 mAh g 1 have almost reached their theoretical specific energy density ( 350 Wh kg 1), which still cannot satisfy the fast-growing requirement of the higher-energy-density batteries for wide applications, particularly long-lasting electric vehicles.
To address the low capacity issue of an aforementioned graphite anode, researchers around the world have been conducting extensive research on exploring alternative anodes for LIBs, such as silicon [5–8], oxides [9–14], sulfides [15–17], etc. Unfortunately, many issues existing in those reported anodes are as follows: (a) excess volume change during battery cycling, (b) high working voltage plateau, and (c) complicated material synthesis steps and high cost, which cause low practical energy density of Li-ion batteries based on above anodes. Besides, Li metal has been highly considered as one of most ideal anode candidates due to its ultrahigh theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g 1), lowest negative electrochemical potential ( 3.040 V versus standard hydrogen electrode), and lightweight (0.534 g cm 3) [18, 19]. In particular, Li metal batteries (LMBs) have recently become one of the most promising alternatives for future high-energy battery technologies when further development of low-capacity LIBs used currently has been in dilemma. The combination of high-capacity oxygen (O2) or sulfur
148 B. Liu and H. Pan
(S) cathode with the Li metal anode attracted intensive interest from the worldwide research community due to their high theoretical energy compared with the traditional LIBs, e.g., 3505 Wh kg 1 for Li-O2 and 2600 Wh kg
1 for Li-S batteries. Further, Fig. 4.1 represents a clear comparison of specific energy densities among different battery systems including Li-air battery, Li-S battery, zinc (Zn)-air battery, advanced Li-ion battery, the existing Li-ion battery, and nickel metal hydride (Ni-MH) battery [20]. Although the estimation of practical energy densities of energy storage devices is complicated, the specific energy values of different battery chemistries clearly map the development perspective of high-energy-density batteries in the future.
Back to the development history of LMBs, the non-rechargeable lithium metal battery (LMBs) was first applied in digital watches, calculators, and medical devices by Exxon in the 1970s [21]. However, such a primary lithium-metal battery inevitably resulted in high cost and environmental pollution. To solve these issues, Moli Energy developed the first commercial rechargeable lithium metal battery (LMBs) through using molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) cathode and excess Li anode in the later 1980s, but it presented a serious safety risk because of the short circuit induced by lithium dendrite growth, thermal runaway, and potential explosion hazards. Thus all of the lithium-metal packs were recalled in 1989. Nippon Denki Kabushiki Gaisha (NEC) and Tadiran (a merge of Tadi Batteries and Ran, today controlled by Saft
4 Rechargeable Lithium Metal Batteries 149
Groupe SA) tried to improve the battery design later but with limited success, whereas very few companies are able to realize rechargeable LMBs. Herein, safety concerns hindered the opportunity of the further commercialization of LMBs at that time. Over the last 40 years, LMBs have been extensively investigated to eliminate safety concern of LMBs.
In this chapter, we first present an overview of Li-metal batteries, and then summarize issues/challenges and recently proposed strategies to develop Li metal anodes and promising cathodes in LMBs. Finally, a general summary and some perspectives for Li metal battery chemistry will be provided. We aim to provide a schematic of the fundamentals of lithium metal battery (LMBs), illustrate key progress in LMBs, and give an inspiration for future developments of nextgeneration Li-metal battery technology.

sections.heading: 4.2 Li Metal Anode
sections.text: Lithium is the lightest one in the alkali metal group and has the smallest atomic radius of all metals. These characteristics enable Li metal with ultrahigh specific capacity and quick Li+ ion transfer. Li metal anode with an extremely high capacity of 3860 mAh g 1 has the most negative potential of all the currently known electrode materials, which enables high discharge voltage and high-energy density in LMBs. However, there are two main barriers facing LMBs. One is the growth of Li dendrites during repeated plating/stripping processes, and the other is low Coulombic efficiency (CE) of these processes. These two critical issues for Li metal anode cause the safety hazard: internal short circuits led by dendrites and limited cycle life of the batteries due to irreversible and continuous reactions between Li and electrolytes that generate thick solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layers on the Li metal surface, consume Li and electrolyte, as well as increase the internal resistance. Thus it’s extremely necessary to clearly understand and consider Li dendrites and related issues.

sections.heading: 4.2.1.1 Li Dendrite Nucleation
sections.text:
Lithium metal can be plated and stripped repeatedly during the charge/discharge processes of LMBs. During Li deposition, i.e., charge process of LMBs, the initial nucleation sites on Li metal surface will be a dominant factor for governing subsequent Li deposition. Li metal thermodynamically easily grows dendritic morphology during such a Li deposition process. In contrast, some multivalent ion metal such as magnesium (Mg) tends to be dendrite-free with two (2D) – and three-dimensional (3D) morphology rather than one-dimensional (1D) dendritic morphology. This is because that Mg has a higher free energy difference between high-dimensional and low-dimensional phases than Li [3, 22, 23]. In addition, the surface diffusion of the Mg2+ ion on Mg anode surface is obviously faster than
150 B. Liu and H. Pan
that on Li or Na surface, which makes Mg metal deposit toward the surrounding sites instead of on some lumped area to grow undesirable dendrites. Overall, in terms of thermodynamic view, both lower surface energy and higher migration energy of Li metal primarily contribute to dendrite formation during Li metal deposition.
During the initial stage of Li-ion plating process, the nucleation models can be mainly classified as follows: (1) heterogeneous nucleation model [24, 25], (2) space-charge model [26], and (3) SEI-induced nucleation model [27]. Li nucleation occurrence on the alien current collectors is identified as a heterogeneous nucleation behavior. As demonstrated by Cui’s group, such a heterogeneous nucleation is demonstrated by the selective deposition of Li on the gold (Au) substrates rather than copper (Cu, Fig. 4.2) [25]. In addition, Chazalviel reported a space-charge model for Li dendrite nucleation [26]. Briefly, during Li-ion deposition at high rates, the concentration of anions in dilute electrolyte decreases near the electrode surface, which leads to the establishment of a very large space charge an electric field near the electrolyte/electrode interface. This facilitates a subsequent ramified growth of Li [26]. Furthermore, Li metal is thermodynamically unstable with an organic solvent; thus both can react to form solid-electrolyte interphase on Li metal anode [28]. This SEI layer will continuously break down and re-form during Li deposition/stripping processes, further promoting dendritic Li growth. However, most models in the reported literature do not focus on the effect of the SEI on the Li dendrite growth mechanisms. So, this can be classified as an SEI-induced nucleating model. The Sacci’s group revealed direct visualization of SEI formation during lithium deposition using in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) [27]. It can be seen that the dark dashed curve indicates the gradual formation of SEI, prior to Li deposition process, as shown in Fig. 4.3. Nevertheless, the actual formation sequence of SEI formation and Li deposition process would be immediately varied by changing electrolytes in a practical condition.
4 Rechargeable Lithium Metal Batteries 151

sections.heading: 4.2.1.2 Li Dendrite Growth
sections.text:
After nucleation of initial-stage Li dendrite growth, Li continues to grow into large deposits. Li dendrite growth is mainly determined by the electronic field, the electrolyte concentration, and properties of SEI films [29, 30]. According to previously reported results, morphologies of Li dendrites mainly contain needlelike, mosslike, treelike structures [31–33]. Needlelike one-dimensional dendrites without numerous branches hold the most threat to cause the short circuit in LMBs. So far, extensive efforts have been made to characterize and analyze the formation and growth steps of Li dendrites by using different characterization methods, including scanning electron microscopy (SEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), optical microscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) [34–39]. For example, Mehdi et al. directly observed real-time SEI formation and Li dendrite growth evolution at Li anode/ electrolyte interface during the first three charge-discharge cycles (Fig. 4.4) [40].
Also, some inactive “dead” Li residues detach from the platinum (Pt) electrode after Li stripping process, and it’s one of the main reasons for the low Coulombic efficiency (CE) in rechargeable LMBs. In recent work [41], an operando observation of the Li electrode surface were time-synchronized with the corresponding potential traces of the designed cell in 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate solution (LiPF6) in ethylene carbonate and dimethyl carbonate (EC, C3H4O3/DMC, (CH3O)2CO) electrolyte in the first three half-cycles from an even larger electrode area scale (Fig. 4.5). The formation/dissolution of new lithium was entangled with the formation of “dead” lithium during repeated cycles across the whole electrode surface. This causes a continuous displacing of “dead” lithium in the electrode and the consequent uncontrollable growth of Li upon cycling.
Some considerable external influences (i.e., current density, pressure, and temperature) on the Li dendrite growth behaviors have been investigated as well. An early work has revealed the influence of the current density and Li plating capacity on the dendrite formation on Li electrode [42]. It has been found that the total amount of discharge capacity enabling no dendrite formation increases with increasing current density up to 1 mA cm 2 and then decreases with further increasing current density, less than 2 mA cm 2 (Fig. 4.6). An optimal condition of a current rate of 1 mA cm 2 with a total amount of discharge of 12 C cm 2 for Li metal deposition was found to prevent the heterogeneous Li dendrite growth. In addition, the external pressure applied on lithium metal battery (LMBs) will have an immediate and partial suppression of Li dendrite growth occurred on Li metal anode. This critical role of pressure particularly in lithium metal battery (LMB) should arouse more attention. Li-ion diffusion, electrolyte viscosity, and reaction kinetics on Li metal are associated with temperature. Akolkar reported modeling dendrite growth during lithium electrodeposition at a sub-ambient temperature, giving a good guideline to define the lowest temperature for safe operation of Li-metal batteries [44]. A key temperature region required to suppress dendrite formation under different current densities were suggested in Fig. 4.7. The red curve indicates a critical temperature. Below the critical temperature, uncontrolled dendrite growth was initiated, while the blue one shows a much lower dendrite growth rate ratio. The region above the blue curve can be identified as the region for suppression of dendrite growth and stable operation of batteries.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Low Coulombic Efficiency Issue
sections.text:
The high reactivity of Li metal results in the parasitic reactions with almost all liquid electrolytes, even with a solid polymer or ceramic solid electrolytes. Those reactions are generally hard to control, which continuously consumes both electrolyte and Li metal, leading to low Coulombic efficiency (CE) during LMBs. The aforementioned Li dendrite problem could intensify the low CE issue of Li metal due to the increased exposed surface area of Li to the electrolytes. Effective methods are required to minimize the side reactions between the electrolyte and Li metal to address the above issue.
156 B. Liu and H. Pan

sections.heading: 4.2.2.1 Evaluation of CE of Lithium Plating/Stripping
sections.text:
In most literature, different calculation methods of CE often result in different values of CE. In addition, CE is dependent on cycling conditions (i.e., current density, temperature, cycling time, and aging). Thus, the value of the CE for a given electrolyte could be misleading and not comparable if the calculation of CE is not associated with detailed testing conditions [28]. Here, four kinds of evaluation methods of CE for Li plating/stripping processes are listed below:
Method 1: CE of Li is calculated through:
CE ¼ QS QD
(4:1)
where QS and QD are charged for Li stripping and plating determined for each cycle. This method is first defined by Aurbach in 1999 [45], which is applicable when Li is deposited on the inert electrode surfaces, such as nickel (Ni), copper (Cu), and tungsten (W).
Method 2: CE of Li metal is calculated through [46]
CE ¼ nQC nQC þ QD
(4:2)
where n denotes the total deposition/stripping times, QD is for originally known amount of deposition charge for Li metal on the working electrodes (Ni or Cu), QD is usually determined by the thickness and density of Li metal electrode, and QC is a fraction of charge cycled across the cell in order to advance lithium striping-deposition cycles. The stripping overpotential is monitored upon cycling. Above process will be completed once the anodic overpotential reaches more than 100 mV.
Method 3: Moreover, some literature also used a figure-of-merit (FOM) value rather than CE. For example [47],
FOMLi ¼ nQDQT ¼ 1 1 CE (4:3)
where nQD is the total accumulated cell capacity, while QT is the theoretical Li capacity or Li turnover number.
Method 4: Besides the above methods, Zhang’s group developed more reliable methods for measuring CE to precisely quantify the amount of Li consumed during cycling and estimate the cycle life of LMBs [48]. In this method, a given amount of charge (QT) is used to deposit Li on the copper (Cu) as a Li reservoir,
4 Rechargeable Lithium Metal Batteries 157
then a smaller portion of the charge (QC) is used to cycle Li for n cycles (Fig. 4.8). After n cycles, a final exhaustive stripping process, corresponding to the stripping charge (QS), is conducted to completely remove all of Li residues on Cu. So, the average CE (CEavg) can be calculated below:
CEavg ¼ nQC þ QSnQC þ QT (4:4)
The advantage of this method is to minimize the effects of Cu current collector because Li plating/stripping occurs on Li metal substrate rather than the external substrate in a practical LMB [48].

sections.heading: 4.2.2.2 Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Li Metal Surface
sections.text:
The formation of complicated solid electrolyte interphase through the reaction between Li and electrolytes was first found by Dey in 1970 [49], then named as solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film by Peled in 1979 [50]. Basically, any electrolytes can be reduced at the Li metal surface due to the highly negative
