sections.heading: 9.1 Introduction and Background
sections.text:
The rapid depletion of fossil fuel resources and global climate changes are pushing forward the development of sustainable clean energy technologies such as advanced batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, and solar cells. Among this energy storage and conversion devices, advanced batteries are playing a significant role in human’s life. In particular, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have currently been reigning over the market for portable energy storage devices including laptops, digital cameras, mobile phones, and even more electric vehicles or grid-level stationary energy storage systems (ESSs) [1–3]. However, LIBs face the challenge of lithium shortage (Table 9.1) as a result of its abundance of only 0.0017 wt % in the Earth’s crust [4], uneven distribution, and the high extraction cost, which hamper the applications of LIBs for storage purposes. For this reason, it is highly urgent to search for alternative energy storage technologies with earth-abundant materials, low cost, high energy, and a long cycle life for large-scale energy storage applications.
The concerns over lithium scarcity have prompted researchers to focus on the alternative sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) system. Sodium, next to lithium in the alkali metal series, not only is more abundant (2.36 wt %) [4] and easily accessible but also possesses similar chemical properties to lithium. Based on the above advantages, SIBs have been extensively investigated [5–8]. However, the larger radius of sodium (Na+, 1.02 Å), compared with that of Li+ (0.76 Å), brings about great challenges in the development of SIBs. Research into the anode material of SIBs shows that sodium ions struggle to reversibly intercalate into graphite, thereby resulting in poor capacities [7, 9, 10]. In addition, the relatively high standard redox potential of Na+/Na ( 2.71 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode, SHE) leads to a lower working voltage in contrast to that of Li+/Li ( 3.04 V vs. SHE) [11] and lower energy density than Li-ion.
Currently, potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) have emerged as another prospective energy storage system with the ever-increasing demand for renewable resources [12–15]. Analogous to sodium, potassium is a relatively plentiful element in the Earth’s crust (2.09 wt%) [4], which can be refined with far lower cost than lithium. More importantly, potassium (K) has a relatively lower standard redox potential ( 2.93 V vs. SHE) than Na ( 2.71 V vs. SHE), suggesting a broader electrochemical operation voltage window of PIBs and thereby providing more energy. Although potassium ion has an even larger radius (1.38 Å) than that of Na+ and lithium (Li+), K+ as charge carrier has been proven to be viable. It’s more encouraging that K+ can intercalate/deintercalate into graphite layer reversibly, with an impressive capacity of more than 200 mAh g 1 [12, 16]. Furthermore, Okoshi et al. [17] revealed that K
348 X. Qi et al.
electrolytes display higher conductivity than Li and Na electrolytes. They proposed the higher conductivity be ascribed to the smaller Stokes radius of solvated K+ owing to its weak Lewis acidity and the small interfacial reaction resistance originating from the lower desolvation activation energy [17]. Early studies have demonstrated higher K+ conductivity in both aqueous and nonaqueous electrolytes [18, 19]. Potassium carriers have been widely adopted in aqueous batteries [20, 21]. In organic electrolytes, such as ethylene carbonate (EC), diethyl carbonate (DEC) solvents, K+ also show a higher ionic conductivity than Li+ and Na+. Considering these advantages, PIBs have rapidly attracted tremendous interest and gradually become a strong competitor to SIBs and even LIBs, and then varieties of materials have been developed and utilized as potential PIB electrodes.
In this new battery technology’s very incipient stage, the research attention should be focused on potentially scalable, industrially and economically attractive, inexpensive electrode materials and the understanding of their cycle-life-property correlations. Therefore, it is the materials scientist’s responsibility to develop novel, highperformance, and sustainable materials to cope with the challenge of providing renewable energy for large-scale energy conversion and storage devices while limiting environmental effects. Carbon-based materials are considered to be one of the most versatile materials for negative electrodes of the energy storage devices owing to their low cost, abundant sources, good chemical stability, high electrical conductivity, and environmental benignity [22, 23]. In particular, chemical stability at a wide temperature range whether in acidic or basic solution prompts carbon materials exceedingly attractive as electrodes in electrochemical energy devices. What’s more, the significance and potential of carbon-based materials have been acknowledged by some of the highest scientific field awards such as the 1996 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (fullerenes), the 2008 Kavli Prize in Nanoscience (carbon nanotubes), and the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics (graphene) [23]. As a result, interest in carbon-based materials and their applications is experiencing its most unprecedented development in modern materials science.
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 349
In this chapter, recent progress in carbon-based materials as anode materials of emerging nonaqueous PIBs is summarized. The class of materials is diverse and consists of graphite, graphene, hard carbon, carbon-based composites, and other carbon nanomaterials. The challenges and future research opportunities for nonaqueous PIBs are also briefly discussed.

sections.heading: 9.2 Carbon-BasedMaterials for Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode
sections.text: Anode materials are a critical component of alkali metal-ion batteries. The failure of the commercialized Li battery launched in the 1980s was induced by Li metal anode, mainly resulting from the dendrite formation related to security issues in the process of charge and discharge [24]. Carbon-based materials have gradually attracted researchers’ considerable interest due to its unique structure and outstanding physiochemical properties. In this section, the research on carbon-based-negative electrode materials for PIBs will be divided into four parts to be discussed in detail.

sections.heading: 9.2.1 Graphite
sections.text:
Among all host structures, graphite has been regarded as quite remarkable. The success of the current rechargeable LIBs is mainly ascribed to the substitute of graphite for metallic Li anode, where lithium graphite (space group P63mc) intercalation compounds (GICs) can form rather than Li plating/stripping, thereby effectively avoiding dendritic lithium and offering a safe operating environment. Nowadays, graphite has been employed almost exclusively in commercialized LIBs owing to its excellent overall properties. Nevertheless, a major obstacle for the development of SIBs is that sodium can’t intercalate reversibly into graphite [25]. These phenomena are mainly related with sodium plating on the graphite surface before forming a stage I GIC [26], which has proven that sodium carbide (NaC6), the only graphite intercalation compound, was not energetically favorable from a thermodynamic perspective [27]. However, K-graphite intercalated compounds (K-GICs) have been reported in the literature in the middle of the twentieth century [28]. Potassium-graphite intercalated compounds were prepared through a non-electrochemical two-zone vapor synthesis technique or alkali metal solvation method. The vapor phase synthesis technique dates from the 1960s, which contains the heating of graphite and intercalant (Li, Na, K, etc.) in two different vessels [28]. The authors also discussed the phase transformation sequence of potassium carbide KC36–(stage III)–KC24(stage II)–KC8 (stage I) in the vapor pressure experiments. Furthermore, the energetics of alkali metal (Li, Na, and K) intercalation in graphite was compared by density functional theory (DFT) using van der Waals (vdW) density functionals [29]. Figure 9.1 demonstrates that the intercalation of Na is indeed energetically unfavorable, different from that of Li. More impressively, K intercalation is even more advantageous than that of Li. Their formation enthalpies
350 X. Qi et al.
for KC8 and LiC6 are 27.5 and 16.4 kJ mol 1, respectively. These have laid a solid theoretical foundation for future research of K ion insertion into graphite even other carbon materials.
Wang and coworkers for the first time investigated reversible (de)intercalation of K+ ions into/from amorphous carbon nanofibers in 2014 [30]. The carbon nanofiber (CNF) electrode produces a first discharge capacity of 680 mA h g 1 and depotassiation capacity of about 300 mAh g 1 at a rate of 50 mAg 1. However, the specific capacity decreases to 200 mAh g 1 on the second cycle and gradually stabilizes at about 80 mAh g 1 after the 20th cycle [30], implying relatively poor cycling performance.
Jian et al. [12] reported ambient-temperature electrochemical potassium (de)intercalation into graphite with a nonaqueous electrolyte of 0.8 M KPF6 solvated in ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC). The graphite electrode presented a surprisingly high reversible depotassiation capacity of 273 mA h g 1 at C/40 (1C= 279 mAh g 1, calculated using the molecular weight of KC8 as the most potassiated phase), rather approximate to its theoretical capacity of 279 mAh g 1, the excellent performance makes graphite a potential anode material for PIBs. The K/graphite cell also produced capacities of 263, 234, 172, and 80 mA h g 1 at current densities of C/10, C/5, C/2, and 1C [12]. As a result, although graphite can display a large capacity at low current rates, its capacity fades dramatically upon higher current rates. This implies an alternative negative electrode material might be conducive to high-rate applications. Ex situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were also carried out to understand the structural evolution of K intercalation and the potassium storage mechanism. As shown in Fig. 9.2, the formation of several stages of K-GICs was observed. Stage III KC36, stage II KC24, and stage I KC8 were detected in a sequence upon potassiation similar to the crystallization of the phases prepared by the two-zone vapor technique [28], while depotassiation recovers from graphite through phase transformations in an opposite sequence.
However, a recent study in a K/graphite half-cell proposes an unusual potassium intercalation mechanism [16]. This study coupled electrochemical measurements with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. They claim that while the intercalation occurs in three stages, the formation of stage III KC24, followed by stage II KC16, and stage I KC8 is energetically more stable than the previously proposed KC36 (stage III) to KC24 (stage II) to KC8 (stage I). Therefore, the mechanism of potassium insertion closely resembles that of lithium [16]. In order to clearly understand how the potassium intercalates into graphite, further research is urgently required.
The major challenge graphite faced with is the large volumetric change (60%) in the process of potassiation/depotassiation, which leads to fast capacity loss and low initial Coulombic efficiencies. Researchers have started to make efforts to choose different binders and electrolytes to alleviate the volume change to some degree. Komaba et al. [18] investigated the effect of different binders on electrochemical performance, including polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, [(C2H2F2)n]), sodium carboxymethylcellulose (CMCNa, [(C2H15NaO2)n]), and sodium polyacrylate (PANa, [(C3H3NaO2)n]) for their graphite/K half-cells. As observed in Fig. 9.3, the use of
352 X. Qi et al.
different binders causes dramatic differences in the electrochemical performance. It was revealed that higher initial Coulombic efficiencies were observed in the latter two binders for the graphite PIBs anodes compared to the PVDF binder [18]. This result was ascribed to the preformed solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) effect of the binders PANa and CMCNa; thus, less potassium is consumed for the formation of SEI layer in the first discharge cycle of the PIBs.
In addition, Zhao et al. [31] have shown the critical effects of electrolytes on the electrochemical performance of graphite in PIBs. The authors investigated three kinds of electrolytes of 1 M potassium hexafluorophosphate (KPF6) in ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate (EC:PC), EC/diethyl carbonate (EC:DEC), and EC/dimethyl carbonate (EC:DMC), respectively. As observed by the charge/discharge voltage profiles, graphite displayed similar reversible capacity of about 240 mAhg 1 in the first three cycles. Nevertheless, the Coulombic efficiency and cycling stability for the three electrolytes present significant difference. It was found
that EC:DEC (used in most PIBs literature) and EC:PC worked well with the graphite anode in comparison to EC:DMC. What’s worth mentioning is that EC: PC obtained the highest Coulombic efficiency in the first cycle among graphite in the other two electrolytes. It may arise from more severe decomposition of DEC and DMC that are not stable at a low potential.
To conclude, graphite is a viable and promising candidate as an anode material in PIBs. The higher average potential for K insertion into graphite as compared with Li can reduce the risk of metal plating. Even so, a more in-depth research of the material is still fairly desired so as to achieve the efficiency required from commercial batteries.

sections.heading: 9.2.2 Graphene
sections.text:
While research shows some promising results with graphite for negative electrodes in PIBs, other carbon materials are still needed to be explored as alternatives due to the large volume change of graphite during the cycling process. Thus, some studies have started focusing on other carbonaceous negative electrode materials.
Graphene (space group P6/mmm) is composed of a monolayer of carbon atoms sp2 bonded into a hexagonal or honeycomb lattice sheet, which was experimentally demonstrated in 2004 [32–34]. Due to its inherent strictly two-dimensional crystal structure, graphene possesses its unique electronic, thermal, mechanical, and chemical properties. For instance, graphene shows a high surface area of 2600 m2 g 1, much larger than that of graphite (~10 m2 g 1) and carbon nanotubes (~1300 m2 g 1) [35]. Its unique electronic properties include ambipolar electric field effect, the extremely high mobility of charge carriers (~105 cm2 V 1 s 1), massless electron, and quantum Hall effects even at room temperature [36, 37]. These remarkable properties make graphene promising in applications of many various electrochemical energy systems. To date, there have been several methods to prepare graphene in the literature, such as mechanical exfoliation [33], ultrasonic cleavage [38], arc-discharge approach [39], chemical vapor deposition [40], epitaxial growth on silicon carbide (SiC) [41], thermal reduction [42, 43], and chemical reduction [44–47]. Based on a review of the current literature, it seems that thermal reduction and chemical reduction methods are the most commonly used in the preparation process of graphene-based materials in electrochemical devices. Especially, the chemical reduction of graphene oxide is one of the best-established routes to make graphene toward the large-scale production for commercial applications [48, 49].
Nanostructure design, composition fine-tuning, and doping have been proven to be effective approaches in improving the electrochemical performance of electrode materials. Considerable attention has been paid to heteroatom doping for tuning and enhancing carbons’ unique physical and chemical properties. In particular, doped carbons with well controllable porosity and the large surface area can boost its electrochemical performance. Heteroatoms such as nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), sulfur (S), and fluorine (F) have been exploited to modify the surface bonding state and electron distribution of carbon architecture in order to improve their wettability and electronic conductivity [50–52]. For example, N dopant enhances positive charge density, leading to the increase of electronegativity and the acceleration of charge transfer [53]. Phosphorus doping substantially changes the local structure of hexagonal carbon due to the larger diameter of P than that of C [54]. Sulfur doping generates more defective sites and expands the interlayer distance of carbon with S generally located at the edge of the carbon layer [55]. Heteroatom doping provides a useful tool for modifying carbons’ unique physicochemical properties and further to boost ion storage performance.
Graphene materials have been investigated as a potential negative electrode material for PIBs. Nitrogen-doped few-layer graphene (N-FLG) was grown on nickel (Ni) foam using acetonitrile in a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process [56]. Electrochemical tests were performed in a half-cell vs. K+/K using CR2032 coin cells (C for ethylene carbonate, R for lithium (as anode), manganese dioxide (as cathode) and cylindrical form, 20 mm diameter, and 3.2 mm in height). N-FLG obtained an initial anodic charge (depotassiation) capacity of 350 mAh g 1 at 50 mAg 1 and remains constant over the 5 cycles at this rate. Notably, this is well beyond the theoretical capacity (279 mAh g 1) of a stage I KC8 GIC [12], close to the theoretical Li capacity in graphite of 372 mAh g 1. Galvanostatic testing
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 355
indicates capacities for the N-FLG and FLG are 200 mAhg 1 and 30 mAh g 1 at 100 mAg 1, over six-fold improved from undoped FLG. In order to elucidate the effect of N-doping sites on the enhanced performance, the mechanism for enhanced storage in N-FLG was further examined with in situ Raman spectroscopy. In situ Raman spectroscopy is a nondestructive testing technique for exploring the electronic and structural changes in graphene and graphite and has become a powerful tool to establish the understanding of Li+ staging in carbons [57, 58]. The in situ Raman results shed light on the role of N-doping which provides active sites in the carbon lattice that can locally store K ions. Meanwhile, N-dopant sites can sustain KC8 formation and thus provide extra charge capacity [56]. This methodology enlightens the post-researchers that atomically precise fabrication of materials can be a practical avenue to optimize the performance of electrode materials for nextgeneration batteries.
Ju group have also attempted some investigations on graphene-based materials in PIBs in order to make a library of carbon-based negative electrodes. A recent study reported few-layer F-doped graphene foam (FFGF) as anode materials for both LIBs and PIBs [59]. The FFGF was prepared via high-temperature solid-state method using PVDF as a single source reactant (Fig. 9.4). Fluorine doping was introduced due to F as the most electronegative element, and the introduction of F atoms into graphene makes the carbon hybridization change from sp2 to sp3, providing a new
356 X. Qi et al.
possibility to modify graphene properties. Electrochemical performance of the FFGF was investigated. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) profile displays three cathodic peaks around 0.5, 0.17, and 0.05 Vas well as one rather broad anodic peak around 0.68 V during the first cycle. The peak around 0.5 V in the first cycle can be attributed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and formation of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film on the F-doped graphene. Then, the sharp cathodic peaks situated at 0.17 Vand 0.05 Vare correlated with the K ions intercalation into FFGF stepwise to form KC8. In the following anodic scan, the broad peak between 0.45 and 0.8 V corresponds to the deintercalation of K ions. From the second cycle onward, the 0.5 V peak disappears, which means that the SEI film mainly forms in the first cathodic process. Besides, the other cathodic/anodic peaks are almost overlapped, suggesting the high reversibility and stability. The galvanostatic cycling profile of FFGF vs. K+/K at 50 mA g 1 shows a high initial discharge and charge capacity of 863.8 and 355.6 mA h g 1, respectively. The initial Coulombic efficiency is 41.2% due to the irreversible capacity from SEI formation, but it still remained above 90% after 20 cycles. The rate cycling performance of FFGF demonstrates that this electrode delivers capacities of 326.1, 271.9, 250.7, and 212.6 mA h g 1 at current rates of 50, 100, 200, and 500 mA g 1, respectively [59]. This material appears to be rather attractive in terms of performance. So far, further work is required to understand the mechanism of K+ insertion/extraction and to adjust the functional groups on the graphene surface to attain optimum performance parameters.
Afterward, phosphorus and oxygen dual-doped graphene (PODG) was synthesized via a thermal annealing method using triphenylphosphine (C18H15P) and graphite oxide as precursors [60]. It exhibits fairly outstanding electrochemical performance even reaching a reversible capacity of 566.6 mAh g 1 at 50 mA g 1, which is much higher than those of the other carbon anodes in PIBs [60]. The PODG electrode presents an ultralong cycling stability of 600 cycles at 2000 mA g 1 with a negligible capacity fading. Recently, few-layer nitrogen-doped graphene (FLNG) was successfully fabricated by a facile bottom-up synthesis technique with dicyandiamide and coal-tar pitch as raw materials [14]. The FLNG delivers competitive reversible capacity (320 mA h g 1 at 50 mA g 1 after 60 cycles), superior rate capability, as well as long-term cycling life at large current density (150mA h g 1 at 500 mA g 1 after 500 cycles) [14]. This superior electrochemical performance can be ascribed to the heteroatom doping, intrinsic high surface area, and enlarged interlayer distance. These structural features and their synergistic effects would promote ion and electron transportation with nanometer-scale diffusion length as well as facilitate the penetration of electrolyte, thereby leading to the superior potassium storage performance.

sections.heading: 9.2.3 Hard Carbon
sections.text:
Hard carbon, also known as nongraphitizable carbon, has been chosen as the competitive anode material in SIBs or PIBs as a result of its larger interlayer spacing. Stevens and Dahn have demonstrated that hard carbon can achieve a reversible
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 357
sodium capacity of ca. 300 mAh g 1 [61]. However, issues of hard carbon anode in SIBs are twofold: poor rate performance and the fact that the majority of its capacity is attained at sodiation potentials close to metal plating. Jian et al. [15] for the first time reported hard carbon microspheres (HCS) as an anode material for K+ storage and also compared their performance in SIBs and PIBs. Hard carbon microspheres are obtained via a hydrothermal synthesis of sucrose, followed by pyrolysis. More encouragingly, HCS shows advantageous performance for PIBs in two important respects compared with SIBs: (1) The ion-intercalation plateau region in the potential profiles of HCS in K cells is averaged at 0.2 V vs. K+/K in contrast to 0.05 V vs. Na+/Na of HCS/Na cell; this can reduce the risk of dendrite formation to a large degree in PIBs. (2) The rate capability of HCS in PIBs is much better than in SIBs. The HCS/K cells show capacities of 229, 205, 190, and 136 mAh g 1 at C/2, 1C, 2C, and 5C, respectively, while HCS/Na cells display capacities of 190, 127, 97, and 73 mAh g 1 at the same rates. In order to clarify why hard carbon exhibits a greater rate capability in PIBs than in SIBs, GITT was utilized to measure the diffusion coefficient of K-ions and Na-ions in HCS electrodes. The ionic diffusion coefficient in HCS electrodes can be determined based on Fick’s second law. The results surprisingly show that the diffusion coefficient of K-ions is slightly higher than that of Na-ions in both insertion and extraction processes (Fig. 9.5). This observation may be attributed to different binding energies between K-C and Na-C and a lower charge density of larger K-ions, which may facilitate a faster K-ion diffusion with a lower activation energy. Therefore, further studies are required to obtain the clear picture of a kinetic comparison between K+ and Na+ in carbon structures, particularly calculation and simulation.
In addition, Jian et al. [62] demonstrated that the limited rate capability of hard carbon spheres (HCS) and the capacity loss of soft carbon (SC) can be surmounted by synthesizing hard-soft carbon composites, integrating advantages of both materials. Furthermore, the authors replaced the commonly used polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder with sodium carboxymethylcellulose (CMCNa) in the process of
358 X. Qi et al.
electrode fabrication, which highly boosts the first cycle Coulombic efficiency, as it does for graphite anodes in PIBs [18]. Both HCS and HCS-SC composites exhibit much more stable cycling performance than SC, while SC and HCS-SC composites present greater rate capability than HCS. Even at 10 C, soft carbon electrode can present a high capacity of 121 mAh g 1 in contrast to 45 mAh g 1 of hard carbon. To shed light on the differences in rate capability among samples, the electronic conductivities of HCS and SC pellets were measured, which are 1.7 and 5.7 S m 1, respectively. The greater electronic conductivity of SC certainly should be responsible for its outstanding rate capability. As a consequence, it can be found that different non-graphitic carbon structures can be differentiated by their performance in K-ion storage. And it also reveals that unique non-graphitic structure with a great level of disorder along the c axis is crucial to avoid capacity loss of carbonaceous anodes in PIBs.
Although these pioneering studies mentioned above achieve encouraging electrochemical results, more research should be concentrated on investigating the storage mechanisms of K+ in hard carbon, which then provides appropriate guidance to enhance the performance of hard carbon as a PIBs anode.
Recently, Yang et al. [13] have successfully synthesized nitrogen/oxygen dualdoped hierarchical porous hard carbon (NOHPHC) applied as the anode material in PIBs by carbonizing and acidizing the NH2-MIL-101(Al) [The Materials of Institut Lavoisier is a mesoporous framework modified by amino groups which consists of super tetrahedral building units including three-dimensional octahedral clusters [Al3O] connected by 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate linker] precursor (see Fig. 9.6). Mixed K-ion storage mechanisms, including capacitance and diffusion, were proposed, in which the capacitance plays a more critical part in its outstanding electrochemical performance. In particular, the existence of aluminum (Al) could serve as the catalyst to induce the graphitization of carbon [63], and the nitrogen- and oxygen-containing organic ligands could provide the N and O resources for the in situ heteroatom doping. Figure 9.7a, b shows the field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of the carbonized product of the NH2-MIL-101 (Al) precursor. It can be clearly seen that the product is comprised of uniform flower-like microspheres with sizes of ca. 2 μm, which are similar to the morphology of the NH2-MIL-101(Al) precursor. And each flower consists of plenty of primary nano-sized “petals” with thicknesses of tens of nanometers. After further removing the metal or metal oxides in the carbonized product by acid treatment, the obtained
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 359
NOHPHC is composed of abundant mesoporous channels and mesopores, which could produce large amounts of defect sites to facilitate ion and electron transport. The NOHPHC electrode exhibits the high initial discharge and charge capacities of 1261 and 315 mA h g 1 at a current density of 50 mAg 1, respectively. The low
Coulombic efficiency of 25% can be ascribed to the formation of the SEI layer on the surface of the NOHPHC. For one thing, the electrolyte used in the PIBs could be responsible for this low efficiency; for another thing, the hierarchical porous structure and the high specific surface area may also lead to the low initial efficiency and slow capacity stabilization, which need more time for the complete formation of the SEI layer. Rate performance measurements were also carried out (Fig. 9.7d). It shows the NOHPHC obtained capacities of ca. 365 and 315 mAh g 1 at 25 and 50 mA g 1, respectively. And even at a high current density of 3000 mA g 1, a capacity of 118 mAh g 1 can be maintained with a capacity retention of 33%. When the current density is restored to 25 mA g 1, the reversible capacity nearly returns to its initial capacity which indicates the superior rate capability of the electrode. The electrode also achieved outstanding long-term cycling stability at 1050 mA g 1 for 1100 cycles. The capacity of the electrode fades from 174 to 130 mAh g 1 in the first 300 cycles, while only 4% capacity loss and nearly 100% efficiency occur in the subsequent cycles. The capacity fading in the first 300 cycles may be attributed to the fact that the fingerprint-like twisted structure was destroyed by the strain that is relevant to the intercalation of large K ions. The adsorption mechanism for capacity could account for the excellent cycling stability in the subsequent cycles. It is because of the superior rate capacity and excellent cycling performance of the NOHPHC electrode that the authors are determined to explore the contribution of two mechanisms, the surface-induced capacitive process and diffusion-controlled intercalation process, in the insertion/extraction of K+ qualitatively and quantitatively, respectively. Figure 9.7e illustrates the mixed mechanisms of potassium-ion storage. Quantitative analysis demonstrated that both capacitance and diffusion are responsible for the excellent K-ion storage, in which capacitance accounts for the majority of the superb electrochemical performance. It will provide a useful guide on the relationship between K-ion storage mechanisms and electrochemical properties for the carbonaceous anode.

sections.heading: 9.2.4 Carbon-Based Composites
sections.text:
Metals or nonmetals that undergo alloying reactions and store alkali metals are among the most appealing anode candidates for high-energy rechargeable batteries because they offer much higher capacities than the commercially employed graphite anodes. Lithium is known to form alloys (LixM) with various metals and nonmetals such as magnesium (Mg), Al, silicon (Si), germanium (Ge), tin (Sn), P, and antimony (Sb). For instance, the theoretical Li storage capacity is up to 4200 mA h g 1 for Si, 2959 mA h g 1 for P, 1600 mA h g 1 for Ge, and 990 mA h g 1 for Sn, respectively [64, 65]. In spite of the high theoretical capacity, the practical application of these alloy-based anode materials is still a vast challenge. A critical barrier that restricts the commercialization of these alloy-based anodes is that they suffer from intense capacity loss upon cycling. One commonly accepted reason is the aggregation and pulverization of active materials caused by severe volume changes. To date, numerous efforts have been devoted to tackling the intrinsic problem, and significant
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 361
progress has been achieved. The strategies for improving the performance of alloytype anodes mainly concentrate on engineering rational nanostructures and introducing conductive carbon substrate, both of which can effectively lead to the faster reaction kinetics and alleviate capacity decay.
So far, alloy-based anode materials in PIBs have also gradually drawn researchers’ interest in terms of their high theoretical capacities and effective strategies toward large volume variation. McCulloch et al. demonstrated that nano-sized antimony carbide (Sb-C) composites exhibited an initial discharge capacity of ca. 880 mAh g 1 at a current density of 35 mAg 1 [66]. Especially, carbon can serve both as an efficient conductive pathway and a buffer layer to mitigate the large volume change of Sb during the cycling process. Due to the occurrence of some side reactions and SEI formation on the surface of the electrodes, the capacity of 880 is irreversible. Sb reversibly alloys with K upon the subsequent cycles, forming cubic K3Sb with a capacity of 650 mAh g 1.
Phosphorus (P) possesses a high theoretical capacity of 2595 mAh g 1 because it can form potassium phosphide (K3P), a binary phase with K [67]. However, the low electrical conductivity and large volume changes limit its further application. In order to restrain the inherent volume expansion of phosphorus during the charge and discharge process, the phosphorus/carbon (P-C) composites are synthesized by a simple mechanical ball-milling as an anode for PIBs. The P-C electrode presents the first discharge and charge capacity of 958.9 and 482.9 mA h g 1, respectively, and a low initial Coulombic efficiency of 50.3% [68]. It still maintained a rather high charge capacity of 323.5 mAh g 1 after 50 cycles at a rate of 50 mA g 1. The outstanding electrochemical performance is mainly ascribed to a structural transformation from red P to black P and the formation of the stable P-C bond, mitigating the dramatic volume expansion upon cycling effectively. Pre-potassiation treatment was carried out to boost the low initial coulomb efficiency. The authors also conducted the X-ray diffraction characterization to further elucidate the K-ion storage mechanism. And it was found that a KP phase was detected during the alloying-de-alloying process.
Sn, as a well-known alloy anode material, has been massively studied for LIBs and SIBs. Tin (Sn) is capable of forming Li4.4Sn and Na15Sn4 alloys reversibly in these cells and displaying theoretical capacities of 991 and 845 mA h g 1, respectively [64, 69]. When utilized as PIBs anode materials, the results show that an Sn atom can accept only one K atom to form KSn alloy with a capacity of 226 mA h g 1. Due to the large volume changes (~197%) during the cycling process, the electrochemical performance of pure Sn is unsatisfactory as reported in previous work [70]. A common strategy to conquer this problem is to prepare Sn-carbon composites in which Sn nanoparticles are mixed with or dispersed in a carbon component. Sultana et al. [71] reported that ball-milled Sn-graphite nanocomposite anodes for PIBs delivered a capacity of 150–170 mAh g 1 for 10–15 cycles at 25 mA g 1 within the potential window of 0.01–2 V with 0.75 M KPF6 in a mixture of EC and DEC electrolyte. Ex situ XRD characterization indicates K2Sn5 and K4Sn23 are the likely potassiated phases. Zhang et al. [72] reported the electrochemical performance of ball-milled phosphorous/carbon (P/C) and tin phosphide/carbon (Sn4P3/C)
362 X. Qi et al.
composites as anode materials for K-ion storage. The P-C electrode produced over 2000 and 1000 mAh g 1 for the first two charge cycles, followed by a sudden capacity loss, only with a retention of 9% of the capacity after 20 cycles. In contrast, the electrochemical performance of the Sn4P3/C composite is more encouraging. The Sn4P3/C electrode displayed superior rate capability: 385 mAh g
1 and 222 mAh g 1 at 50 mA g 1 and 1 A g 1, respectively. More importantly, this alloy anode retained a capacity of over 300 mAh g 1 after 50 cycles. A two-step reaction helping to buffer the stress was proposed for K+ storage (Fig. 9.8), which explains the improved electrochemical performance clearly.
Very recently, Ju group also make some efforts in C@M (M= Sn, Sb) composites as anode materials for K-ion storage [73, 74]. Three-dimensional (3D) hierarchically porous carbon/Sn (HPCS) composite was synthesized by in situ generated sodium chloride (NaCl) crystals as templates, followed by calcination at three different temperatures. The thickness of the 3D network of carbon ultrathin films is only several nanometers. The Sn nanoparticles are uniformly distributed in the inner surface of hierarchically porous carbon materials and preserve the structure and interface well, leading to a highly reversible electrochemical reaction. Obviously, the 3D hierarchically porous framework could provide efficient space for K+ storage and fast pathways for K+ transportation. Electrochemical results showed that HPCS-650 exhibited both high capacity and excellent cyclability. To be specific, the electrode at 650 C obtained a first charge and discharge capacity of 847.9 mAh g 1 and 384.5 mAh g 1 at 50 mAg 1. Moreover, the electrode still maintained a reversible capacity of about 276.4 mAh g 1 for 100 cycles steadily with a Columbic efficiency of more than 96%. However, the sample at lower carbonization temperature (450 C) didn’t display relatively more superior performance than that of other samples. The reason may be that the lower degree of graphitization gives rise to poor conductivity and K+ meet greater hindrance in the ion transfer process. In order to elucidate the Sn and K alloying process, the authors focus on the analysis of the third cycle of the cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles and propose the reversible alloying and conversion reaction mechanisms. These can be summarized as the following equations:
9 Carbon-Based Materials for Advanced Potassium-Ion Batteries Anode 363
23Snþ 4K $ K4Sn23 (9:1) K4Sn23 þ K $ K2Sn5 (9:2) 8Cþ Kþ þ e $ KC8 (9:3)
Antimony nanoparticles uniformly embedded in the 3D porous carbon synthesized by similar methods have also been shown to offer high discharge capacities, superior rate capability, and relatively stable cycle life for K-ion storage [73]. Apparently, some metal alloying systems have displayed promising performance for K+ storage; meanwhile, the large volume changes of K alloying reactions will pose challenges and should be further evaluated.
Compared to unsustainable carbon resources, biomass can serve as a renewable resource to prepare carbon electrodes for the applications of electrochemical energy storage [75]. It’s reported that biomass carbon materials have been extensively applied as anode materials in LIBs and SIBs [76–78]. Similar to the findings reported for Li and Na, this class of materials also have been proven to intercalate K successfully. For example, some waste or scrap materials derived from seafood waste (chitin) [79], waste tires [80], or pencils [81] can be explored as carbon anodes for K+ storage. The idea that biowaste materials are recycled to synthesize anodes for PIBs is interesting but instructive and conducive to the sustainable development of the whole society.

sections.heading: 9.3 Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
This chapter presented an overview of the most up-to-date progress in carbonbased materials as anode materials for potassium-ion batteries. Since the intercalation of potassium ions into graphite anodes has been demonstrated to be feasible, researchers have successively conducted more investigations on other carbon anode materials; meanwhile, some advancements have been achieved. However, the research on nonaqueous PIBs is still in its infancy stage; there are some challenges to be surmounted for the future development and practical applications of this new battery chemistry, including but not limited to (1) understanding of the storage mechanisms and kinetics of K ions during the intercalation reactions; (2) focus on understanding of the SEI layer, its relationship to the electrolytes/additives used, and the mechanism of formation and growth; (3) the optimization of current electrolyte and binder systems to make it compatible and efficient; and (4) underlying safety hazards due to more chemically reactive K than Li and Na. There is still a long winding road to fulfilling viable performance of emerging PIBs for practical applications. Overall, carbon-based materials are the most prospective electrode candidate materials for the future practical applications of PIBs. And there are good reasons to believe that potassium-ion batteries have the remarkable potential to meet crucial goals for future energy storage devices.

sections.heading: 10.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Commercial lithium-ion batteries (265 Wh/kg) provide 6.5 more energy than lead acid and more than 2 that of nickel-metal hydride (NiMH). These large gains in energy density have ushered in the wide proliferation of portable electronics and the commercialization of long-range personal electric vehicles. Car manufacturing companies such as Tesla and Volkswagen propose that large-scale production of electric vehicles will lower the battery pack cost to $100/kWh (currently around $150/kWh). Such large-scale projects have already started and will be more prevalent by 2020. However, the success of the electric vehicle hinges on the safety, durability, and lifetime of the battery pack. These characteristics are critically important because the lithium-ion battery operates outside its electrochemical stability window. During

charging, the electrolyte is exposed to potentials beyond its stability, so it reduces on the graphite anode and may oxidize on the cathode. The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the electrolyte is below the Fermi level of the anode, and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the electrolyte lies above the Fermi level of the cathode. In addition, cathode discharge products may have increased solubility in the electrolyte and may be lost during cycling. Thus, battery lifetime is governed by the degree with which these undesired reactions are mitigated. For example, the proper choice of electrolyte solvents and additives form a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) on the graphite anode. This thin layer of solid electrolyte is not electrically conductive, so it stops further decomposition of the electrolyte, but it allows the permeation of lithium cations (Li+) such that battery can continue to operate. The commercial assembly process of lithium-ion batteries contains lithium in the cathode. The graphite anode is delithiated at the time of cell fabrication, so the battery is assembled in its discharged state. The electrochemically catalyzed selfassembly of the SEI during initial formation cycles irreversibly consumes lithium from the cathode which requires careful balancing of the electrodes by loading with excess cathode material. As a result, this practice reduces the energy density of the battery. In addition, the SEI decomposes at temperatures above 60 C which further reduces the energy density due to the need for additional temperature management infrastructure. Similar chemistry occurs at the cathode.
Electrodes assembled with preformed stable interfaces may improve the cell energy density since no excess would be required at the cathode. Popular strategies for improving the interface stability of electrodes include various vapor/vacuum deposition of thin oxide layers and thin polymeric coatings. It is desirable that such coatings (1) increase the stability of the electrolyte at the electrode interface, (2) reduce dissolution of soluble species, (3) are thin enough as to not significantly increase cell impedance, and (4) are applied in a simple, fast, and cheap manner. When applied, such coatings can extend the cycle life of the battery and may allow for stability at higher charge voltages with corresponding increases in extracted capacity during discharge. In addition, advanced lithium-ion cathodes such as lithium-rich and nickel-rich cathodes also benefit from such stable coatings with reported increases in cycle life. Battery safety can also be improved by coatings applied to common polypropylene separators. In the catastrophic event of a thermal runaway, cell temperature can quickly rise above 160 C which irreversibly shrinks commercial separators and exposes the electrodes to electric shorts. Ceramic and polymer-coated separators have been demonstrated to have improved thermal stabilities and conductivities of lithium cations and superior wettability by electrolyte solvents. The economic implementation of such coatings may foster the commercialization of advanced lithium-ion batteries with up to 20% improvement in energy density at the cell level (up to 315 Wh/kg). Over time, such advanced technology may mature to offer >10,000 cycles which may foster the introduction of electric drivetrains for vehicles used in commercial platforms (such as carrier trucks, USPS, etc.) with grueling nonstop schedules of operations. There are only a handful of batteries which go beyond lithium-ion. They commonly replace graphite anodes with alloying and ultimately pure metallic anodes (lithium, sodium, or magnesium)
370 C. B. Bucur
and pair them with cheap, high energy density cathodes such as sulfur or oxygen. While the challenges of these batteries are more numerous and more difficult to solve than those of lithium-ion, they also benefit from thin polymeric coatings to impede dissolution of discharge intermediates (sulfur is the typical example), to construct highly conductive electrode matrices, or to reign in the uncontrollable dendritic deposition of metallic lithium or sodium. As such, a lithium-sulfur battery may offer up to 3 gains in energy density (760 Wh/kg). These future, post-lithium-ion batteries may usher in the age of the long-range electric plane. For reference, an electric Tesla Model S 85 vehicle has an overall energy density of 40 Wh/kg and an average cruising power usage of 10 W/kg (C/4 operation), whereas a Cessna 172 airplane has an overall energy density of 470 Wh/kg with an average cruising power usage of 80 W/kg (if electric, C/6 operation). A rate of C corresponds to complete discharge or charge in 1 h; C/4 corresponds to full discharge in 4 h. Comprehensive reviews for the use of polymeric coatings in batteries have been published in the past 5 years [18, 25, 34, 63, 94]. The following chapter will focus on cutting edge advances in the past 3 years. Part 2 of the chapter will focus on simple polymeric coatings based on template polymerization of spin coating addition, and part 3 will demonstrate the advantages offered by the layer-by-layer multilayer technique.

sections.heading: 10.2 Simple Polymeric Coatings
sections.text: Stabilizing films which form in situ during battery operation consist in part of polymerized solvent or additive components. Common electrode-coating techniques include vapor deposition such as atomic layer deposition of stable oxides such as aluminum oxide (Al2O3). While this technique can control the adsorbed thickness to anatomically specified thickness, it is very slow (1 Å per cycle) and very expensive (half a million dollar instrument cost). Similarly, thin coatings can be quickly and cheaply applied from polymer solutions. The challenge is to obtain conformal and thin polymeric coatings as the most desirable conductive polymers, such as polyaniline (PANI), a mixture of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS) ionomers, polyacetylenes (PAC), polyphenylenes, or polypyrroles (PPY), contain conjugated double bonds and are not truly soluble in any solvent. They may, however, form good dispersions in some solvents. Table 10.1 lists many of the polymers of interest reported here.

Several recent reports suggest that lithium metal plates smoothly from gel polymer or polymer electrolytes. Byon et al. constructed a lithium-iodine battery with a high energy density of 330Wh/kg by pairing a high-concentration aqueous iodine solution with a water-stable solid electrolyte lithium aluminum titanium phosphate (Li1+x+3zAlx(Ti, Ge)2 xSi3zP3 zO12) (LATP) with a lithium-stable gel polymer electrolyte bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (TFSI)/N-methyl-N-propylpiperidinium (PP13) based on polyethylene oxide (PEO) (PEO20/LiTFSI/PP13TFSI/SiO2) [103]. The gel polymer electrolyte is stable up to 200 C, forms a stable interface with lithium metal, and promotes smooth deposition/dissolution at the anode. The total conductivity was 0.7 mS/cm at 55 C, and a stable capacity of 200 mAh/g is reported with a flat plateau at 3.5 V (Fig. 10.1). The rate of operation was 1 mA/cm2. For reference, typical rates of operation for commercial lithium-ion cells (Panasonic NCR18650B) at C/3 rates are 1.7 mA/cm2 at room temperature. A similar approach of controlling the lithium metal anode was reported by Goodenough et al. who used a lithium fluoride (LiF)-enhanced garnet solid electrolyte lithium lanthanum titanate (Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12)-(LLZT-LiF) and a cross-linked PEO/LiTFSI polymer electrolyte with a melting point of 240 C to control the lithium metal anode [54]. With a conductivity of 0.5 mS at room temperature, lithium/LLZT/lithium iron phosphate (Li/gel/LLZT/LiFePO4) and Li/gel/LLZT/sulfur batteries were constructed and cycled with a real capacity of 1 mAh/cm2 (Fig. 10.1) and at rates of 0.2 mA/cm2. The lithium-sulfur battery observed no capacity decay over 100 cycles with 1000 mAh/g capacities.
Nafion and polyvinylidene were cast-coated in sequence on a lithium metal foil in a lithium-sulfur battery with a liquid electrolyte. This paper by Luo et al. reports that these thin coatings result in smooth plating (Fig. 10.2) of lithium at the anode [59]. The resulting polymeric membrane had a density of 0.2 mg/cm2 and is 3 μm
